column17: On Sept 19th, residents of Gireida held a vigil demanding the perpetrators who killed a liutenant the day before in Idan village to be arrested and brought to trial. [Size=no report]
On Sept 19th, residents of Talodi staged a sit-in to demand that the gold exploration companies stop working, as instructed by the South Kordofan governor the previous week.
On Sept 19th, in Wad Medani, protesters demonstrated to demand accountability and to put the members of the former regime on trial. [Size=thousands]
On Sept 19th, in Port Sudan, protesters demonstrated to demand accountability and to put the members of the former regime on trial. [Size=thousands]

On Sept 19th, protesters marched to the headquarters of the Ministry of Justice in Khartoum, demanding the elimination of all symbols of the former regime in the country. Police forces blocked all roads leading to the presidential palace to prevent rebels from reaching him. [Size=thousands]

On Sept 18th and 19th, in Gereida, 8 people in total (including a woman, a child and an army lieutenant) were killed by unknown perpetrators armed with Kalashnikov and other machine guns. Fatalities are spread over two events (2).
On Sept 19th, residents of Kalogi staged a sit-in to demand the the gold exploration companies to stop working, as instructed by the South Kordofan governor during the previous week.
On Sept 19th, owners of unlicensed vehicles staged a protest in El Geneina demanding their vehicles not to be banned from the roads. [Size=thousands]
On Sept 19th, in Khartoum, protesters demonstrated to demand accountability and to put the members of the former regime on trial. [Size=thousands]
On Sept 19th, residents of Gedaref staged a protest demanding the removal of the state governor. [Size=no report]
On Sept 20th, a protest was held by residents of Rabak calling for the removal of a laundry due to the health and environmental damage it brings to the neighborhood. [Size=no report]
Around Sept 20th (exact date not reported), in the village of Idan (Gereida) armed herdsmen attacked farmers. No fatalities reported.

Around Sept 20th (exact date not reported), after an attack by herdsmen on farmers in Idan, army and police pursued the herdsmen. Following an armed clash, an army lieutenant was shot dead, two policemen were wounded and one person went missing.

On Sept 20, a protest was held in Omdurman against the erection of a monument of Abdelazim Abubakr, who was killed in the same city, during protests against the former regime of Omar Al Bashir. [Size=no report]

On Sept 22nd, a protest of hundreds against bread shortages, price increase and scarcity of public transport was held by students in Nyala.Police intervened, using Dushka machine guns and tear gas to disperse protestors. Four students were wounded and some passed out due to the tear gas. [Size=hundreds]

On Sept 22nd, residents of Talodi organized a demonstration against the visit of a delegation from Khartoum. Protesters also demanded the removal of the governor. An army force with two vehicles blocked the protesters' way to the mining factory. [Size=no report]

On Sept 22rd, in Nyala, for the second day in a row, a demonstration of thousands was held to demand the dismissal of acting governors, an end to violence and the arrest of all perpetrators of crimes in Darfur. The protest was mainly attended by students. [Size=thousands]

On Sept 22nd, in Wadi Halfa, dozens of protesters gathered to demonstrate against toxic gold mining operations and to demand the immediate departure of the companies and removal of the Rapid Support Forces from the mining areas. [Size=dozens]

On Sept 22rd, in Nyala a demonstration of thousands was held to demand the dismissal of acting governors, an end to violence and the arrest of all perpetrators of crimes in Darfur. The protest was mainly attended by students. [Size=thousands]
On Sept 23rd protestors took the streets of El Abbasiya condemning the killing of 8 people in Gereida on Sept 18th. [Size= no report]

On Sept 23rd thousands of protestors took the streets of Omdurman, condemning violence by security forces the previous day against students demonstrating in Nyala city and the killing of 8 people in Gereida on Sept 18th. [Size= thousands]

On Sept 23rd, thousands of protestors took the streets of Khartoum, condemning violence by security forces against students demonstrating the previous day in Nyala city, and the killing of 8 people in Gereida on Sept 18th. [Size= thousands]

On Sept 23rd, in El Fasher, a demonstration of thousands was held to demand the dismissal of acting governors, an end to violence and the arrest of all perpetrators of crimes in Darfur. [Size=thousands]

On Sept 23rd thousands of protestors took the streets of El Obeid, condemning violence by security forces the previous day against students demonstrating in Nyala city and the killing of 8 people in Gereida on Sept 18th. [Size= thousands]

On Sept 23rd thousands of protestors took the streets of El Hasahisa, condemning violence by security forces the previous day against students demonstrating in Nyala city and the killing of 8 people in Gereida on Sept 18th. [Size= thousands]

On Sept 23rd thousands of protestors took the streets of Kassala, condemning violence by security forces the previous day against students demonstrating in Nyala city and the killing of 8 people in Gereida on Sept 18th. [Size= thousands]

On Sept 23rd thousands of protestors took the streets of Gedaref, condemning violence by security forces the previous day against students demonstrating in Nyala city and the killing of 8 people in Gereida on Sept 18th. [Size= thousands]

On Sept 23rd, in El Geneina, a demonstration of thousands was held to demand the dismissal of acting governors, an end to violence and the arrest of all perpetrators of crimes in Darfur. [Size=thousands]

On Sept 23rd, in Zalingei, a demonstration of thousands was held to demand the dismissal of acting governors, an end to violence and the arrest of all perpetrators of crimes in Darfur. [Size=thousands]

On Sept 23rd thousands of protestors took the streets of Kosti, condemning violence by security forces the previous day against students demonstrating in Nyala city and the killing of 8 people in Gereida on Sept 18th. [Size= thousands]

On Sept 23rd thousands of protestors took the streets of Khartoum North, condemning violence by security forces the previous day against students demonstrating in Nyala city and the killing of 8 people in Gereida on Sept 18th. [Size= thousands]

On Sept 23rd, in Ed Daein, a demonstration of thousands was held to demand the dismissal of acting governors, an end to violence and the arrest of all perpetrators of crimes in Darfur. [Size=thousands]

On Sept 23rd, in Nyala, for the third day in a row, a demonstration of thousands was held to demand the dismissal of acting governors, an end to violence and the arrest of all perpetrators of crimes in Darfur. The protest was mainly attended by students. [Size=thousands]
On Sept 24th, protesters helda sit-in in Sawarda (coded as Abri with GP2 for unfound Sawarda) against a gold mining company, which causes environmental damage. [Size=no report]
On Sept 25th, in Al Kalakla a protest was staged in solidarity with the wave of violence that hit students and citizens of Nyala the previous week. [Size=no report]
On September 26th, the Sudanese government announced the closure of the border with Libya and the CAR. The closures were justified on the grounds of (unspecified) security and economic threats.

On Sept 26th, a protest of unknown size was staged in front of the Sudanese Foreign Ministry and the Egyptian embassy in Khartoum. Protesters called for the release of the Sudanese student Waleed Abdelrahman, who was arrested in Cairo participating in Sept 20th demonstrations. [Size=no report]

column9: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change; SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; SCP: Sudanese Congress Party
column17: On September 27th, the residences of several political leaders (including from the FFC, SPA, and SCP) were attacked with molotov cocktails in Khartoum, with no injuries reported. The attackers are alleged to be ""affiliates of the deposed Al Bashir regime"". [size=no report]

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On September 28th, during a protest gathering and amidst unclear circumstances, at least three people were killed in Kidingeer (South Darfur state). Reports suggest that protesters were attacked (with demonstrators possibly protesting against a killing by security forces the same day) by military and/or RSF paramilitaries (both actors coded), with one report suggesting six (including an RSF soldiers) died. [size=no report]

On September 28th, gunmen on horses and camels (described as 'militiamen', and provisionally coded as a Darfur pastoralist militia) attacked Sindu village (Central Darfur state), killing one (one source says two, lower estimate used) and wounding eight civilians (who had recently returned to the area following displacement). The village was torched and looted, and several women and children are missing.
On September 29th, protesters gathered in Mukjar (Central Darfur) to demonstrate the attack on Sindu the previous day. [size=dozens]
On or around October 1st, demonstrators gathered in Jabal Aulia, to protest the growing of a crop deemed harmful to human health by an investment company in Yarmouk. [size=hundreds]
On October 1st, demonstrators gathered in Asalaya (White Night state), calling for electricity to be introduced to the village. [size=no report]

On October 1st, gunmen riding camels (coded as a Darfur pastoralist militia) attacked a cattle camp near Libya village in Jebel Marrah (Central Darfur state, coordinates used), abducting two children and stealing livestock. When pastoralists from the camp confronted the attackers, the gunmen shot and seriously wounded a local pastoralist.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: At an unspecified time (mentioned alongside an event from early October 2019, and coded as 1 October 2019 at time prec3), two female children were raped by men in RSF uniform (and coded as such) at or near Nertiti (Nertiti locality, Central Darfur state).

On October 2nd, five gunmen (coded as Darfur militiamen) attacked three IDP farmers near Nabagai (South Darfur state, approximate coordinates 5km west of Gereida used at prec2), killing one and wounding the other two, after they resisted the efforts of the attackers to steal their donkey cart.
During the week beginning September 30th, two soldiers raped a 13 year-old girl (implied to be an IDP) near Sortony IDP camp (North Darfur).

On October 2nd, employees of the state revenue authority demonstrated in Khartoum in response to collapsing government revenue collection, and calling for the dismissal of the Director General, and reforms to the workplace. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: During the week beginning September 30th, five armed pastoralists in military uniform (coded as RSF paramilitaries) raped two girls (implied to be IDPs) north of Shalaiya IDP camp (Central Darfur), after firing in the air and then chasing the girls (and four other girls who escaped capture).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On October 2nd, SLM-Al Nur rebels alleged that RSF paramilitaries attacked their position at Oro (no location found, coordinates for Jebel Marrah, Central Darfur, used at prec2). The rebels claimed to have repulsed the attack, and inflicted ""heavy casualties"" upon the RSF (10 fatalities coded).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On or after October 2nd, RSF paramilitaries reportedly attacked civilians in the area of Oro (no geographic information found, coordinates for Jebel Marrah, Central Darfur, used at prec2), and looted 200 head of cattle. There is no information regarding casualties.

On the week beginning on September 30th, protesters gathered in Kassala (Kassala state), calling for a legally questionable sale of a gas market to a private investor to be suspended. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On October 3rd, demonstrators torched the facilities of various gold mining companies in Talodi (South Kordofan state), before attacking an RSF paramilitary base, killing one RSF and wounding several. Three security guards of the mining companies were also killed, and 6 demonstrators injured (three of whom were seriously wounded by gunfire). [size=hundreds]

On October 3rd, demonstrators marched to a funeral in Khartoum for a recently identified victim of the June 3rd Khartoum massacre (who had been missing), carrying the recently identified body, and calling for justice for the victims of those who died during the uprising. [size=large]
On or around October 5th, militiamen killed two civilians (coded as pastoralsts) and looted cattle, in the area of Tullus (South Darfur state).
On 5 October 2019, unknown armed men raped three female children in the Golo area (Rokoro locality, Central Darfur state).
On October 5th, demonstrators - including IDPs - gathered in Kutum (North Darfur), to protest against an unexplained killing of an IDP at a gold mine in El Tomat the previous day. [size=hundreds]
On October 6th, demonstrators gathered in Kadugli (South Kordofan state), calling for the acting governor to resign amidst deteriorating security in South Kordofan. [size=dozens]
On October 6th, unknown gunmen raped a 14 year-old girl in the area of Koron (Central Darfur).

On October 7th, merchants gathered at Ed Daein (East Darfur state), protesting tax and VAT fees, and calling for the head of the state tax chamber to resign, citing links between the head and the Bashir regime. [size=dozens]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On October 7th, over 200 RSF paramilitaries attacked two mines in Talodi (South Kordofan), beating 8 or 10 people, arresting 10 or 14 persons (who were kept in a metal container), and engaging in looting. The 10 prisoners were released at the intervention of the military the following day. The paramilitaries were not from South Kordofan.

On October 7th, teachers mobilised a protest in Jabal Aulia (Khartoum state), amidst a nationwide strike by school students and teachers against mounting insecurity and attacks against pupils and teachers. [size=no report]

On October 7th, residents of Talodi (South Kordofan state) marched to the military HQ in the town, calling for military protection following an attack by out-of-state paramilitaries the same day. One source indicates the RSF paramilitaries fled the town following the protest. [size=large]

On October 7th, workers and resistance committee members of the Omdurman Teaching Hospital demonstrated against the management of the hospital, and also called for an independent judicial system in the country. [size=no report]
On or before October 8th, soldiers were reported to have raped a 12 year-old girl in the area of Golo (Central Darfur). There is no further information.

On October 8th, striking workers from Petronide (an oil firm owned by the former state intelligence agency NISS) demonstrated at the company HQ in Khartoum, in a dispute relating to unfavourable contracts workers were compelled to accept, and the firm's monopoly on the petroleum sector. [size=no report]

On October 8th, staff at Ali Abdel Fattah hospital in Khartoum demonstrated against inadquate health facilities offered by the hospital, and against the part-privitisation of the hospital at the hands of its current manager. [size=no report]
On October 8th, residents of Berber and surrounding areas gathered in Berber (River Nile state) to protest against environmental damage caused by a cement factory. [size=large]

On October 9th, journalists working for state news agency SUNA demonstrated outside the SUNA HQ in Khartoum, calling for a restructuring of the organisation and to shake off editorial policies reminiscent of the Bashir regime. [size=small]

On October 10th, IDPs demonstrated in El Fasher (North Darfur), articulating a range of greivances, including against insecurity and widespread gun ownership; pollution related to gold mining; the presence of supposed foreign settlers in the area; and for greater assistance for facilitating the return of IDPs. [size=no report]

On or around October 10th, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum, calling for the release of three Sudanese youths to be released from detention in Egypt, where they have been held for three years. [size=hundreds]

On or around October 10th, demonstrators gathered in Kassala (Kassala state), calling for the release of three Sudanese youths to be released from detention in Egypt, where they have been held for three years. [size=hundreds]

On October 10th, residents of Karima (Northern state) built barricades on the roads in order to prevent the Governor of the state from leaving an event, in protest deteriorating economic conditions. Security forces (coded as police) were reported to have attacked protesters, and the source notes that one protester was wounded when they were hit by a security vehicle, though it does not specify whether this was deliberate or accidental. [size=no report]

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On October 10th, demonstrators marched in Khartoum, calling for the root causes of Sudan's civil wars to be resolved. Demonstrators were blocked from reaching the Presidential Palace by police and RSF paramilitaries, who fired tear gas and used batons against demonstrators. [size=large]

On October 10th, unknown gunmen shot and wounded two brothers at Kombo (Central Darfur, coordinates for Komba Denko used). SLM-TC rebels accused government militiamen of being responsible, but this is so far unconfirmed (actor1 provisionally coded as UAG).

On October 10th, demonstrators gathered in Ed Debba (Northern state), calling for a Saudi investor to desist from establishing further projects in the nearby area, which the demonstrators say risks causing environmental damage, and displacing locals from their area of residence. [size=no report]

On or around October 10th, workers at the Eye Hospital in Khartoum demonstrated against the administration of the hospital, and calling for it to be replaced by a new administrative team without links to the Bashir-era. [size=no report]
On October 10th, demonstrators marched to the Ministry of Health in Khartoum, to protest the handlings of the bodies of victims of the June 3rd massacre. [size=no report]

On October 13th, 2019, demonstrators gathered at al Hilaliya (El Gazira state), and begun a sit-in that lasted at least eight days. The protesters are calling for a change in the senior administrative personnel in the area, and poor health care, education, enivornmental standards and lack of electricity. [size=no report]
On October 14th, armed pastoralists shot and killed a farmer near Abu Gamra (North Darfur state), after he attempted to save his crops from the armed men's camels.

On October 14th, PDF paramilitaries staged a roadblock on the road between El Fula and Khartoum (coordinates for El Fule, West Kordofan state, used at prec2). The soldiers were calling to be fully integrated into the army. As there is no report of violence or use of barricades, the event has been coded as a peaceful protest. [size=dozens]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 14 October 2019, RSF paramilitaries attacked and wounded 17 civilians at Khor Waral village (South Kordofan state), and looted some of their belongings. Three people are reported missing as of late November (fatality precision coded at 2).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column16: Radio Dabanga; Radio Miraya; Sudan Tribune
column17: On October 15th, RSF paramilitaries and members of the Hawazmah ethnic group were reported to have ambushed (some sources say attacked) civilians at an unspecified road near Khor Waral (South Kordofan state, coordinates for Waral used at prec2). Conflicting accounts say that 16 traders have been detained by the attackers (three of whom were later released), though there are currently no reports of injuries or fatalities.
Between 15 to 22 October 2019, IDPs demonstrated in Kebkabiya IDP camp (North Darfur state), in opposition to the ""status"" of peace talks underway in Juba. [size=no report]

Between 15 to 22 October 2019, IDPs demonstrated at an IDP camp in El Geneina (presumed to be Krinding IDP camp, West Darfur state), in opposition to the ""status"" of peace talks underway in Juba. [size=no report]
Between 15 to 22 October 2019, IDPs demonstrated in Tawila IDP camp (North Darfur state), in opposition to the ""status"" of peace talks underway in Juba. [size=no report]
Between 15 to 22 October 2019, IDPs demonstrated in Hamidiya IDP camp near Zalingei (Central Darfur state), in opposition to the ""status"" of peace talks underway in Juba. [size=no report]
Between 15 to 22 October 2019, IDPs demonstrated in Hasahia IDP camp near Zalingei (Central Darfur state), in opposition to the ""status"" of peace talks underway in Juba. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On 17 October 2019, soldiers from SAF Military Intelligence beat a man at a checkpoint in Al Abbasiya town (South Kordofan state), before detaining him at the military base in the town, and holding him until Oct 31 on the suspicion that he was supplying goods to the SPLM-N.

On October 17th, protesters gathered in Kassala (Kassala state), calling for the resignation of senior health officials in the area due to the spread of Dengue fever, and calling for the sale of a gas market in the city to a private investor to be cancelled. [size=thousands]
On October 17th, demonstrators gathered in Haya (Red Sea state), calling for the local commissioner as well as figures associated with the Bashir regime to be removed from office. [size=no report]

On October 17th, demonstrators gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), protesting an official decision (made during the Bashir era) to reassign land originally allocated for a school to be used for commercial purposes. [size=no report]

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column16: Sudan News Agency; UN Panel of Experts; Xinhua
column17: On 17 October 2019, SLM/A-Al Nur clashed with SAF soldiers near Brobas in East Jebel Marrah locality (South Darfur state). Both sides accused the other of initiating the clash. There is no mention of fatalities in any of the sources.

On October 18th, farmers attempted to clear pastoralists from farmland in the area of Martal in East Jebel Marrah (coordinates for Deribat, South Darfur state, used at precision). The pastoralists fired towards the farmers, wounding a 12 year-old boy.

On October 18th, 2019, protests resumed in Talodi (South Kordofan state). Demonstrators are calling for RSF paramilitaries to be removed from mines in the area; for health services to be improved; and for the Amir of the area to be replaced. [size=no report]
On October 18th, 11 pastoralists attacked and beat a farmer in the vicinity of Faluja (South Darfur state), before stealing his possessions and his donkey.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column16: UN Panel of Experts; Xinhua; Sudan News Agency
column17: On 18 October 2019, SLM/A-Al Nur clashed with SAF soldiers at an unspecified area to the east of Jebel Marrah (coordinates used for Katur, Tawila locality, North Darfur state). Both sides accused the other of initiating the clash. There is no mention of fatalities in any of the sources.
On October 19th, men collecting firewood were shot at by unknown gunmen near Manawashi (South Darfur state). One of the men died in the gunfire, and three brothers were wounded.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On Octber 19th, RSF paramilitaries severely beat a civilian in Talodi (South Kordofan state), after he and two other members of the Talodi Youth Association for Development visited Altugula gold mine to meet community leaders. The victim escaped and was protected by Military Intelligence soldiers. The RSF began to shoot in the area of the market, scattering residents.

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On October 20th, 2019, FFC and NCP students clashed at El Zaeem El Azhari University in Khartoum North, after studies resumed following an 11-month closure. Dozens were reported to have been wounded. [size=dozens]
On October 20th, 2019, vendors demonstrated at the Tax Office in Nyala (South Darfur state), against a significant increase in taxation. [size=dozens]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On October 20th, departing RSF paramilitaries deliberately poured chemicals (including cyanide) into waterways near Atugula gold mine near Talodi (South Kordofan state), amidst ongoing protests and violence relating to pollution caused by gold mining. Two animals died from drinking the water, prompting residents to avoid drinking it.

column7: Pastoralists (Sudan); Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column16: Al Rakoba; Radio Dabanga; Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation
column17: On October 20, 2019, a pastoralist militia operating alongside RSF paramilitaries attacked and looted five villages (Um Jadwal, Haddad, Amoud El Sahab, Keyokei and Kiwi) around Gereida (South Darfur state, coordinates used at prec2), beating civilians, robbing cattle and causing residents (at least some of whom were IDP farmers) to flee. Two of the residents have gone missing following the attacks.

On October 21st, 2019, demonstrators gathered in Sennar (Sennar state) to commemorate the 55th anniversary of the 1964 October Revolution, and called for all vestiges of the Bashir and NCP regime to be removed, and officials brought to justice for any crimes they have committed. [size=large]

On October 21st, 2019, demonstrators gathered in Atbara (River Nile state) to commemorate the 55th anniversary of the 1964 October Revolution, and called for all vestiges of the Bashir and NCP regime to be removed, and officials brought to justice for any crimes they have committed. [size=thousands]

On October 21st, 2019, demonstrators gathered in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state) to commemorate the 55th anniversary of the 1964 October Revolution, and called for all vestiges of the Bashir and NCP regime to be removed, and officials brought to justice for any crimes they have committed. [size=thousands]

On October 21st, 2019, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum to commemorate the 55th anniversary of the 1964 October Revolution, and called for all vestiges of the Bashir and NCP regime to be removed, and officials brought to justice for any crimes they have committed. [size=hundreds of thousands]

On October 21st, 2019, demonstrators gathered in Wad Medani (El Gazira state) to commemorate the 55th anniversary of the 1964 October Revolution, and called for all vestiges of the Bashir and NCP regime to be removed, and officials brought to justice for any crimes they have committed. [size=thousands]

On October 21st, unknown gunmen attacked a farmer (who was also an IDP) at his farm in Um Obeish (South Darfur state, approximate coordinates 10km west of Gereida used at prec2). The attackers shot the man, broke both of his legs, and robbed him of his horse as well as his money.

On October 21st, 2019, demonstrators gathered in Nyala (South Darfur state) to commemorate the 55th anniversary of the 1964 October Revolution, and called for all vestiges of the Bashir and NCP regime to be removed, and officials brought to justice for any crimes they have committed. [size=small]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On or around October 21st, a doctor and pharmacist were beaten by RSF paramilitaries in Nyala (South Darfur).

On October 21st, 2019, demonstrators gathered in Omdurman to commemorate the 55th anniversary of the 1964 October Revolution, and called for all vestiges of the Bashir and NCP regime to be removed, and officials brought to justice for any crimes they have committed. [size=tens of thousands]

On October 21st, 2019, demonstrators gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) to commemorate the 55th anniversary of the 1964 October Revolution, and called for all vestiges of the Bashir and NCP regime to be removed, and officials brought to justice for any crimes they have committed. [size=large]

On October 23rd, 2019, teachers demonstrated in El Fasher (North Darfur state), demanding an increase in their salaries; arrears to be paid; and for the dismantling of Bashir-era symbols and trade unions (which had been linked to the Bashir regime). [size=hundreds]

On October 23rd, 2019, residents of Omdurman protested at the Council of Ministers building, demanding improvements in the collection of waste, and for a new waste centre to be constructed. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On or before October 24th, 2019, FFC demonstrators blocked the main road in An Nahud (West Kordofan state) using metal and concrete objects, in protest against irregularities in the supply and sale of subsidised flour. [size=no report]

On October 25th, 2019, striking oil workers protested outside an unspecified oil facility (likely Heglig, and coded as such at geoprec3). The workers are opposing poor labour rights which result from the monopoly of the oil sector by the state oil firm. [size=small]

On October 26th, 10 gunmen attacked the village of Roro near Joghana (South Darfur state coordinates used), wounding two men and two women, two seriously. The village accomodates IDPs who are returning to their areas.

On or around October 27th, residents of Haya blocked the road at Haya (Red Sea state), amidst unrest over the lack of basic services in the area. (The source does not mention the means through which the road was blocked; actor 1 coded as protesters). [Size=no report]

On October 27th, supporters of former Janjaweed leader Musa Hilal demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for his release and other imprisoned members of the Revolutionairy Awakening Council (SARC). [size=small]
On October 27th, armed pastoralists shot a farmer in the legs in the village of Girni close to Nertiti (Central Darfur state, coordinates for Nertiti used at prec2).

column9: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On October 27th, FFC members were reportedly attacked by an unknown group (suspected of being remnants of the Bsahir-regime, and accordingly coded as Popular Security Forces) in Omdurman, who used live rounds and threw stones. A memer of the FFC was abducted by the group.
On October 27th, an SAF soldier raped a 25 year-old IDP at gunpoint as she was farming near Thur camp (Central Darfur state). The army has arrested the suspected rapist.

column7: Pastoralists (Sudan); Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column16: Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation; Radio Dabanga
column17: On October 28, 2019, a pastoralist militia operating alongside an unspecified militia group (coded as RSF) attacked five female IDP farmers at Shangil Tobay (North Darfur state), beating them and looting property.
On October 28th, striking doctors demonstrated in Atbara (River Nile state), calling for a change in the board of administrators, and against the absence of medical supplies. [size=no report]

On October 28th, gunmen shot two IDPs near Kafan Kei village (coordinates for Manawashi, South Darfur state, used at prec2), killing one, after they refused to hand over their animals. Police have arrested one of the suspected gunmen.

On 28 October 2019, armed pastoralists attacked female farmers in the area of Shangil Tobay (Dar el Salam locality, North Darfur state), gang-raping and beating an unspecified number of women, and cutting several with knifes.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column16: Al Rakoba; Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation
column17: On October 29, 2019, RSF paramilitaries attacked a farm near Shadad IDP camp (North Darfur state), killing an Imam and wounding his brother (and possibly several displaced civilians).

On October 29th, residents of Khartoum North began a sit-in demonstration at Ali Abdelfattah Hospital, calling for a replacement of the administration and the improvement in the numbers of staff and quality of patient care in the hospital. [size=small]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On October 29th, residents of Haya (Red Sea state) and members of the FFC resistance committees demonstrated against the lack of health services, food, fuel and electricity in the area. Note that the source indicates protests have taken place in other nearby areas, but does not specifiy where (one event coded). [size=small]
On October 29th, secondary school students protested in Um Rawaba (North Kordofan state), against high registration fees to sit secondary school exams. [size=hundreds]

On October 30th, SAF soldiers attacked miners in the Aghbash, Jumbana, and Kesrein mines in El Radoom locality (South Darfur state, coordinates for Songo used at prec2), after a soldier was reportedly robbed. In the clashes that followed, one miner was killed and several wounded, after being hit with rifle butts.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces

On October 30th, gunmen attacked a transport vehicle between Abyei town (coordinates used) and Amieth Market, robbing the passengers. The gunmen opened fire on the bus after the robbery, killing the driver and wounding five others (including a 3 year-old child).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces

column17: On October 31, 2019, suspected RSF paramilitaries (or RSF affiliates) killed an IDP farmer and his daughter at Um Ajajah Kasi Jabal (North Darfur state. No geographic information found, coordinates for Tawila used at prec2).

On November 1st or 2nd, demonstrators carried the bodies of a slain father and daughter (killed on Nov 1st) from Sarafaya to El Fasher (North Darfur state), demanding the the governor of North Darfur provides security in the area. [szie=no report]
On November 1st, gunmen (implied to be armed pastoralists, and coded as such) shot a farmer and his daughter at their farm in the Sarafaya area (North Darfur state), killing both.

On November 1-2, 2019, pastoralists and farmers clashed in the area of Habila (South Kordofan state), resulting in eight fatalities (including a student) and 30 injuries, some serious. The cause of the fighting is unclear. Two events coded with fatalities distributed across both.

On November 1-2, 2019, pastoralists and farmers clashed in the area of Habila (South Kordofan state), resulting in eight fatalities (including a student) and 30 injuries, some seriously. The cause of the fighting is unclear. Two events coded with fatalities distributed across both.
On November 3, 2019, residents of Babanussa (West Korodfan state) protested against poor services and infrastructure, and to encourage agricultural development. [size=no report]
On November 4, 2019, pastoralists attacked a farmer near Tinkara village (North Darfur state, coordinates for Tangararra used at prec2), wounding her in the head. There is no further information.
On November 4, 2019, pastoralists hit a farmer in the head with an axe near Dobo Umda (North Darfur state), after she attempted to clear them from her farm land.
On November 4, 2019, armed pastoralists shot and wounded a farmer near Dobo Umda (North Darfur state), after he attempted to clear them from his land.

column16: Radio Miraya; Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan)

The source says ""Both groups sustained several casualties"", though zero fatalities have been coded, due to a lack of any deaths being mentioned.

On November 9, 2019, pastoralists attacked a female farmer as she attempted to clear their livestock from her farm near Dobo Umda (North Darfur state). The means by which she was attacked are not specified. The source implies she was wounded, rather than killed.

On November 9, 2019, pastoralists attacked two female farmers as they attempted to clear their livestock from their farms near Tabit (North Darfur state), and then stole their produce. The means by which they were attacked are not specified. The source implies the victims was wounded, rather than killed.
On or around November 10, 2019, gunmen fired upon two commercial vehicles near Suli Miri (Central Darfur state, coordinates for Miri used at prec2), injuring one passenger.

[size=no report]

column9: Police Forces of Sudan (2019-) General Intelligence Service
column17: On November 11, 2019, residents of Abu Naama (Sennar state) destroyed equipment belonging to the Kanaf Abu Naama project, including tractors, offices, depots and factories. The residents are demonstrating against the use of potentially dangerous chemicals by the company, which they say is carcinogenic. Police forces intervened with sticks and tear gas, causing 15 injuries, and GIS (formerly NISS) arrested two. [size=no report]

On or around November 11, 2019, demonstrators blocked the road between Khartoum and Wad Madnai at Abu Ushar (El Gazira state), using burning tires. The demonstrators are demonstrating against the deterioration of basic services in the town, and for not receiving their quota of flour for two days. [size=no report]

On November 11, 2019, students from the University of Nyala protested at the government administrative HQ in Nyala (South Darfur), against the lack of transportation options, which are causing students to miss lectures. [size=no report]

On November 12, 2019, three children were killed after they threw stones at unexploded ordinance near Tangasi (Northern state). Another child and a woman were injured. The bomb was likely from the military training camp at nearby El Dirwa.

On or before November 12, 2019, medical staff from throughout Khartoum gathered at Khartoum Teaching Hospital, calling for the hosptial to be administered by the federal Ministry of Health; for the accident and emergency department to be re-opened; and for workers who had been dismissed in the revolution to be reinstated. [size=hundreds]
On November 13, 2019, pastoralists beat ""many"" farmers with sticks and whips (injuring three seriously), in the area of Katur (North Darfur state). There is no further information.

column17: On 3 December 2019, relatives of those who were killed in the course of the uprising in Sudan marched to various political and judicial institutions - including the President's Palace - in Khartoum, calling for justice. [size=thousands]
On 3 December 2019, IDPs demonstrated in Zam Zam camp (North Darfur state), against attacks by armed pastoralists, and at the shrotages of essential goods and services in the camp. [size=no report]

On 4 December 2019, PDF militiamen shot dead a farmer at Shag El Kitir village (South Kordofan state, approximate coordinates 9km north-west of Um Barambita used at geoprec2), after he refused to hand over his produce to them. No action has been taken by authorities.

On 4 December 2019, two groups of unidentified gunmen clashed in the market at Kass (South Darfur state). Four civilians - including a teenager - were killed in the crossfire. The gunmen left the market once security forces arrived.

On 5 December 2019, unspecified militiamen (coded as Darfur Pastoralist militia, given the contextual information in the source) attacked Lia village (South Darfur state), burning crops, and firing in the air to scare residents.
On 5 December 2019, unidentified gunmen killed a civilian in Umm Dukhun (Central Darfur state), before looting his body. There is no further information.

On 6 December 2019, armed pastoralists clashed with police at Galala village in western Kreinik locality (no geographic information found, coordinates for Derjeil, West Darfur state, used at geoprec2), resulting in two civilians being wounded in the crossfire.
On 6 December 2019, armed pastoralists attacked Al Kereinik (West Darfur state), killing a farmer in the process, and wounding several others.
On 6 December 2019, residents of Umm Dukhun (Central Darfur state) protested against rising insecurity and human rights abuses in the area, following a spate of incidents. [size=no report]

On or around 6 December 2019, academics from the University of Ribat in Khartoum protested against the dismissal of employees during the national uprising; the continued presence of Bashir-era officials in higher education institutions; and for the dismantlement of the old state. [size=small]
On 7 December 2019, SAF attacked civilians at Abu Gamal (Kassala state), wounding 15. The reasons for the attack are unclear.
On 7 December 2019, armed pastoralists attacked farmers at Shoba (North Darufr state), wounding 20 (the source notes 12 female farmers were seriously wounded).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 7 December 2019, RSF paramilitaries abducted and tortured an agricultural committee specialist at their HQ south of Kebkabiya (North Darfur state). There is no clear motive for the attack.
On 8 December 2019, protesters gathered in Kebkabiya (North Darfur state), to protest against insecurity caused by RSF paramilitaries and armed pastoralists. [size=large]

On 8 December 2019, Arab nomadic militiamen (presumed to be Misseriya militiamen, and coded as such) attacked the Lou area of Abyei, killing three Ngok Dinka civilians. A further three civilians are missing (fatality precision 2 used).

On 9 December 2019, demonstrators burned tires on the main road between Wad Medani and Khartoum near Wadelmajzoub and Al Sawar in El Gazira state (no geographic information found; coordinates for Wad Medani, El Gazira state, used at geoprec3), in opposition to attempts by local government to put a rubbish dump in a residential area. Police beat demonstrators, wounding an unspecified number. One event coded. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change; Labour Group (Sudan)
column17: On or around 9 December 2019, protesters (including FFC members) demonstrated against arbitrary dismissals of employees of the Kenana Sugar Factory at Kenana (Sennar state), and for a restructuring of the management of the factory. Police dispersed protesters with batons and tear gas. 10 activists were arrested. [size=no report]

On 9 December 2019, demonstrators burned tires on roads in Kassala (Kassala state), in demonstration against an attack on civilians by soldiers two days prior. Police attempted to disperse the demonstrators, wounding five. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 9 December 2019, gunmen in military uniform (presumed to be RSF paramilitaries, given their presence in the area) attacked farms in the area of Khor Ramla (Central Darfur), injuring six farmers, and gang-raping a 16 year-old girl.
On 9 December 2019, secondary school students marched in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), in opposition to high prices for food and transportation. [size=no report]

On 9 and 10 December 2019, student supporters of the outlawed National Congress Party attacked left-wing students at the Islamic University at Omdurman, with several students wounded in the clashes. The source indicates that police dispersed the groups, although this is unclear. [size=no report]
On 9 December 2019, Ethiopian shifta (bandits) abducted three Sudanese civilians at an unspecified location in Eastern El Galabat locality (coordinates for Galabat used at geoprec2).

On 10 December 2019, armed pastoralists clashed with a local farmer self-defence militia (seemingly accompanied by SAF) at Tabra, 15km north-west of Tawila (North Darfur state; no geographic information found, coordinates for Tawila used at geoprec2). One farmer militiaman and one soldier were killed, and two others wounded.
On 10 December 2019, Ethiopian Shifta killed a civilian (implied to be a pastoralist) at Barka Nurein (Gedaref state. No geographic information found, coordinates for Mobiat used at geoprec2).

On 9 and 10 December 2019, student supporters of the outlawed National Congress Party attacked left-wing students at the Islamic University at Omdurman, with several students wounded in the clashes. The source indicates that police dispersed the groups, although this is unclear. [size=no report]

On 11 December 2019, armed pastoralists shot at three female farmers after they attempted to clear the pastoralists from their land, in the area of Dobo Umda (North Darfur state). Two of the farmers were wounded, and the other is missing (fatality precision 2 used).

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On or before 11 December 2019, an unspecified rebel group (presumed to be SLM/A Al-Nur rebels, given their presence in the area) shot dead an armed pastoralist at an area implied to be close to Sortony (North Darfur state).

On 11 December 2019, armed pastoralists blocked a road near Sortony IDP camp (North Darfur state) in protest against an attack that killed a pastoralist. They threatened to attack the camp unless residents (whom they allege to be harbouring rebels) turn over the perpetrators of the rebel ttack which killed a pastoralist. [size=no report]
On 11 December 2019, protesters gathered in Tawila (North Darfur state), to demonstrate against attacks by armed pastoralists in the area. [size=no report]
On 12 December 2019, a police officer raped a 16 year-old girl in Geissan (Blue Nile state). Police have refused to acknowledge the event.

On 12 December 2019, Nuba youth attacked members of the Beni Amer clan in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), sparking clashes between the groups. 29 were reported to have been injured, two seriously. The initial attack occurred after the postponement of a court trial which was to prosecute those involved in previous rounds of violence between the two groups in the city.

On 12 December 2019, students marched in El Fasher (North Darfur state), calling for affordable bread, improvement to transportation in the city, and for improvements to the University of El Fasher. [size=no report]

On or around 12 December 2019, students of the University of the Holy Quran and Islamic Sciences in Khartoum began a sit-in protest, calling for an end for segregation between male and female students, and for a toning down of the Islamic content of the university. [size=no report]

On or before 12 December 2019, protesters marched to the governors office in El Fasher (North Darfur state), carrying the bodies of the two deceased men from the clash at Tabra on 10 Dec, in protest at insecurity in the region. [size=no report]
On 13 December 2019, residents of Al Kereinkik (West Darfur state) demonstrated against corruption, violence and a lack of bread and fuel. [size=hundreds]
On 13 December 2019, residents of Habila (West Darfur state) demonstrated against corruption, violence and a lack of bread and fuel. [size=hundreds]

On 13 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Khartoum, in opposition to the 'Green March' to be organised the following day by supporters of deposed President Omar al-Bashir and his banned NCP party. [size=large]

On 13 December 2019, protesters gathered in El Galabat (Gedaref state), to protest against attacks by Ethiopian shifta in the area. The source says that demonstrators blocked the road to the border, but does not specify the means through which this was done. [size=no report]
On 13 December 2019, residents of Kondobei (West Darfur state) demonstrated against corruption, violence and a lack of bread and fuel. [size=hundreds]

On 14 December 2019, deposed President Omar al-Bashir was sentenced to two years imprisonment in a correctional institute for elderly prisoners, on charges of corruption. Bashir also faces charges relating to the 1989 coup that brought him to power, as well as violence against protesters.

On 14 December 2019, supporters of President Omar al-Bashir and his banned NCP party marched in Khartoum, in opposition to the dismantlement of the Bashir regime, and to his jail sentence handed down that same day. [size=3,000]

During the month of December 2019, three Sudanese were reported to have been killed and four injured at the hands of Ethiopian Shifta (roving bandits) in El Fashaga locality (Gedaref state, coordinates for Ad Dahhab used at geoprec2). 200 head of cattle were also stolen. One event coded at time prec3.

During the months of November and December 2019, a report by Darfuri farmer claimed that 20 farmers had been killed and over 30 wounded in a series of attacks in and around Jebel Marra (coordinates for Um Sayala, Dali, Koto, and Kadareik in North and Central Darfur states used at geoprec2; other locations mentioned include Karfala, Um Laouta, and Tangarara). 18 fatalities total coded (two fatalities already in the ACLED dataset deducted), spread across four events at time prec3 ( 4 each).

column7: Police Forces of Sudan (2019-) General Intelligence Service
column9: Journalists (Sudan); Former Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 16 December 2019, Sudanese authorities continued their dismantlement of the Bashir al-Ingaz regime, seizing the assets of several NCP-affiliated unions, and with the GIS (formerly NISS) dissolving three media houses linked to the notorious former intelligence agency (the SMC, Sudan Vision, and the Khartoum Electronic Media Centre).
On 16 December 2019, protesters gathered in El Geneina (West Darfur state), calling for the military governor to be removed, following allegations of extensive corruption. [size=thousands]

On 17 December 2019, farmers from Kalamindo locality demonstrated in El Fasher (North Darfur state), against trespassing, theft and damage to crops caused by pastoralists. The demonstrators also marched with the body of a slain farmer (killed in Korma) in El Fasher (North Darfur state) calling for justice and improved security in the area. The source mentions that the farmers blocked a road, but does not specify the means by which this was done (actor1 coded as protesters). [size=no report]

On 17 December 2019, students from the University of Ed Daein (East Darfur state) demonstrated following the death of a student, who drowned by falling into a water tank at her dormitory. The students accused the administration of negligence. [size=large]

On or around 17 December 2019, unknown gunmen attacked a police colonel, his family, and his bodygaurds (actor2 coded as police) at an unspecified location on the road between Buram and Nyala (South Darfur state, coordinates for Buram used at geoprec2). The attackers beat his family, and stole from his entourage.

On or before 17 December 2019, armed pastoralists shot dead a farmer and wounded another in the al Ghanam area near Korma (North Darfur state, coordinates used at geoprec2), when he attempted to clear their animals from his land. Police and a local rescue team arrested one of the attackers.
On or around 18 December 2019, police fired upon a vehicle that did not stop at a checkpoint in Murnei (West Darfur state), killing a child in the process.

On 18 or 19 December 2019, demonstrators carried the body of a sheep farmer killed at Abu Sakin to the governor's house at El Fasher (North Darfur state), in protest at insecurity in the area. [size=no report]

On or around 18 December 2019, rioters set fire to police stations at two unspecified locations in West and Central Darfur state, following the death of a child in an incident involving the police in Murnei (West Darfur state). One event coded in Murnei at geoprec2, and another in Zalingei (North Darfur) coded at geoprec3. [size=no report]

On or around 18 December 2019, rioters set fire to police stations at two unspecified locations in West and Central Darfur state, following the death of a child in an incident involving the police in Murnei (West Darfur state). One event coded in Murnei at geoprec2, and another in Zalingei (North Darfur) coded at geoprec3. [size=no report]
On 18 December 2019, unknown assailants killed a sheep farmer as he was grazing his sheep near Abu Sakin (North Darfur state) using sticks. There is no clear motive for the attack.

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched at an unspecified location in Northern state (presumed to be Dongola, and coded as such), to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=no report]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Atbara (River Nile state) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=tens of thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Ed Daein (East Darfur state) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Ed Damer (River Nile state) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in El Fasher (North Darfur state) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in El Geneina (West Darfur state) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in El Obeid (North Kordofan state) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Gedaref (Gedaref state) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Kassala (Kassala state) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Greater Khartoum (three events coded in Khartoum, Omdurman and Khartoum North) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Greater Khartoum (three events coded in Khartoum, Omdurman and Khartoum North) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Nyala (South Darfur state) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Greater Khartoum (three events coded in Khartoum, Omdurman and Khartoum North) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Sennar (Sennar state) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Wad Medani (El Gazira state) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

On 19 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Gedaref (Gedaref state) to commemorate the uprising that began in December 2018, calling for the goals of the revolution to be fulfilled, and justice for those killed in the course of the uprising. [size=thousands]

column9: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 20 December 2019, members of the outlawed NCP began distributing political material (under the name 'United Sudanese Movement') in Ed Daein (East Darfur state). Members of FFC resistance committees launched a counter-protest, preventing the material from being distributed. [size=dozens]

On 20 December 2019, journalists from the dismantled Sudanese Journalists Union (which was linked to the feared NISS agency under the Bashir regime) held a sit-in protest in Khartoum, after the organisation was disbanded on 14 Dec. The protest was boycotted by most journalists based in the capital. [size=40]
On 23 December 2019, Darfuri students from Tawila locality demonstrated at the Ministry of Justice in Khartoum, following a spate of attacks by armed pastoralists in their home area. [size=no report]

On 25 December 2019, Ethiopian Shifta (roving bandits) fired upon Sudanese civilians at Wad Kouli beside the border with Ethiopia (Gedaref state, coordinates for Was Faiya used at geoprec2), killing one, and wounding four.

On 25 December 2019, protesters marched in Khartoum to commemorate the anniversary of mass marches in the city in December 2018, calling for the removal of the remnants of the Bashir regime and justice for those who suffered under it; the consolidation of civilian rule; an investigation into military and paramilitary sources of finance; and an end to economic hardship. [size=thousands]

On or before 26 December 2019, rioters burned a civil administration office and torched several cars at El Geneina (West Darfur state), after a female IDP was injured in a hit and run incident. The demonstrators also stole four firearms. ""Regular forces"" (coded as army) dispersed the crowds with gunfire. [size=no report]

On 26 December 2019, two female Masalit IDPs were killed by Arab-identified militiamen (presumed to be Maaliya) as they were gathering firewood at Sisi camp in Kreinik locality (West Darfur state). There is no clear motive for the attack. Residents of Sisi IDP camp later apprehended the attackers.

On or after 26 December 2019, Masalit IDPs protested against the recent killing of two women near Sisi, blocking the road from Sisi to El Geniena at an unspecified location along the road (presumed to be at or near Sisi, West Darfur state). It is unclear how long the protest lasted for. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column9: Former Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 27 December 2019, an RSF deserter (who had been intimidating residents whilst wearing his RSF uniform) was shot and killed by RSF paramilitaries when they arrested him at an unspecified location in Gereida locality (South Darfur state, coordinates for Gereida used at geoprec2).

column8: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
column17: On or around 27 December 2019, three days of systematic looting began at the UNAMID Sector South HQ, outside Endur (South Darfur state), which was recently transferred to the government of Sudan. Reports suggest that both police as well as IDPs were involved in the looting, which ended after RSF paramilitaries arrived.
On 28 December 2019, unknown persons torched three churches in Bout (Blue Nile state). They then burned them down a second time after they had been rebuilt, on 16 January 2020 (one event coded).

On 29 December 2019, Maaliya pastoralists attacked the relatives of a Masalit IDP man who killed a Maaliya man earlier that day, killing two, wounding an unspecified number and torching Krinding market, according to the Sultan of the Masalit. The event occurred in Krinding IDP camp (West Darfur state).

column7: Farmers (Sudan); FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 29 December 2019, farmers and resistance committee members from agricultural areas in El Gazira staged a demonstration on a train that departed from Wad Medani (El Gazira state) bound for Khartoum. The demonstrators were commemorating the founding of the Farmers Union in 1953, and called for the revival of the El Gazira scheme. [size=no report]

On 29 December 2019, Darfuri protesters gathered in the three cities of Greater Khartoum, calling for justice for the victims of the Al-Ingaz regime living in Sudan's peripheries, and for deposed President Omar el Bashir to be tried at the ICC. (Three events coded in Khartoum, Omdurman, and Khartoum North). [size=hundreds]
On 29 December 2019, residents of Babanussa (West Kordofan state) began a sit-in protest, after plans for upgrading the areas roads were altered, bypassing the town. [size=dozens]

On 29 December 2019, Darfuri protesters gathered in the three cities of Greater Khartoum, calling for justice for the victims of the Al-Ingaz regime living in Sudan's peripheries, and for deposed President Omar el Bashir to be tried at the ICC. (Three events coded in Khartoum, Omdurman, and Khartoum North). [size=hundreds]

On 29 December 2019, seven Maaliya pastoralist were wounded by Masalit residents of the Kriding IDP camp (West Darfur state, actor coded as Masalit militia) when they went to retrieve the body of a Maaliya man who was killed in a fight earlier that day, according to the Arab Youth Committee.

On 29 December 2019, attackers (described as 'Janjaweed', but coded as Maaliya pastoralist militia) attacked El Geneiena hospital (West Darfur state), killing one, and assaulting several medical staff.

On 29 December 2019, Darfuri protesters gathered in the three cities of Greater Khartoum, calling for justice for the victims of the Al-Ingaz regime living in Sudan's peripheries, and for deposed President Omar el Bashir to be tried at the ICC. (Three events coded in Khartoum, Omdurman, and Khartoum North). [size=hundreds]

On 29 December 2019, workers of the El Salam cement factory protested in Rabak (White Nile state), calling for improved pay, worker safety, and an end to unjust management practices at the plant. [size=no report]

On 30 December 2019, unknown gunmen abducted an elderly IDP as he travelled from Nertiti to Jebel Marrah (coordinates for Nertiti, Central Darfur state, used at geoprec2). The fate of the man is unknown.

On 30 December 2019, protesters from the Maaliya ethnic group (some of whom were related to a victim (or victims) of violence the previous day) demonstrated in El Geneina (West Darfur state), calling for the perpetrators of the killing to be handed over to them within one day. [size=no report]

On 30 December 2019, Maaliya pastoralists attacked Murnei, Kereinkik and Sultan House IDP camps (West Darfur) amidst serious violence directed against Masalit IDPs. UNAMID estimates say at least 65 were killed and over 50 injured (other reports suggest significantly higher injuries). Three events coded with three fatalities each (other fatalities from UNAMID estimates spread across separate events), with coordinates for Durti (West Darfur) used for Sultan House camp.

column8: Former Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: On 30 December 2019, 29 members of the notorious former intelligence agency, NISS, were sentenced to death by a court in Omdurman, who found them guilty of torturing a teacher to death in Kassala in January. Four officers were sentenced to three years in prison, and seven were acquitted.

On 30 December 2019, protesters (including members of the teachers union) gathered at the court in Omdurman, in solidarity with a teacher who was killed in Kassala in January by NISS agents. Police dispersed the crowds with tear gas, which reportedly led to the death of an asthmatic civilian. [size=hundreds]

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces; Pastoralists (Sudan)
column16: Darfur 24; UNAMID; UNOCHA; Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 30 December 2019, serious fighting was reported in Krinding IDP camp and multiple areas in and around El Geneina city (West Darfur state) including Delmengi and Majmari villages. Attacks led by Maaliya pastoralists and RSF paramilitaries against Masalit Darfuris (including Masalit IDPs), though some fatalities on the side of the Maaliya are reported. UNAMID estimates say at least 65 were killed and over 50 injured (other reports suggest significantly higher injuries), of which 47 fatalities have been coded to events in Krinding camp and El Geneina (the epicentre of the violence, with the remainder of estimated fatalities spread across smaller events). Event at Krinding IDP camp coded as armed clash to allow for a small number of Maaliya fatalities which occurred.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces; Pastoralists (Sudan)
column16: UNAMID; UNOCHA; Darfur 24; Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 30 December 2019, serious fighting was reported in Krinding IDP camp and multiple areas in and around El Geneina city (West Darfur state) including Delmengi and Majmari villages. Attacks led by Maaliya pastoralists and RSF paramilitaries against Masalit Darfuris (including Masalit IDPs), though some fatalities on the side of the Maaliya are reported. UNAMID estimates say at least 65 were killed and over 50 injured (other reports suggest significantly higher injuries), of which 47 fatalities have been coded to events in Krinding camp and El Geneina (the epicentre of the violence, with the remainder of estimated fatalities spread across smaller events). Event at Krinding IDP camp coded as armed clash to allow for a small number of Maaliya fatalities which occurred.

On 30 and 31 December 2019, the Awlad Gaid and Mansour sections of the Misseriya clashed in the areas of Tebeldina and Abga Rajel (South Darfur state, coordinates for Tebeldina used at geoprec2). Six were killed and five injured; RSF paramilitaries broke up the clashes. Two events coded with fatalities spread across both.

column16: UNOCHA; UNAMID; Sudan Tribune; Darfur 24; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 30 December 2019, Maaliya pastoralists attacked Murnei, Kereinkik and Sultan House IDP camps (West Darfur) amidst serious violence directed against Masalit IDPs. UNAMID estimates say at least 65 were killed and over 50 injured (other reports suggest significantly higher injuries). Three events coded with three fatalities each (other fatalities from UNAMID estimates spread across separate events), with coordinates for Durti (West Darfur) used for Sultan House camp.

column16: Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga; UNOCHA; Darfur 24; UNAMID
column17: On 30 December 2019, Maaliya pastoralists attacked Murnei, Kereinkik and Sultan House IDP camps (West Darfur) amidst serious violence directed against Masalit IDPs. UNAMID estimates say at least 65 were killed and over 50 injured (other reports suggest significantly higher injuries). Three events coded with three fatalities each (other fatalities from UNAMID estimates spread across separate events), with coordinates for Durti (West Darfur) used for Sultan House camp.
On 31 December 2019, Maaliya pastoralists attacked a police outpost at Atia (West Darfur state), killing two police, before looting the area.

On 31 December 2019, Maaliya pastoralists attacked the police HQ and legislative council building in El Geneina (West Darfur state), killing four police and wounding one other. Property (including weapons and a police vehicle) were then stolen.

On 30 and 31 December 2019, the Awlad Gaid and Mansour sections of the Misseriya clashed in the areas of Tebeldina and Abga Rajel (South Darfur state, coordinates for Tebeldina used at geoprec2). Six were killed and five injured; RSF paramilitaries broke up the clashes. Two events coded with fatalities spread across both.

On 1 January 2020, demonstrators gathered in Wad Medani (El Gazira state) to protest against the violence in West Darfur over the previous three days, which had mainly been led by Arab-identified Maaliya against Darfrui Masalit. [size=no report]

On 1 January 2020, IDPs in Zamzam camp (North Darfur state) demonstrated against the violence in West Darfur over the previous three days, which had mainly been led by Arab-identified Maaliya against Darfrui Masalit. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 1 January 2020, IDPs blocked the road between El Geneina town and the airport at Ardamata IDP camp (West Darfur state) following three days of violence in the area, preventing the motorcade carrying senior officials (including PM Hamdock and Deputy Chair of the Sovereign Council 'Hemedti'). RSF dispersed the crowds. The means through which the road was blocked are not specified (actor1 coded as protesters). [size=hundreds]

On 1 January 2020, IDPs in Gereida camp (South Darfur state) demonstrated against the violence in West Darfur over the previous three days, which had mainly been led by Arab-identified Maaliya against Darfrui Masalit. [size=no report]
On 1 January 2020,unknown attackers armed with bladed weapons attacked doctors at a hospital in Omdurman, wounding one. There is no clear motive for the attack.

On 1 January 2020, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum to protest against the violence in West Darfur over the previous three days, which had mainly been led by Arab-identified Maaliya against Darfrui Masalit. [size=hundreds]

On 1 January 2020, unknown attackers armed with bladed weapons were reported to have attacked civilians in the area of Freedom Square during independence day celebrations (Note that this event is separate to an event in which women were attacked at the square on the same day). Police dispersed the attackers using tear gas.

On 1 January 2020, unknown attackers armed with bladed weapons attacked five women in Freedom Square in Khartoum, during independence day celebrations. Three women were injured. The motive for the attack is unclear.

On 1 January 2020, gunmen on camels and horses (coded as Darfur Pastoralist militia) attacked Terinja village (North Darfur state; coordinates for Sortony IDP camp used at geoprec2), displacing at least 70 families. There are no reports of casualties or fatalities, and the attackers looted the village.

On 2 January 2020, demonstrators (including IDPs from West Darfur) gathered in Khartoum and Khartoum North (two events coded) to protest against the violence in West Darfur from 27-30 Dec, which had mainly been led by Arab-identified Maaliya against Darfrui Masalit. [size=no report]

On 2 January 2020, demonstrators (including IDPs from West Darfur) gathered in Khartoum and Khartoum North (two events coded) to protest against the violence in West Darfur from 27-30 Dec, which had mainly been led by Arab-identified Maaliya against Darfrui Masalit. [size=no report]

From 2-4 January 2020, Beni Amir and Nuba groups clashed once again in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). 2 were killed on 2 Jan; 6 on 3 Jan; and 6 on 4 Jan. Between 115 and 127 were injured across three days of fighting. The current clashes are attributed to the killing of a man during a fight with another man, who was later arrested.

On 2 January 2020, female demonstrators marched in Khartoum in an event organised by around 60 women's civil society organisations and political movements, calling for the government to sign and implment the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. [size=hundreds]

From 2-4 January 2020, Beni Amir and Nuba groups clashed once again in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). 2 were killed on 2 Jan; 6 on 3 Jan; and 6 on 4 Jan. Between 115 and 127 were injured across three days of fighting. The current clashes are attributed to the killing of a man during a fight with another man, who was later arrested.
On or before 3 January 2020, female students demonstrated in Khartoum, following repeated thefts in the area. Demonstrators burned tires, blocking part of Al-Ghaba street. [size=no report]

On 4 January 2020, a vehicle carrying civilians was attacked by armed gunmen, killing four (including a child) and wounding three. The incident occurred on the road between Nyala and Burma, with the source implying the event to have taken place near Buram (South Darfur state, coordinates used at geoprec2).

From 2-4 January 2020, Beni Amir and Nuba groups clashed in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). 2 were killed on 2 Jan; 6 on 3 Jan; and 6 on 4 Jan, and between 115 and 127 were injured across three days of fighting. The current clashes are attributed to the killing of a man during a fight with another man, who was later arrested.

On 5 January 2020, protesters staged two demonstrations (one event coded) in Kadugli (South Kordofan state), calling for resistance committee members who had been arrested on public order charges to be released (and who were released following the protests). [size=no report]
On 7 January 2020, protesters marched in Khartoum, calling for justice for the victims of the June 3rd massacre. [size=hundreds]

column7: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction); Refugees/IDPs (Sudan)
column17: On 7 January 2020, protesters (including IDPs and supporters of SLM/A-Al Nur rebels) marched in Zalingei (Central Darfur state), calling for the government to extradite deposed ruler Omar el Bashir and his associates for trial at the ICC; for arms to be collected from militias in Darfur; and for an investigation into the perpetrators of the recent violence in West Darfur. [size=hundreds]

column7: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 7 January 2020, protesters (including supporters of SLM/A-Al Nur rebels) marched in Khartoum, calling for the government to extradite deposed ruler Omar el Bashir and his associates for trial at the ICC, and for an end to violence in Darfur. [size=large]

column7: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction); Refugees/IDPs (Sudan)
column17: On 7 January 2020, protesters (including IDPs and supporters of SLM/A-Al Nur rebels) marched in Nyala (South Darfur state), calling for the government to extradite deposed ruler Omar el Bashir and his associates for trial at the ICC, and for an end to violence in Darfur. [size=large]

column7: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction); Students (Sudan)
column17: On 7 January 2020, protesters (including students and supporters of SLM/A-Al Nur rebels) marched in El Fasher (North Darfur state), calling for the government to extradite deposed ruler Omar el Bashir and his associates for trial at the ICC, and for an end to violence in Darfur. [size=hundreds]

On 8 January 2020, clashes resumed in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) between two unspecified groups (coded as Beni Amir and Nuba militias, given that violence in Port Sudan has involved these groups over the past months) armed with bladed weapons, causing five injuries.

On 9 January 2020, striking port workers demonstrated in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for the release of the Shipping and Unloading Association director, who had been arrested in relation to a killing the previous day. [size=no report]

On 9 January 2020, gunmen on horses (coded as Darfur pastoralist militia) attacked Seraf Jidad (West Darfur state), killing two brothers, and seriously injuring their sister and mother. The attackers then looted livestock and money.

On 9 January 2020, police and a local search group (coded as unidentified communal militia) arrested five gunmen on horses (coded as Darfur pastoralist militia) who had earlier attacked Seraf Jidad village (West Darfur, coordinates used at geoprec2). Additional militiamen arrived and attacked the police and search group, and released the five captives. The source does not mention if there were any casualties.

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column9: NCP: National Congress Party; Police Forces of Sudan (2019-)
column17: On 11 January 2020, supporters of the outlawed National Congress Party marched in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), but were intercepted by a counter-demonstration involving FFC members. Conflicting reports suggest that NCP demonstrators (and potentially, armed NCP supporters) as well as police attacked counter-demonstrators, wounding between 7 and 11 (2 seriously) using firearms and tear gas. [size=at least 7]

On 12 January 2020, unknown gunmen killed an IDP farmer in the area of the farms at Judu 3, 3km south of Saraf Omra town (coordinates for Fassi, Central Darfur state, used at geoprec2). The attackers then mutilated the body of the victim.

On or around 12 January 2020, five ""militiamen"" (coded as Darfur communal militia) attacked an elderly displaced person at Fata Borno camp (North Darfur), wounding him. There is no further information.

On 12 January 2020, IDPs demonstrated in Kebkabiya (North Darfur state), in a protest which appears linked to the ongoing peace talks in Juba, and which prevented delegates to the talks from being selected. [size=no report]
On 13 January 2020, unknown attackers fired upon a family travelling between Kutrum and Nertiti (Central Darfur, coordinates for Turru used at geoprec2), wounding a teenager.

On 13 January 2020, militiamen on camels (coded as Darfur pastoralist militia) attacked two commercial vehicles on the road between Nertiti and Jildo near Gurnei village (coordinates for Guldo, North Darfur state, used at geoprec2). The attackers robbed the victims. There is no report of injuries or fatalities.

On 13 January 2020, medical students protested in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), following the decision by the state government to transfer the Dean of the medical college at the local University. [size=no report]

column6: Former Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column9: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column16: Radio Tamazuj; Al Rakoba; Radio Dabanga; AP; AFP; Sudan TV
column17: On 14 January 2020, former NISS soldiers from the Operations Authority division mutined, firing weapons in the air in several NISS bases in Khartoum and Khartoum North.
