column17: On 12 May 2020, an unspecified group attacked members of UNISFA Force Protection assigned to protect members of the Joint Border Verification and Monitoring Mechanism, as they travelled from Kadugli to Murta (South Kordofan state). The UNISFA vehicle was damaged, but no injuries occurred.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column16: Radio Dabanga; Hudo Centre; Crisis Watch
column17: On 13 May 2020, RSF paramilitaries attacked Nuba residents of Albardab village in Kadugli locality (West Kordofan state), killing 9, and beating an unspecified number. Around 200 dwellings were torched and/or looted, and at least 2,000 displaced. The attack comes amid ethnicized clashes between Nuba soldiers and Hawazma Baggara RSF.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 13 May 2020, RSF paramilitaries (likely of the Hawazma clan of the Baggara) claimed that soldiers from the 14th SAF division (likely of Nuba ethnicity) attacked them at a cattle camp close to Kadugli town (South Kordofan state), killing 9 and wounding 16 (including 10 civilians).
On 14 May 2020, unspecified 'militiamen' killed three civilians in the area of Katur in Tawila locality (North Darfur state), before stealing livestock.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 14 May 2020, suspected RSF paramilitaries entered Kadugli town (South Kordofan state), killing at least five (presumed to be Nuba civilians) and wounding an unspecified number. A number of houses were also torched. The attack comes amid ethnicized clashes between Nuba soldiers and Hawazma Baggara RSF.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Border Guards
column17: On 14 May 2020, Border Guard paramilitaries attacked IDPs working at a charcoal factory in the Boronro area south of Nertiti (Central Darfur state), wounding five using whips and rifle butts.

On 14 May 2020, internal clashes between unspecified security units (presumed to be army) broke out in Rokoro town (Central Darfur state), spilling into the hospital. An NGO staff member was seriously wounded in the crossfire. There is no further information, including whether there were fatalities.

On 15 May 2020, unspecified 'militiamen', who had killed three the previous day, launched an attack in the area of Katura in Tawila locality (North Darfur state). The attackers fired upon a well, before stealing livestock. It does not appear as though anyone was injured in the attack.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 15 May 2020, suspected RSF paramilitaries killed two civilians and wounded another in two districts of Kadugli (South Kordofan state). The attacks follow violent unrest in and around the town, related to ethnicized clashes between Nuba soldiers and Hawazma Baggara RSF.

On 16 May 2020, armed men (including some wearing military uniforms) attacked the villages of Tirti and Khairwajid in Beida locality (West Darfur state), in what appears to be a reprisal attack following the killing of a local relative of the men. 2 were killed (fatalities split across two events), between 17 and 28 abducted, and both villages were torched. One source indicates that the conflict is organised around ethnic lines, involving Arab and Masalit groups (with the Masalit presumed to be the victims of the attack). 1,401 people were displaced.

On 16 May 2020, armed men (including some wearing military uniforms) attacked the villages of Tirti and Khairwajid in Beida locality (West Darfur state), in what appears to be a reprisal attack following the killing of a local relative of the men. 2 were killed (fatalities split across two events), between 17 and 28 abducted, and both villages were torched. One source indicates that the conflict is organised around ethnic lines, involving Arab and Masalit groups (with the Masalit presumed to be the victims of the attack). 1,401 people were displaced.

On 19 May 2020, the SLM/A faction under Minni Minawi announced it would withdraw from the SRF rebel alliance, which is currently negotiating in peace talks with the government in Juba. The following day the SRF stated that they accepted his withdrawal, and resignation as Vice-President of the SRF.
On 19 May 2020, unknown armed men killed a merchant and wounded another civilian between Nertiti and Gerni (Central Darfur state). There is no further information.

On 20 May 2020, a mob - initially comprising over ten family members - attacked health workers at Omdurman hospital after their relative died of knife wounds. At least five doctors were wounded after stones were thrown at them, before a larger mob (who were not connected to the family) of at least 30 people formed and attacked security guards of the hospital. Doctors at the hospital subsequently went on strike in response to the attack. [size=more than 30]

Around 20 May 2020 (as reported), large numbers of demonstrators gathered in Khartoum (and in unspecified cities elsewhere in Sudan) to protest against the coronavirus lockdown measures, and what they described as 'neocolonial' interventions by the UN and World Bank. [size=large]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column9: Nuba Reika Ethnic Group (Sudan); Taxi Drivers (Sudan)
column17: On 21 May 2020, RSF paramilitaries executed a rickshaw driver (from the Nuba Reika ethnic group) outside of Kadugli (South Kordofan state), amid ethnicized violence between RSF Hawazma Baggara and Nuba SAF soldiers in the area.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 21 May 2020, RSF paramilitaries stopped a vehicle at Albardab, north of Kadugli (South Kordofan state), and executed a civilian for being a member of the Nuba ethnic group. The attack comes amid ethnicized clashes between Nuba soldiers and Hawazma Baggara RSF.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Around 21 May 2020 (as reported), two civilians were killed and then robbed by RSF paramilitaries at an unspecified area in the Sirba locality (West Darfur state). The source suggests the two either shot or run over by the RSF. Two RSF have been arrested.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column17: On 21 May 2020, SLM/A-Nur factions (one linked to a faction controlled by Saleh Borsa, and the other linked to a dissident commander, Mubarak Aldok) clashed in the Daya area of Rokoro locality (Central Darfur state), in fighting which is likely related to gold mining. Both sides are reported to have suffered """"heavy casualties"""", with 17 reported killed between this event and one on 11 June (fatalities evenly distributed across two events). 6,887 total being displaced between this clash and fighting on 11 June.
On 21 May 2020, militiamen riding camels and horses killed four civilians and wounded seven at an unspecified location in Gereida locality (South Darfur state). There is no further information.

column16: Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation
column17: On 21 May 2020, Fallata pastoralists attacked civilian vehicles in the Wadi Khaddari area of Gereida locality (South Darfur state; location presumed to be at the eastern edge of the locality), killing 3 and wounding 7, before looting the victims.

On 23 May 2020, protesters gathered in Omdurman to commemorate the upcoming anniversary of the June 3rd massacre. Police used tear gas against the demonstrators, in the vicinity of a hospital; a doctor was beaten and arrested for confronting police about the use of tear gas in the area. [size=no report]

On 23 May 2020, two armed groups clashed at the market in Dilling (South Kordofan state), in what is described as a personal dispute which escalated. Two were killed (one of whom was a civilian) and three wounded (at least of whom may be civilians). Five have been arrested, and the families ordered to leave the area.

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 23 May 2020, protesters (including Resistance Committee members) demonstrated in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), denouncing high bread prices and the June 3rd massacre of 2019. Police arrested 13. [size=at least 13]

On 23 May 2020, violence was reported in Jebel Moon locality (West Darfur state), in the area of either Gergi Gergi in the north-west of the locality, or Jiljil and Beir Batha near Ushara to the south-east. The source indicates these were linked to land disputes involving pastoralists and recently returned refugees and IDPs (presumed to be attacks against the IDPs). 1,231 were displaced between this event and another on June 4th; there is no information regarding fatalities or casualties.

On 24 May 2020, a militia tracked pastoralists suspecting of killing a relative of theirs to an unspecified location between Abu Jaradel (Central Darfur state) and the border with the Central African Republic. In the ensuing firefight, 10 pastoralists were killed as well as 3 of the party tracking the pastoralists.

column16: Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation
column17: On 25 May 2020, armed pastoralists clashed with police at Birkat Seira (North Darfur state) after local farmers confiscated the pastoralist's cattle and took them to the police station. The pastoralists then beat 11 farmers, and destroyed their onion farms.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column16: Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation
column17: On 25 May 2020, unspecified militiamen in army uniform (and presumed to be RSF paramilitaries) shot an internally displaced person in the Bale area 3km north-east of Nertiti (Central Darfur state), after they accused him of stealing sheep. The victim died of his wounds shortly after.

column16: Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation
column17: On 26 May 2020, militiamen attacked Bumbla village in Saraf Omra locality (North Darfur state), wounding at least four men with gunfire and beatings, and an unspecified number of women. An unspecified number were displaced. There is no clear motive for the attack.

On 27 May 2020, Ethiopian Shifta were reported to have raided the village of Mashra El Fursan in El Quresha locality (Gedaref state). The source does not mention whether there were fatalities or casualties.

On 27 May 2020, unknown attackers coming from the direction of Kadugli entered ""Rahad"" refugee camp at an unspecified location in the Greater Kordofan region (coordinates for the refugee camp at Tegmala, South Kordofan state, used), killing one South Sudanese refugee and seriously wounding four. There is no clear motive for the attack.

column16: Sudan News Agency; Al Rakoba; Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 28 May 2020, Ethiopian soldiers operating alongside Shifta were reported to have entered Sudanese territory at Barakat Nourein in El Quresha locality (Gedaref state), following an earlier clash between SAF and the Shift. One SAF captain and one child (one source says two) were killed; six SAF soldiers and at least three civilians wounded; and an unknown number were displaced. Sudanese reinforcements have deployed to the area.

On 28 May 2020, SAF clashed with Ethiopian Shifta in the area of Barakat Nourein in El Quresha locality (Gedaref state), after the SAF refused to allow the Ethiopians to make use of river water in the area, amid growing tensions in the area (claimed by Ethiopia). One Ethiopian militiaman was wounded.

Around 29 May 2020 (as reported), demonstrators gathered in Babanussa (West Kordofan state), to denounce the arrest and torture of several young men arrested earlier that day. Demonstrators torched the locality offices, vehicles, and the house of the locality director. [size=no report]

Around 29 May 2020 (as reported), SAF arrested several young men following a disagreement at a petrol station in Babanussa (West Kordofan state), amid continued petrol shortages. The men were reported to have been abused at the barracks.

Around 30 May 2020 (as reported), members of the Ja'alin group clashed with members the Bigirma group in the Seiro El Jaaliyin area of Abu Houja locality (Sennar state), in a dispute linked to plans to convert agricultural land for residential purposes. Two people were killed, and ten injured.

Around 31 May 2020 (as reported), relatives of an RSF soldier who was stabbed in an unclear incident with an Abu Tira paramilitary demonstrated against his killing at El Geneina (West Darfur state). [size=no report]

Around 31 May 2020, protesters gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) to denounce growing food prices and water shortages in the city. A soldier was reported to have shot multiple rounds in the air to frighten the protesters. [size=no report]

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 1 June 2020, SLM/A-Nur rebels clashed with SAF soldiers at a checkpoint in Kutrum in Nertiti locality (Central Darfur state), killing 27 soldiers, and suffering 9 fatalities of their own. Subsequent reports suggest the rebels took the area from government forces. 36 fatalities distributed across two events (with the second event on 5 June 2020).

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column17: Around 1 June 2020 (beginning of month), two factions of the SLM/A-Nur rebel group (the Boursa and Al Douk groups) clashed in the area of Toga in Rokoro locality (Central Darfur state), in a fight reportedly linked to control of gold mines in the areas around Dorsa and Daya. Over 27,000 civilians were displaced; there is no mention of casualties or fatalities.

On 2 June 2020, unknown gunmen on camels and horses attacked and killed two pastoralists in the area of Martial in Tawila locality (North Darfur state), after the pastoralists prevented the gunmen from stealing camels in the area.

Around 2 June 2020, government forces have accused an unspecified faction of the SLM/A rebellion (allegedly operating in conjunction with Musa Hilal's RAC force) of attacking government forces (presumed to be military) and taking territory in the Kutrum area of Nertiti locality (Central Darfur state). The accusation has been denied by SLM/A-Al Nur rebels based in the area. There is no information on fatalities.
On 2 June 2020, PDF paramilitaries shot two farmers in Kujuria (South Kordofan state), after insinuating the farmers had stolen their cattle. One of the victims died, the other was seriously wounded.

On 2 June 2020, an unknown militia attacked the villages of Berbar and Danan (approx. 30km north of Nertiti, Central Darfur state), killing 3 women, and wounding 6 civilians (3 of whom were women). Shelling was also been reported in the area, although the connection between the militia attacks and shelling is unclear.

Around 2 June 2020, the villages of Berbar and Danan (approx. 30km north of Nertiti, Central Darfur state) were shelled by an unknown group, killing two and wounding six. Government forces have accused an unspecified faction of the SLM/A rebellion (allegedly operating in conjunction with Musa Hilal's RAC force) of activity in the area, which has been denied by SLM/A-Al Nur rebels based in the area.
Around 2 June 2020, residents of El Azhari in Khartoum burned tires to denounce the continued water outages in the neighbourhood for the past two weeks. [size=no report]
Around 2 June 2020, protests against water shortages and soaring food prices continued in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). [size=no report]
On 3 June 2020, a 15 year-old girl (presumed to be an IDP) was gang raped by pastoralists near Otash IDP camp in Shattai locality (South Darfur state). There is no further information.
On 3 June 2020, hundreds of demonstrators marched in Khartoum North, to commemorate the anniversary of the June 3rd massacre of 2019. [size=hundreds]
On 3 June 2020, thousands of demonstrators marched in Khartoum, to commemorate the anniversary of the June 3rd massacre of 2019. Some demonstrators burned tires in the street. [size=thousands]
On 3 June 2020, unknown attackers wounded 4 and displaced ""several"" at the village of El Jorof, west of Jebel Amer mine in El Sireaf locality (North Darfur state). There is no further information.

On 4 June 2020, violence was again reported in Jebel Moon locality (West Darfur state), in the area of either Gergi Gergi in the north-west of the locality, or Jiljil and Beir Batha near Ushara to the south-east. The source indicates these were linked to land disputes involving pastoralists and recently returned refugees and IDPs (presumed to be attacks against the IDPs). 1,231 were displaced between this event and another on May 23rd; there is no information regarding fatalities or casualties.

On 4 June 2020, an unknown militia group riding in a Land Cruiser attacked Karu village in west Tawila locality (North Darfur state; location presumed to be an alternative spelling of Korru), clashing with inhabitants of the area. The attackers killed three, and one of their own was wounded. There is no further information.

On 4 June 2020, three unknown attackers shot an off-duty policeman in the Karakli area of Saraf Omra locality (North Darfur state), and stole his weapon. The victim died of his wounds shortly after. The three assailants have been arrested.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 5 June 2020, RSF paramilitaries killed three displaced farmers from the Tira group of the Nuba, at a farm 2km outside of Kadugli town (South Kordofan state). Two of the farmers were tortured before being executed. The attack comes amid recent ethnicized violence in the Kadugli area.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column16: UNSC; Radio Dabanga; Darfur 24; Sudan Tribune
column17: Around 5 June 2020 (as reported), government forces (comprising SAF and RSF) claimed to have re-taken territory they allegedly lost earlier that week to an unspecified faction of the SLM/A rebellion (allegedly operating in conjunction with Musa Hilal's RAC force) at Kutrum (Central Darfur state), and claimed to inflict ""heavy losses "" on the rebel groups. 36 fatalities distributed across two events (with the first event on 1 June 2020), according to a source which says 27 government soldiers were killed to 9 rebels.

On 6 June 2020, Misseriya militiamen attacked members of the Nuba group at El Fugara in Lagawa locality (West Kordofan state), accusing them of stealing cattle belonging to the Misseriya. The source says a ""number"" of people were killed and injured across this attack and others in the area. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.
Around 6 June 2020 (weekend of), Sudanese police were reported to have arrested 1,750 South Sudanese youth involved in a violent dispute and tortured them at a police station in Khartoum North.

On 6 June 2020, three unknown gunmen shot and killed a farmer in the area of Alsharak in Rashad locality (South Kordofan state; approximate coordinates 20km west of Abu Kershola town used). There is no further information.

Around 6 June 2020 (weekend of), South Sudanese refugees (reportedly armed with machetes) clashed with a militia of armed bricklayers in the Jaji Yusuf of area of Khartoum, in what is described as a labour dispute. 5 South Sudanese were killed and around 45 wounded. At least two of the bricklayers were wounded. The bricklayers are also reported to have torched refugee settlements in the area.

Around 7 June 2020, Misseriya militiamen attacked members of the Nuba group at El Dabkaya in Lagawa locality (West Kordofan state), accusing them of stealing cattle belonging to the Misseriya. The source says a ""number"" of people were killed and injured across this attack and others in the area. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

On 7 June 2020, members of the Nuba ethnic group clashed with a militia from the El Hallawiyin area of El Gazira state at Mahareiba in El Kamlin locality (El Gazira state), in a long-running dispute reignited by a recent fight at a market place. 10 Nuba were injured were injured by rifle fire, and commercial buildings were destroyed.

Around 7 June 2020, Misseriya militiamen attacked members of the Nuba group at Al Tareen in Lagawa locality (West Kordofan state), accusing them of stealing cattle belonging to the Misseriya. The source says a ""number"" of people were killed and injured across this attack and others in the area. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

On 8 June 2020, the Sudan Armed Forces announced that the notorious Popular Defence Forces militia linked to the Al-Ingaz regime was to be disbanded (with earlier reports indicating it was to be renamed the Reserve Department, and placed under SAF control).

On 9 June 2020, gunmen on camels attacked a well at Dobo Umda (North Darfur state), wounding a civilian. SAF soldiers intervened, and one of the soldiers was shot dead by the gunmen. The attackers then abducted three women, releasing two later.
On 10 June 2020, unknown gunmen shot and wounded a farmer near Nertiti (Central Darfur state). There is no further information.

On 10 June 2020, three Arab-identified pastoralists were attacked at Kalma IDP camp (South Darfur state) by a refugee militia, after getting lost in the camp. Two of the pastoralists were killed. Note that one source suggests the victims were members of (or were mistaken for being members of) the Rapid Support Forces.

On 10 June 2020, dozens of supporters of the outlawed NCP demonstrated in Khartoum against the newly agreed UN mission for Sudan. The supporters attacked the father of a man who had been killed in the uprising against ex-President Bashir. Police fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrators. [size=dozens]

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column17: On 11 June 2020, SLM/A-Nur factions (one linked to a faction controlled by Saleh Borsa, and the other linked to a dissident commander, Mubarak Aldok) clashed at Wegi village near Daya in Rokoro locality (Central Darfur state), in fighting which is likely related to gold mining. Both sides are reported to have suffered """"heavy casualties"""", with 17 reported killed between this event and one on 21 May (fatalities evenly distributed across two events). 6,887 total being displaced from Wegi and nearby villages of Ila, Fara, Daya and Katiro between this clash and fighting on 21 May.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 12 June 2020, SLM/A-al Nur fighters from an unspecified faction raped a woman and four of her daughters at Tairo (presumed to be close to Daya, Central Darfur state, given fighting in the area). The sexual assault may be linked to fighting the previous day between the factions.

On 13 June 2020, armed pastoralists severely beat farmers near Shoba in Kebkabiya locality (North Darfur state), and fired weapons into the air, after the farmers refused the demands of the pastoralists to leave their farms.
On 13 June 2020, armed pastoralists fired upon IDP farmers at Aradeeba in Kass locality (South Darfur state), killing one. The attackers then looted money and animals from the survivors.

Around 13 June 2020 (as reported), Ethiopian Shifta killed a Sudanese farmer at the Jiz al-Dud area of eastern El Gazira state, and stole 400 livestock. The attack comes amid tensions in the Sudan-Ethiopia border in the area.

Around 14 June 2020, demonstrators threw stones at a member of the local authority and at a police station in the area of Umm Kamalti in Bielel locality (South Darfur state), during a demonstration following an earlier violent land dispute involving members of the Zaghawa ethnic group. [size=no report]

On 14 June 2020, fighting broke out between rival communal groups in the Umm Kamalti area of Bielel locality (South Darfur), killing one and wounding ten. At least one of the groups consisted of members of the Zaghamaw ethnic group. The clash appears to be related to a land dispute.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 15 June 2020, RSF paramilitaries (initially described as Misseriya militiamen) attacked police guarding a communications tower at El Kuweik, 13km north of Kadugli town (South Kordofan state), after they were prevented from stealing fuel. One police officer was killed, and one seriously wounded.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Around 15 June 2020 (month of), a spate of attacks (including rape) attributed to RSF paramilitaries alongside unspecified pro-government militias were reported in the Nertiti area of Central Darfur state, killing ""many"" (with IDPs presumed to be a target for such attacks). Unknown fatalities coded as 10.

column9: Ngok Clan Group (Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (Sudan); Pastoralists (Sudan)
column17: On 15 June 2020, suspected Misseriya gunmen raided cattle from several locations around Abyei town, including Mading Thon, Minyang, and/or Miang Anil, likely from Ngok Dinka pastoralists. Between 500 and 1,437 head of cattle were stolen. UNISFA peacekeepers attempted to pursue the raiders, but were unable to engage.

On 16 June 2020, more than 25,000 demonstrators (including IDPs) demonstrated in Mukjar town (Central Darfur state) to commemorate the March 2nd massacre carried out by Janjaweed commander Ali Kushayb. [size=more than 25,000]

Around 16 June 2020 (as reported), a mass grave containing dozens of student conscripts was found at El Elafon on the outskirts of Khartoum. The students - who had deserted compulsory military training - were killed by unspecified security services linked to the Al-Ingaz regime (and presumed to have been army) at an unspecified time in 1998.

On 16 June 2020, IDPs demonstrated in Ardamata IDP camp (West Darfur state), in support of the extradition of ex-Janjaweed commander Ali Kushayb to the ICC, and calling for other members of the Al Ingaz regime to be extradited. [size=no report]

On 17 June 2020, hundreds of supporters of the United Popular Front for Liberation and Justice marched in Kassala (Kassala state), demanding the release of the recently arrested chairman of the rebel group, El Amin Daoud. The source indicates the demonstrators were involved in rioting; security services (presumed to be police) used tear gas to disperse the group. An academic was wounded either at this event or at a demonstration the following day in Gedaref. [size=hundreds]

Around 17 June 2020 (as reported), demonstrators (including IDPs) began a sit-in at Kebkabiya (North Darfur state), in protest at continued violence in the area and in camps for displaced persons. [size=no report]

On 17 June 2020, family members of a girl who was sexually assaulted the previous day demonstrated in Nyala (South Darfur state), denouncing the response of the security forces to the attack. Unspecified security services were deployed, although the source does not mention whether force was used against the demonstrators. [size=no report]
On 18 June 2020, pharmacists demonstrated in Khartoum against the unavailability of essential medicines. [size=no report]
On 18 June 2020, recently dismissed government employees demonstrated in Khartoum, contesting their removal following an investigation by an anti-corruption body. [size=no report]

On 18 June 2020, supporters of the United Popular Front for Liberation and Justice staged a large march in Gedaref (Gedaref state), demanding the release of the recently arrested chairman of the rebel group, El Amin Daoud. The source indicates the demonstrators were involved in rioting. An academic was wounded either at this event or at a demonstration the previous day in Kassala. [size=large]

On 21 June 2020, ENDF shelled an SAF camp in the Sundus area of El Fashaga locality close to the Ethiopian border, amid an escalating land dispute between the two countries. One Sudanese soldier was wounded, and parts of the camp were burnt.

column16: BBC News; Radio Dabanga; Al Rakoba; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 21 June 2020, Ethiopian militiamen ""backed"" by ENDF attacked SAF al-Anfal (described as being on the eastern bank of the Atbara river) of El Fashaga locality (Gedaref state). One Sudanese soldier was killed and two wounded; SAF claimed to have repulsed Ethiopian forces and inflicted ""heavy casualties"".

On 21 June 2020, police arrested and severely beat a journalist who was taking pictures of vehicles queuing at a petrol station whilst covering fuel shortages in Suakin (Red Sea state). The incident is one of several instances of harassment directed towards journalists in Red Sea state the same week.

On 22 June 2020, dozens of demonstrators blocked a bridge at Soba West (Khartoum), following heavy-handed police raids in the area to stop illicit alcohol brewing, which also involved cases of theft. Police used tear gas against the demonstrators. [size=dozens]

On 22 June 2020, dozens of youth gathered in Atbara (River Nile state) in opposition to shortages of basic goods, high prices, and cuts in the supply of water. Youths burned tires on main roads in the area. [size=dozens]

column7: Teachers (Sudan); FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column8: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Abu Tira
column16: Radio Dabanga; Al Rakoba; Ayin Network
column17: On 22 June 2020, an FFC-organised protest took place at Turr in Nertiti locality (Central Darfur state), in opposition to violence and militia attacks in the area. Central Reserve Police (a.k.a. Abu Tira) arrested and severely beat three teachers who were attending the demonstration. [size=at least three]

On 23 June 2020, female-led demonstrations, which included IDPs, took place in El Geneina (West Darfur state) to commemorate those killed in massacres led by recently arrested former Janjaweed leader Ali Kushayb. Some speakers called for greater representation for women in official positions during the transitional unity government. [size=no report]

On 23 June 2020, gunmen from Chad clashed with Sudanese pastoralists in the Wassata area (described as being in the ""far north"" of West Darfur state, around 50km east of the Chadian border, and presumed to be in eastern Kulbus locality), with 16 killed in the clash (7 from Chad, 9 from Darfur, at least one of whom died later of their wounds), and 10 wounded. The source indicates fighting was sparked by an effort by the Chadian gunmen to retrieve stolen cattle and/or to avenge the death of a leader of the Chadian group killed in April.

On 23 June 2020, dozens of youth gathered once again in Atbara (River Nile state) in opposition to shortages of basic goods, high prices, and cuts in the supply of water. Youth burned tires on main roads in the area, and police used tear gas against the demonstrators, after attempting to negotiate with the youth the previous day. [size=dozens]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Military Police
column17: On 23 June 2020, a SAF soldier who was being pursued by Military Police on suspicion of involvement in drug dealing threw a grenade at his pursuers in the market at Nertiti (Central Darfur state), wounding 8 (3 Military Police, and 5 IDPs who were in the market). The MP then shot and wounded the soldier.
Around 24 June 2020 (as reported), farmers demonstrated in Kassala (Kassala state) against shortages of fuel and other agricultural inputs. [size=no report]

column8: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
column17: On 24 June 2020, unknown attackers fired upon a UNISFA vehicle in between Goli and Todach in the disputed Abyei area (coordinates for intermediate location of Thothok used at GP2), wounding three soldiers (one seriously). The attack comes amid deteriorating security in the area.

On 24 June 2020, the military reponded to a protest in central Khartoum. The reason for the demonstration was not reported. During the demonstration, a military vehicle (presumed to be SAF) hit and wounded a child. It is unclear if the child was part of the protest. [size=no report]

Around 25 June 2020, various employees on the El Gazira state payroll (including teachers) protested in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), following the failure of state authorities to pay salaries for the month of May. [size=no report]

On 25 June 2020, Ethiopian militiamen (said to be ""backed"" by the Ethiopian army, in an unspecified capacity) clashed with SAF in the Taya area of Eastern El Galabat locality (Gedaref state), amid escalating hostilities linked to a dispute over land. Two Sudanese soldiers were wounded, whilst the source claims an unspecified number of Ethiopian gunmen were killed. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

Around 25 June 2020 (as reported), residents of Salah in Umm Badda locality (Khartoum) burned tires and blocked the main road, to denounce the lack of adequate water and electricity services. [size=no report]

Around 25 June 2020, demonstrators blocked roads and started fires in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), to denounce water shortages resulting from industrial action taken by state employees. [size=no report]

On 25 June 2020, two women belonging to the Fur community were beaten and raped by armed pastoralists near Belle el-Sereif in East Jebel Marrah locality (South Darfur state). There is no further information.

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (2019-) Prison Guards
column17: Around 26 June 2020 (as reported), prisoners rioted at the prison in Kassala (Kassala state), reportedly over the refusal of prison guards to respond to the case of a prisoner showing symptoms of coronavirus. Authorities (presumed to be prison guards) engaged with the rioting prisoners, as several were reported to have attempted to escape. [size=at least several]

On 26 June 2020, vendors reportedly attacked police at a market in Omdurman after authorities tried to move the vendors for violating coronavirus public health measures. Police dispersed the vendors with tear gas, causing a stampede which wounded one person. [size=no report]

On 26 June 2020, clashes between unspecified local groups erupted in the Hodeid area in the north of Talodi locality (South Kordofan state), in what is described as a land dispute, killing ""dozens"" and wounding an unspecified number. Dozens of fatalities coded as 12.

On 27 June 2020, armed farmers clashed with cattle rustlers north of Demyak in the area of El Bataha in Kadugli locality (South Kordofan state). At least 6 were killed in the clash, and one person wounded.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 27 June 2020, demonstrators protested in Abu Jubaiha (South Kordofan state) against environmental damage caused by gold processing at Merefaeen factory. Guards at the factory (presumed to be RSF) used tear gas and batons against demonstrators, wounding six (one seriously). [size=at least 6]

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (2019-) Prison Guards
column17: On 27 June 2020, prisoners rioted at Kassala prison (Kassala state), in what appears an attempted prison break. Police (presumed to be prison guards) used live rounds against the prisoners, wounding four and killing one prisoner (who's relatives say was not involved in the violence). [size=at least five]

On 28 June 2020, hundreds of protesters marched in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state) rejecting what they described as a 'partial peace' being negotiated in Juba, and calling for improved social security; justice for past abuses; and an autonomous status for the state, and inclusion by members of the state in the peace talks. [size=hundreds]

column8: Police Forces of Sudan (2019-) Prison Guards
column17: On 28 June 2020, prisoners rioted at Kassala prison (Kassala state), after four prisoners contracted coronavirus. Police (presumed to be prison guards) used live rounds against the demonstrators, seriously wounding two, whilst several other prisoners sustained injuries. [size=at least several]

On 28 June 2020, unknown gunmen on motorbikes shot dead a woman near Khor Ramla IDP camp in Nertiti locality (Central Darfur state), before turning their guns on SAF soldiers at the same location, killing 1 and wounding 2.

column16: Radio Dabanga; Darfur 24; VOA; Ayin Network
column17: On 28 June 2020, thousands of demonstrators (including IDPs) marched in Nertiti (Central Darfur state) in opposition to continued attacks by paramilitary forces in the area; calling for senior RSF and Military Intelligence commanders to be removed; and for pro-government militias to be disarmed. The protesters began a sit-in at the town, which has so far lasted for two weeks, and drawn supporters from other towns and villages in the area. Update: On 7 July, a delegation from the Sovereign Council visited, and pledged to replace senior security officials; embark on disarmament and confiscation of motorcycles; and make swift improvements to infrastructure and environmental standards. [size=thousands]

On 30 June 2020, police clashed with PDF militiamen (who had recently been disbanded) at El Fayd in Rashad locality (South Kordofan state), after the PDF killed a civilian farmer at his home in the town. The police fled after the PDF opened fire.

On 30 June 2020, IDPs demonstrated in Mukjar (Central Darfur state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, IDPs demonstrated in Murnei (North Darfur state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, IDPs demonstrated in Ronga Tas camp (Central Darfur state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, demonstrators marched in Kadugli (South Kordofan state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, IDPs demonstrated in Abu Shouk camp (North Darfur state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in Dongola (Northern state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=hundreds of thousands]

On 30 June 2020, demonstrators marched in El Fula (West Kordofan state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, demonstrators marched in Singa (Sennar state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in Atbara (River Nile state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. The demonstrators in Atbara also called for civilian governors to be appointed, and for the course of the revolution to be corrected. [size=hundreds of thousands]

On 30 June 2020, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in Gedaref (Gedaref state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=hundreds of thousands]

On 30 June 2020, tens of thousands of demonstrators marched in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=tens of thousands]

On 30 June 2020, demonstrators marched in Kebkabiya (North Darfur state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. After handing memoranda to a local official, elements of the police fired upon demonstrators, wounding six (including two children). [size=at least six]

On 30 June 2020, demonstrators marched in Wad Medani (El Gazira state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 30 June 2020, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators (including FFC resistance committees) marched in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces (including the Port Sudan massacre of January 2005). [size=hundreds of thousands]

On 30 June 2020, tens of thousands of demonstrators marched in El Roseires (Blue Nile state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=tens of thousands]

On 30 June 2020, IDPs demonstrated in Hamidiya camp (Central Darfur state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 30 June 2020, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in El Geneina (West Darfur state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. Resistance Committee members presented the governor with a memorandum, which called for the results of investigations into serious violence in the Kerending area in December to be released. Resistance Committee demonstrators occupied the former NCP building. ""Regular forces"" (presumed to be army) intervened, and wounded an unspecified number of protesters. [size=hundreds of thousands]

On 30 June 2020, IDPs demonstrated in Zamzam camp (North Darfur state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, demonstrators marched in An Nahud (West Kordofan state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in El Obeid (North Kordofan state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=hundreds of thousands]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 30 June 2020, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in Ed Daein (East Darfur state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. Resistance committees handed a memorandum to authorities at Ed Daein, calling for the dismissal of 13 officials and inclusion of FFC members in the Economic Committee. [size=hundreds of thousands]

On 30 June 2020, demonstrators marched in Kosti (White Nile state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, IDPs demonstrated in Kalma camp (South Darfur state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule, improved living conditions, and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. IDPs also called for the disarmament of armed groups, compensation to victims, greater access for humanitarian groups, and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 30 June 2020, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in Zalingei (Central Darfur state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. Resistance Committee members called for the root causes of Sudan's conflicts to be addressed, and for efforts to remove corrupt officials to be intensified. [size=hundreds of thousands]

On 30 June 2020, IDPs demonstrated in Ardamata camp (West Darfur state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, demonstrators marched from Haji Yusuf in East Nile locality (Khartoum state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. Police fired tear gas at the protesters. At least 55 were injured across Sudan. [size=no report]

column16: Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune; East African (Kenya); Al Rakoba
column17: On 30 June 2020, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in Greater Khartoum (three events recorded in Khartoum, Khartoum North and Omdurman) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. Police fired tear gas at demonstrators across the city, and were reported to have used live rounds (killing two demonstrators in Omdurman, one of whom died of their injuries on 4 July), and arrested large numbers of people. At least 55 were injured across Sudan. [size=hundreds of thousands]

On 30 June 2020, demonstrators marched in Shendi (River Nile state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in El Fasher (North Darfur state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=hundreds of thousands]

On 30 June 2020, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in Nyala (South Darfur state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=hundreds of thousands]

On 30 June 2020, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in Kassala (Kassala state) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. [size=hundreds of thousands]

column16: Al Rakoba; East African (Kenya); Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 30 June 2020, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in Greater Khartoum (three events recorded in Khartoum, Khartoum North and Omdurman) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. Police fired tear gas at demonstrators across the city, and were reported to have used live rounds, and arrested large numbers of people. At least 55 were injured across Sudan. [size=hundreds of thousands]

column16: Sudan Tribune; East African (Kenya); Al Rakoba; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 30 June 2020, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in Greater Khartoum (three events recorded in Khartoum, Khartoum North and Omdurman) as part of nationwide demonstrations calling for greater progress to be made in dismantling the NCP regime and to entrench civilian rule; improved living conditions; and for justice for the victims of violence by state forces. Police fired tear gas at demonstrators across the city, and were reported to have used live rounds, and arrested large numbers of people. At least 55 were injured across Sudan. [size=hundreds of thousands]

column9: Former Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Prisoners (Sudan)
column17: Around 1 July 2020 (week of), a mass grave was discovered in Khartoum, containing the bodies of 28 SAF officers who had launched a failed coup attempt on 23 April 1990. The soldiers had been executed after a trial in a military court shortly after. The discovery of the grave was announced to the public on 23 July 2020.
On 1 July 2020, three men in army uniform (and presumed to be SAF) raped a woman at Domia on the outskirts of Nyala (South Darfur state).

Around 1 July 2020 (beginning of month), Misseriya and Hamar militia were reported to have clashed in the area of Teboun and Al Kelebat in Babanusa locality (West Kordofan state), displacing almost 2,800 people. There is no information on injuries and/or fatalities.

Around 1 July 2020 (beginning of month), Misseriya and Hamar militia were reported to have clashed in the area of Umm Deibun in Al Idia locality (West Kordofan state), displacing 1,652 people. There is no information on injuries and/or fatalities.

On 3 July 2020, demonstrators gathered in Kassala (Kassala state) calling for investment and re-development; the dismissal of local officials; and an investigation into violence in the city. [size=no report]

On 4 July 2020, ethnic tensions between Masalit and an unspecified Arab-identified group were sparked in El Geneina (West Darfur state), after an individual was killed by an armed group in the city. The sources did not specify the ethnicity of victim or perpetrator. Relatives of the victim mobilised in response to the attack.

column7: Refugees/IDPs (Sudan); FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 4 July 2020, a large crowd of Resistance Committee members and residents of Soba El Ardai camp (and presumed to be refugees and/or IDPs) barricaded the main road with burning tires and smashed car windows in the Jebel Aulia suburb of Khartoum, to demonstrate against recurrent problems with the water and electricity supply in the area. The demonstrators then began a sit-in demonstration. [size=large]

On 4 July 2020, fighting erupted between Beni Amir and members of the Nuba group in New Halfa (Kassala state), following a dispute in the marketplace. One was killed on the day fighting began, and 46 were wounded (5 seriously) across three days of clashes. Two districts of the town were torched; security forces reportedly refused to intervene when fighting first broke out.

Around 4 July 2020 (between 1 July - 7 July), residents of Jabet (Red Sea state) barricaded the road running through the locality (with the road presumed to have been blocked with tires, as happened on a subsequent demonstration on 8 July), to demonstrate against the lack of electricity in the area. [size=no report]

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 5 July 2020, Masalit and an unspecified Arab-identified group (coded as Darfur communal militia) clashed with firearms, bladed weapons and grenades in El Geneina (West Darfur state) following a killing the previous day. Two were killed and three injured, with an RSF officer - presumed to be on the side of the Arab-identified group - among the wounded.

On 5 July 2020, fighting continued between Beni Amir and members of the Nuba group in New Halfa (Kassala state). 46 were wounded (5 seriously) across three days of clashes, and two districts of the town were torched.

Around 5 July 2020 (midweek), an IDP farmer who had been abducted at a farm (likely to the north-east of Nertiti, Central Darfur state) on 1 July was killed by the unidentified attackers. His body was discovered in the Gurni area on 10 July.

column9: Ngok Clan Group (Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (Sudan)
column17: On 5 July 2020, suspected Misseriya gunmen shot dead a Ngok Dinka man in the Kolbul area in the central region of the disputed Abyei area. There is no further information.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 5 July 2020, SLM/A-al Nur rebels clashed with government forces (presumed to be SAF) at Kamaraya in west Jabel Marrah (Central Darfur state), after government troops from Koron attacked rebel positions. SLM/A-al Nur said they inflicted a heavy loss of lives on government forces, and that three rebels died. Unknown overall fatalities coded as 10.

column16: Al Rakoba; Radio Dabanga; Ayin Network
column17: On 6 July 2020, demonstrators (including IDPs) began a sit-in protest at Fata Borno in Kutum locality (North Darfur state), denouncing insecurity and demanding disarmament; the expulsion of settlers occupying IDP land; and improvements in police and government services in the area. On 10 July, local officials announced a ban on motorcycles (often used in attacks) and committed to improving security for farmers. [size=no report]
On 6 July 2020, farmers began a sit-in protest at Kosti (White Nile state), calling for state assistance for agricultural inputs, and the dissolution of the Farmers Association. [size=no report]
On 6 July 2020, demonstrators from Nertiti town gathered in Khartoum, in solidarity with an on-going sit-in protest against insecurity in Central Darfur. [size=no report]

On 6 July 2020, fighting continued between Beni Amir and members of the Nuba group in New Halfa (Kassala state). 46 were wounded (5 seriously) across three days of clashes, and two districts of the town were torched.

On 6 July 2020, six armed pastoralists (described as being members of the Arab-identified ""Bazaa"" tribe) shot dead an ethnic Berti farmer at Abu Ahmed village close to Um Sauna in El Taweisha locality (North Darfur state), and wounded two other farmers, after they had attempted to clear the pastoralists from their land. Local vigilantes and police have arrested one of the attackers.

column7: Refugees/IDPs (Sudan); FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 7 July 2020, an SAF Brigadier General (accompanied by other soldiers) drove his vehicle into the barricade at Soba El Ardai camp in the Jebel Aulia suburb of Khartoum, in an attempt to break up the sit-in demonstration (which involved Resistance Committee members, and likely refugees and/or IDPs), wounding two. Some demonstrators then attempted to attack the Brig. Gen, but were prevented from doing so by soldiers and other demonstrators. [size=no report]

On 7 July 2020, hundreds of dock workers marched in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) alongside family members of five imprisoned executives from the Sea Port Corporation who are accused of corruption, after one of the detainees died in jail. The demonstrators are calling for their release, and have emphasised that coronavirus social distancing measures are not in place at the prison. [size=hundreds]

On 8 July 2020, dozens of teachers demonstrated in Nyala (South Darfur state), after they discovered that the pay rise offered to public workers had not been applied to their salaries. The teachers began a sit-in protest at the state Ministry of Finance. [size=dozens]

column16: Al Rakoba; Ayin Network; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 8 July 2020, demonstrators began a sit-in protest at Kebkabiya (North Darfur state) following the killing of a farmer at nearby Shoba, calling for justice for those wounded in a demonstration the previous week; for senior security officials and the military governor to be dismissed; the continued dismantling of the NCP 'deep state'; and improved security in the area. [size=no report]
On 8 July 2020, a woman (presumed farmer) was raped in farmland near Buri in Nertiti locality (Central Darfur state) by two unknown perpetrators. There is no further information.
On 8 July 2020, residents of Jabet (Red Sea state) barricaded the road running through the locality with tires, to demonstrate against the lack of electricity in the area. [size=no report]
Around 8 July 2020, a farmer was killed by an unspecified actor (presumed to be a Darfurian militia group) at Shoba in Kebkabiya locality (North Darfur state), sparking protests in Kebkabiya town.

Around 8 July 2020 (as reported), demonstrators gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), in solidarity with the sit-in at Nertiti and calling for a resolution to violence in New Halfa. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change; SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; Labour Group (Sudan)
column17: Around 8 July 2020 (week of), demonstrators, including Resistance Committee and SPA members, began a sit-in protest at Misterei (West Darfur state), raising a litany of grievances relating to insecurity, corruption and poor infrastructure. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 9 July 2020, demonstrators (including Resistance Committee members) marched in Kassala (Kassala state), denouncing the failure of authorities to implement demands from a demonstration the previous week, and calling for various officials to be dismissed from their posts. The demonstrators then began a sit-in protest. [size=no report]

On 9 July 2020, a vigilante militia from Ghirba searched the area for an armed group (likely pastoralists) who had attacked two pastoralists earlier that day near Ghirba in El Radoom locality (South Darfur state). Upon discovering the culprits at a camp for pastoralists, the search party was fired upon by the pastoralist militia, killing 4. Note that it is unclear whether pastoralists were among the search party.

On 9 July 2020, two pastoralists were shot by an armed group (likely a pastoralist militia) near Ghirba in El Radoom locality (South Darfur state), killing one and wounding the brother of the deceased. There is no clear motive for the attack.

On 9 July 2020, striking workers from the state water corporation in Khartoum demonstrated in the capital, calling for higher salaries and the dismissal of the director, due to alleged corruption and links to the al-Ingaz regime. [size=no report]

On 9 July 2020, a farmer was reported to have been attacked by an unspecified group (presumed to be militiamen from Darfur) at an unspecified location in the Nertiti area (Central Darfur state). The source does not mention whether the farmer survived the attack.
On 10 July 2020, unknown raiders (presumed to be inhabitants of the area) attacked pastoralists at Kamda in Lagawa locality (West Kordofan state), killing three and wounding two.

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 10 July 2020, two gunmen attacked Ashireyah (presumed to be an alternative spelling of Esheraya) in Bahr el Arab locality (East Darfur state), killing a police officer and civilian, and wounding 4 RSF paramilitaries, before the RSF killed the two gunmen (described as ""militants""). There is no clear motivation for the assault.

On 12 July 2020, members of a union for disabled persons began a sit-in demonstration in Atbara (River Nile state), after the local authorities ordered the union to vacate part of its property. [size=no report]

On 12 July 2020, hundreds of demonstrators at the sit-in camp at Kutum (North Darfur state) were subjected to tear gas and live rounds fired by police, after a section of the demonstrators attacked a visiting delegation and burned the police station they were sheltering in. Three demonstrators were shot and wounded. [size=hundreds]

On 12 July 2020, thousands of demonstrators marched in Kebkabiya (North Darfur state) in favour of the ongoing sit-in protest against insecurity in the area, before joining the sit-in protest. [size=thousands]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 12 July 2020, Resistance Committee members began a sit-in protest at the locality HQ of Bahr el Arab locality in East Darfur state (unknown location, Abu Matariq town used at GP2), calling for the dismissal of officials linked to the al-Ingaz regime; for improved security and development in the area; and for greater attention to be paid to the needs of women and children. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 12 July 2020, Resistance Committee members demonstrated in Ed Daein (East Darfur state), denouncing the failure of the governor to remove Bashir-era officials, and calling for a road to be built to An Nahud. [size=no report]
Around 12 July 2020 (as reported), vendors demonstrated in Haji Yusuf (Khartoum state) due to problems with street sweeping and cleaning in the area. [size=no report]

On 12 July 2020, demonstrators from Fata Borno IDP camp (North Darfur state) blocked roads in the areas around the sit-in camp, in protest at an unpopular speech by the governor of the state, and denouncing the various failings of the state government. [size=no report]
On 12 July 2020, street cleaners demonstrated in Khartoum North, denouncing their low wages and the failure of authorities to pay them for the month of June. [size=no report]
On 12 July 2020, demonstrators began a sit-in protest at Yassin (East Darfur state), amid a number of similar protests being staged against insecurity in the area. [size=no report]

On 13 July 2020, an unknown armed group (described in some sources as ""militiamen"", and in one source as being a militia linked to the deposed al-Bashir regime) on motorbikes, horses and camels attacked the sit-in protest at Fata Borno in Kutum locality (North Darfur state), killing 10 and wounding 17, and burning the market and stealing cattle. Police forces attempted to repulse the militia, but then retreated. [size=at least 27]

column9: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
column17: On 13 July 2020, an armed man fired upon a UNISFA vehicle in Kadugli (South Kordofan state), killing a Sudanese employee of the mission, amid tensions over the Abyei area. The attacker then fled the scene.
On 13 July 2020, demonstrators marched in Dilling (South Kordofan state), calling for an end to violence and racism. [size=no report]

Around 13 July 2020 (as reported), state energy workers demonstrated in Khartoum in opposition to long-standing problems with work conditions, including excessive reliance on contractual labour. [size=no report]
Around 13 July 2020 (as reported), residents of El Hawata (Gedaref state) began a sit-in protest, demanding that the road to the Gedaref be tarmacked. [size=no report]
On 13 July 2020, demonstrators marched in Zalingei (Central Darfur state), calling for an end to hate speech and racism. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 13 July 2020, protesters from Kutum locality as well as Resistance Committee members gathered in Khartoum, to denounce violent attacks on two sit-in camps in the area. The protesters delivered a petition to the Prime Minister's office. [size=no report]
On 13 July 2020, demonstrators marched in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for an end to hate speech and racism. [size=no report]

On 14 July 2020, residents of Ed Duweim (White Nile state) began a sit-in protest calling for the dismissal of senior civil servants and police; a restructuring of the judiciary and police; and the dissolution of dubious civil society organisations and non-existent agricultural companies. [size=no report]
On 14 July 2020, demonstrators marched in Nyala (South Darfur state), calling for an end to hate speech and racism. [size=no report]
On 14 July 2020, unspecified gunmen shot and killed 2 IDP farmers near Kereinik town (West Darfur state). There is no further information.

On 14 July 2020, hundreds of protesters gathered at the hospital in El Fasher (North Darfur state), calling for justice following the attack on Fata Borno IDP camp the previous day; for improved security in the area; and for new settlers on the land of IDPs to be removed. [size=hundreds]

On 14 July 2020, residents of Amri began a sit-in at the new settlement of Amri (in Northern state), calling for compensation for destruction caused by the Merowe dam; for an investigation into killings from 2006; and for an investigation into corruption at the dam. [size=no report]
On 14 July 2020, residents of Sinkat (Red Sea state) began a sit-in demonstration, calling for improved roads, services and the removal of local officials. [size=no report]
On 14 July 2020, residents of Port Sudan (Red Sea state) began a sit-in demonstration, calling for improved roads, services and the removal of local officials. [size=no report]

Around 15 July 2020 (as reported), state irrigation and excavation workers demonstrated in Wad Medani (El Gazira state) following the failure of authorities to pay their salaries in June. The demonstrators also called for the dismissal of the director of the authority. [size=no report]

On 15 July 2020, farmers who had been resettled due to dam construction confronted soldiers on their farmland (implied to be in the Shuwak area of El Fashaga locality, Gedaref state) after finding they were farming on the land. One farmer was shot and four others were wounded due to being beaten with rifle butts. The source does not mention whether the farmers were engaged in violent activity.

Around 15 July 2020 (between 14 July - 16 July), protesters gathered in Kereinik town (West Darfur state), to denounce the killing of two IDP farmers. The main road in the town was blocked, but the means through which it was blocked is not specified. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 15 July 2020, police attempted to force their way into the Resistance Committee-organized sit-in at Ed Daein (East Darfur state), but were prevented from gaining access by the demonstrators. [size=no report]

On 16 July 2020, two unspecified groups (implied to be local residents) armed with sticks clashed over a piece of farmland around 5km south of Abu Delek in Kalimendo locality (North Darfur state, coordinates for Korbat used at GP2), with one person killed and five wounded.

On 16 July 2020, two women (presumed farmers) were raped by unknown perpetrations in the Tiga farming area, presumed to be in southern El Malha locality (North Darfur state). There is no further information.

On 16 July 2020, demonstrators gathered in Gedaref (Gedaref state), calling for justice for victims of state repression, including for 12 people who were killed in Gedaref during the uprising. [size=no report]

On 16 July 2020, workers from the Khartoum Water Authority demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for the removal of the director of the authority and investigations into corruption, and against non-payment and restructuring of salaries. Police fired live rounds in the air to disperse the protesters. [size=no report]
On 16 July 2020, bus drivers blocked roads in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) in protest at delays in work permits. [size=no report]
On 16 July 2020, residents of Kass (South Darfur state) demonstrated against insecurity, corruption, and poor services. [size=no report]

On 16 July 2020, demonstrators gathered in Kassala (Kassala state), occupying the bridge linking the two halves of the town, in protest at the increase in the local transportation tariff. [size=no report]

On 16 July 2020, gunmen shot dead two men at the offices of a mining company in Kadugli (South Kordofan state), where one of the victims was employed. The source notes that RSF and SAF soldiers are based across the road from the scene of the attack, but did not attempt to pursue the attackers.

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column16: Radio Dabanga; Al Rakoba; Ayin Network
column17: On 17 July 2020, unknown militiamen attacked a Resistance Committee sit-in at Misterei (West Darfur state), wounding 17. The attackers also entered several locations in the town and torched a number of neighborhoods, and occupied the market for a time. Two of the wounded died later of their wounds. [size=at least 17]

On 17 July 2020, three pastoralists (presumed to be Rizeigat, given subsequent events) were killed by an unspecified group in the Kendka area (presumed to be in or near El Geneina, West Darfur state). The killings are reported to be linked to intense fighting that broke out in El Geniena from 19 July.

Around 17 July 2020 (as reported), members of the pastoralist community in Nyala (South Darfur state) staged a protest, calling for peaceful co-existence with residents of the area; for designated grazing routes to be reinstated; and to raise awareness of the exploitation of pastoralists by the regime of ex-President Omar al-Bashir, which has severely damaged relations between groups in the area. [size=no report]
On 17 July 2020, two female IDPs were raped by unspecified militiamen north-east of Kassab camp in Kutum locality (North Darfur state). There is no further information.

On 17 July 2020, dozens of Islamist protesters marched in Khartoum, denouncing the implementation of constitutional changes which relaxed several areas of Shari law that was introduced in 1983 and maintained by the regime under ex-President Omar el Bashir. [size=dozens]

Around 17 July 2020 (as reported), hospital staff and doctors from Al Moa'lem hospital in Khartoum protested against continued failures on the part of authorities to pay their salaries. [size=no report]

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column16: Ayin Network; Darfur 24; Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 19 July 2020, large clashes broke out in El Geneina town between the Rizeigat and Masalit groups, both of whom were reported to have mobilized official soldiers (in civilian clothes) to engage in the fighting (presumed to be RSF for the Rizeigat and SAF for the Masalit, pending further information). At least 3 were killed (some sources suggest 6) and 7 wounded, whilst 3 RSF paramilitaries were wounded during the events. Thousands have been displaced in the fighting, which appears to relate to escalating murders in the area.

Around 19 July 2020 (as reported), residents of Umm Shouka in southern Sennar state (presumed to be in El Souki locality) protested after authorities attempted to reclaim land which was fraudulently sold to them during the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change; Pastoralists (Sudan)
column17: Around 19 July 2020, protesters - including Resistance Committee members and pastoralists - demonstrated on the Gedaref-Kassala highway (implied to be near Rawashda, Gedaref state), following the decision by the military governor to open up the forest of Gedaref to commercial interests. [size=no reports]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On 20 July 2020, SAF Military Intelligence arrested a Darfurian human rights lawyer at Kutum (North Darfur state), and held him until 26 June, during which time he was tortured by the MI officers.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 20 July 2020, clashes in El Geniena (West Darfur state) resumed between members of the Rizeigat and Masalit, killing 4. Both groups were reported to have mobilized official soldiers (in civilian clothes) to engage in the fighting (presumed to be RSF for the Rizeigat and SAF for the Masalit, pending further information).

On 20 July 2020, five unknown attackers shot two farmers (a man and a woman) east of Saraf Ed Dei close to Kadugli (South Kordofan state), killing both (with the man dying shortly after the shooting).

column9: Baggara Ethnic Militia (Sudan); Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 21 July 2020, dozens have been reported dead and ""many"" wounded in fighting described as being tribal in nature in Kadugli (South Kordofan state) (actors presumed to be Nuba and Hawazmah Baggara, based on recent clashes in the city). RSF were reported to have been active in the city during the events (presumed to be on the Hawazmah side), and around 2,000 have been displaced. The fighting is said to be linked to recent killings in the area, amid recurrent violence in and around Kadugli.
On 21 July 2020, residents of Kadugli (South Kordofan state) demonstrated against recent killings in the area, and calling for authorities to provide security. [size=no report]

On 21 July 2020, supporters of former President Omar el Bashir beat a prosecution lawyer outside the court house in Khartoum, where Bashir and other senior members of the NIF/NCP regime were on trial. The victim took shelter in a police car. [size=no report]

Around 21 July 2020 (as reported), residents of Temple/Tempel in El Gazira state (no geographic information found) began a sit-in protest in the town, calling for the town to be granted its own locality, rather then being an administrative unit. Resistance Committees have supported the move, but it is unclear if they are participating in the demonstration. [size=no report]

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 21 July 2020, clashes in El Geniena (West Darfur state) resumed between members of the Rizeigat and Masalit for a third day. Both groups were reported to have mobilised official soldiers (in civilian clothes) to engage in the fighting (presumed to be RSF for the Rizeigat and SAF for the Masalit, pending further information). No report on fatalities.

On 22 July 2020, Prime Minister Hamdock announced that all military governors of the 18 states had been removed, and replaced with civilian governors, following significant grievances directed against the continued presence of military governors from the Bashir-era. The appointments have drawn widespread disapproval among parts of the FFC alliance, who have been disappointed with the allocation criteria and/or the unrepresentative nature of the governors (both ideologically, and with regards to the presence of only two female governors).
Around 22 July 2020 (as reported), the bodies of two Masalit men were found in the vicinity of Masmaja in Habila locality (West Darfur state). There is no information on the attackers.

column7: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 22 July 2020, clashes in El Geniena (West Darfur state) resumed between members of the Rizeigat and Masalit, killing 3. Both groups were reported to have mobilised official soldiers (in civilian clothes) to engage in the fighting (presumed to be RSF for the Rizeigat and SAF for the Masalit, pending further information).

On 23 July 2020, a large group of protesters (including from members of the Beja group) gathered in Kassala (Kassala state) in opposition to the newly appointed governor of the state. The demonstrators began a sit-in protest. [size=large]
On 23 July 2020, unknown gunmen shot and killed an IDP farmer east of Nertiti (Central Darfur state). There is no further information.

column16: Reuters; Radio Dabanga; Ayin Network; Darfur 24; UNOCHA
column17: On 23 July 2020, irregular militiamen attacked farmers (including displaced farmers who had returned to the area) at Abu Dos (presumed to be an alternative spelling of Abdoze) in Gereida locality (West Darfur state). At least 19 were killed and around 25 wounded, 8 seriously. Nearly 4,000 have been displaced. RSF paramilitaries stationed in the area to protect the returnees fled as soon as the attack began. The identity of the attackers is unclear.

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 23 July 2020, protesters (likely including FFC members) gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan state) in opposition to the newly appointed governor of the state. [size=no report]

On 23 July 2020, feminist groups demonstrated in Khartoum, denouncing underrepresentation for women in the new governors announced the previous day, as well as the lack of women for ambassadorial nominations. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 23 July 2020, protesters (likely including FFC members) gathered in Ed Daein (East Darfur state) in opposition to the newly appointed governor of the state. [size=no report]

Around 23 July 2020 (as reported), residents of El Hawata (Gedaref state) began a sit-in demonstration, calling for the construction of a new road and to address under-development in the area. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change; Farmers (Sudan)
column17: Around 23 July 2020 (as reported), residents (including farmers and Resistance Committee members) of the seven towns of Wad al-Mahi (Blue Nile state) gathered in Town 4, in a protest against anticipated negative effects of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam. [size=no report]
On 23 July 2020, two female farmers were shot dead by unknown attackers in the area of Misterei (West Darfur state). There is no further information.
