On 24 July 2020, residents of Gereida (South Darfur state) began a sit-in protest in the town, following the attack of Abu Dos the previous day. The demonstrators are calling for an end to insecurity and for senior security officials to be replaced. [size=no report]
On 24 July 2020, unknown gunmen shot and killed two IDP farmers working in the Hilat Temebto area, implied to be close to El Salaam camp south-east of Nyala (South Darfur state).

On 24 July 2020, protesters (including Islamists) marched in Khartoum, in a rally led by the former speaker of the parliament. The protesters were denouncing the recent changes to the law, which relaxed several strict laws dating back from 1983. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 24 July 2020, Resistance Committee members marched in the Jabra area of Khartoum, decrying the failure of the FFC to stand up to the military government. After becoming involved in an altercation with a conservative woman, police arrested three and beat them. [size=at least three]

On 24 July 2020, a mother and her two children were killed in the area of Misterei (West Darfur state) by unknown attackers. The victims were likely to be Rizeigat, given the nature of a subsequent reprisal attack.

On 25 July 2020, around 500 residents of Misterei (West Darfur state) protested against violence in and around the town, following the death of at least 60 people in an attack the same day. [size=around 500]

On 25 July 2020, the Sudanese Professionals Association announced it had entered into an alliance with the SPLM-North faction of Abdel-Aziz al-Hilo. The announcement came after the Sudanese Professionals Association - who had spearheaded and coordinated the uprising in Sudan - announced it was withdrawing from the Forces for Freedom and Change, citing self-interested behavior of unspecified members of the alliance; disorganization; and a lack of progress in tackling the problems of the country.

On 25 July 2020, around 500 Rizeigat militiamen clashed with Masalit fighters at Misterei (West Darfur state), following the killing of a mother and her children in the area the previous day. At least 77 are reported to have been killed (including at least 4 police, presumed to be fighting against Rizeigat) and around 60 wounded, whilst the police station was stormed and the armory looted by the Rizeigat. At least 1,500 families have been displaced.
Around 25 July 2020 (as reported), unknown gunmen shot and wounded a woman in the area of Gurni in Nertiti locality (Central Darfur state). There is no further information.

On 26 July 2020, dozens of lawyers demonstrated in El Fasher (North Darfur state), calling for the release of a lawyer arrested in Khartoum, and for an end to insecurity and arbitrary detentions in the area. [size=dozens]
On 26 July 2020, feminist groups demonstrated in Khartoum, against the recent appointment of only 2 female governors (out of 18 governorships). [size=no report]

On 26 July 2020, members of the Beja ethnic group blocked the main road to Khartoum near Sinkat (Red Sea state), to highlight changes they wanted made to the Eastern Track peace process, which has recently been reopened for further negotiations. [size=no report]
On 26 July 2020, street cleaners demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for increases in wages and for protective equipment to be provided to them, due to the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

On 26 July 2020, suspected Misseriya gunmen attacked Borunga in Kass locality (South Darfur state). Information on fatalities or casualties is unclear; at least 20,500 were displaced between this attack and a subsequent raid on 31 July, whilst 28 dwellings were torched.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column17: On 26 July 2020, in-fighting among the SLM/A-Nur rebel group was reported in Sharg Jebel Marrah locality (South Darfur state), with fighting occurring in Buh and or Torong Tonga (the latter being close to Sabun El Fag and Gur Lambung, with no geographic information available on Buh). 48 were reported killed between this event and another on 3 August (fatalities distributed evenly across two events). Large numbers of civilians are reported to have been displaced. Event presumed to involve loyalist SLM/A-Nur against a splinter faction, pending further information.
On 26 July 2020, a police officer was killed by an unknown group in Abu Kershola town in Rashad locality (South Kordofan state). There is no further information.

column16: Darfur 24; Radio Dabanga; Al Rakoba; Reuters
column17: On 26 July 2020, Mahriya Rizeigat pastoralists clashed with Bani Hussein farmers at Al Jarf in El Sireaf locality (North Darfur state), with five being killed, and dozens reported injured. Security forces intervened to prevent further clashes.

On 27 July 2020, members of the Beja ethnic group barricaded the main road to Khartoum near Sinkat (Red Sea state) again with logs and rocks. The demonstrators are calling for changes to the Eastern Track peace process, which has recently been reopened for further negotiations. [size=no report]
On 27 July 2020, a farmer was killed by unknown person(s) at or near Abu Kershola town in Rashad locality (South Kordofan state). There is no further information.

On 28 July 2020, residents of Abu Jubaiha (South Kordofan state) began a sit-in protest at the administrative HQ, calling for the dismissal of the locality director and local army commander; for an end to environmental damage caused by gold mining; and for a large number of improvements in socio-economic standards in the area. [size=no report]

On 28 July 2020, members of the Beja ethnic group barricaded the main road to Khartoum near Sinkat (Red Sea state) again, leading to clashes with truck drivers who were prevented from moving, leaving 5 people wounded (3 seriously). The reasons for the clashes are unclear, though one source suggests that truck drivers were defending themselves from suspected thieves. The demonstrators are calling for changes to the Eastern Track peace process, which has recently been reopened for further negotiations. [size=no report]
On 28 July 2020, demonstrators demonstrated in Kassala (Kassala state), denouncing the recently appointed governor of Kassala state. [size=no report]

On 28 July 2020, striking railway workers demonstrated in Khartoum, against the failure of authorities to pay their salaries for the month of July, and for the delayed payment of overtime hours. [size=no report]

On 28 July 2020, residents of Kadugli (South Kordofan state) demonstrated against ongoing violence and insecurity in and around the city, with protesters handing a petition to the new governor, calling for improvements in security. [size=no report]

On 30 July 2020, members of the Fallata pastoralist group clashed with members of the Taaisha ethnic group at Magangari along the border between Dimsu and Um Dafug locality of South Darfur state, resulting in at least 20 deaths, with dozens wounded. The reason for the fighting is unclear.

Around 31 July 2020 (as reported), IDPs fleeing from Abu Dos village of Gereida locality (South Darfur state) were attacked by an unspecified group. The displaced were fleeing to Nyala, Tullus and southern Gereida localities, but the source does not specify which location(s) the attack(s) took place in. There is no information on injuries or fatalities.

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Military Intelligence Service; Civilians (Sudan)
column17: On 31 July 2020, hundreds of demonstrators (including IDPs) rioted in Kass (South Darfur state) following an attack on Borunga earlier that day. Demonstrators attacked the police station; torching it and stealing from the armory, before releasing prisoners. A member of SAF Military Intelligence and a civilian were killed during the riots. [size=hundreds]

column16: Al Rakoba; Radio Dabanga; Ayin Network; UNSC; Sudan Tribune; Darfur 24
column17: On 31 July 2020, a suspected Misseriya militia group attacked Borunga village in Kass locality (South Darfur state) seemingly in retaliation after its leader had been arrested the day before and released on the morning of 31 July. The group burned dwellings and vehicles, and killed at least one person (some reports suggest ""scores"" were killed) and wounded at least 3. At least 20,500 have been displaced between this clash and an early clash on 26 July.
On 31 July 2020, youth demonstrated in Borunga in Kass locality (South Darfur state), in opposition to a violent attack earlier that day. Police used teargas to disperse the youth. [size=no report]

On 1 August 2020, unknown gunmen attacked several (unspecified) villages in Shattai locality (South Darfur state). There is no further information, including whether there were injuries or fatalities. Thousands are reported to have been displaced between violence in Shattai and Kass localities.

On 1 August 2020, Zaghawa farmers and members of the Nubian ethnic group clashed with bladed weapons at Iskan village close to New Halfa (Kassala state), after a dispute escalated. 2 were killed and 28 injured (7 seriously), and property and vehicles were torched.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 2 August 2020, an unknown group clashed with RSF paramilitaries at Borunga in Kass locality (South Darfur state), killing one 1 RSF and wounding 4 other paramilitaries, with 11 civilians also wounded. It is unclear if the group is the same one linked to an attack on Borunga on 31 July.

Around 2 August 2020 (as reported), residents of Umm Dhibban and Al-Asilat in Sharq el Nile locality (Khartoum state) blocked the highway to Wad Medani (presumed to be close to Umm Dhiban) with burning tires, in opposition to the failure of authorities to provide flood relief. [size=no report]

On 2 August 2020, unknown gunmen once again attacked several (unspecified) villages in Shattai locality (South Darfur state). There is no further information, including whether there were injuries or fatalities. Thousands are reported to have been displaced between violence in Shattai and Kass localities.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column17: On 3 August 2020, in-fighting among the SLM/A-Nur rebel group was reported in Sharg Jebel Marrah locality (South Darfur state), with fighting occurring in Buh and or Torong Tonga (the latter being close to Sabun El Fag and Gur Lambung, with no geographic information available on Buh). 48 were reported killed between this event and another on 26 July (fatalities distributed evenly across two events). Large numbers of civilians are reported to have been displaced. Event presumed to involve loyalist SLM/A-Nur against a splinter faction, pending further information.
On 4 August 2020, gunmen hijacked an ambulance in Nyala (South Darfur state), and briefly abducted the driver of the vehicle, before releasing him later that day at Abu Shouk camp.

On 4 August 2020, 3 armed men (described as 'militiamen') attacked two IDP gold miners at Foula in Kutum locality (North Darfur state, approximate coordinates from description in source used), killing one and seriously wounding the other. The group have also been reportedly involved in a series of robberies in the area.
On 6 August 2020, residents of Suakin (Red Sea state) blocked the main road with burning tires, to denounce continuing fuel shortages in the area. [size=no report]

column16: Ayin Network; Sudan Tribune; Sudan News Agency; Darfur 24; Radio Dabanga
column17: Around 6 August 2020, around 3 civilians were reported to have been killed and 8 wounded in the Khor Warral area of Dilling locality (South Kordofan state). The army has accused SPLM-North (al-Hilu faction) forces of mining the area and attacking pastoralists, whilst the rebels have accused a pro-government Baggara Hawazma militia of killing residents of the local area in two attacks.

On 7 August 2020, youth (described as being supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood) demonstrated after Friday prayers in Khartoum, in opposition to changes to the constitution and the use of force by authorities to suppress protests by Muslim and conservative groups. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: Around 8 August 2020 (as reported), residents of Abu Karinka locality (East Darfur state) reported that RSF paramilitaries recently deployed to the area have been attacking civilians with whips, and forcibly shaving the heads of those deemed to have 'Western' hairstyles.

column16: Radio Dabanga; Ayin Network; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 8 August 2020, hundreds of members of the Fellata ethnic group began a sit-in protest at Nyala (South Darfur state), denouncing a spate of arrests of their kinsmen in the Saadoun area. [size=hundreds]

On 8 August 2020, around 70 men (suspected of being Ngok Dinka, and coded as such) attacked Ngok Dinka domestic workers employed by Misseriya at the village of Ibrahim in the area between Goli and Todach in the disputed Abyei area (coordinates for intermediate location of Thothok used at GP2). A young Ngok Dinka child was killed as well as two of the attackers, though it is unclear whether the defending armed group were Ngok Dinka and/or Misseriya. 4 Ngok Dinka workers sustained wounds in the attack.

column16: Sudan Tribune; Reuters; AP; VOA; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 9 August 2020, members of the Nuba community who were marching to the governor's office in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) were attacked by members of the Beni Amir ethnic group after passing through their neighborhood, leading to intense clashes. In the five days of fighting that followed, at least 35 killed (one of whom died later of their wounds), including six on the first day of fighting, 123 injured (including at least some soldiers), and at least 85 arrested. Homes and shops have been torched. Fatalities distributed across five events to conform to death toll reported across the first three days of fighting, with remaining fatalities split evenly across the fourth and fifth days.

On 9 August 2020, Darfurians living in Khartoum demonstrated against continuing insecurity in South Darfur; arbitrary arrests in the area; and for justice for those who have been displaced due to violence. [size=no report]

On 9 August 2020, SSPDF allegedly attacked the Ngok Dinka village of Goli (Abyei), killing three (including a child) and wounding three. Two soldiers of their own were lost during fighting. There is no clear motive for the attack.
On 10 August 2020, armed pastoralists abducted a farmer from Dobo Umda in Dar El Salam locality (North Darfur state).
On 10 August 2020, members of the Nuba community in Khartoum demonstrated against ongoing violence in South Kordofan state, including numerous attacks on Nuba civilians. [size=no report]

column16: VOA; Sudan Tribune; Reuters; AP; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 10 August 2020, clashes between members of the Beni Amir and Nuba continued, with at least 35 killed (one of whom died later of their wounds), including seven on the second day of fighting, and 123 injured (including at least some soldiers) across five days of fighting in Port Sudan, and at least 85 have been arrested. Homes and shops have been torched. Fatalities distributed across five events to conform to death toll reported across the first three days of fighting, with remaining fatalities split evenly across the fourth and fifth days.
On 10 August 2020, health workers based at an isolation center in Khartoum protested against their new accommodation arrangements, and at the lack of salaries for the month of July. [size=no report]

On 11 August 2020, demonstrators gathered at the Ministry of Planning and Urban Development in Khartoum, calling for land they purchased in a housing development scheme to be officially turned over to them. [size=no report]

column16: AP; Reuters; VOA; Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 11 August 2020, clashes between members of the Beni Amir and Nuba continued, with at least 35 killed (one of whom died later of their wounds), including 12 on the third day of fighting, and 123 injured (including at least some soldiers) across five days of fighting in Port Sudan, and at least 85 have been arrested. Homes and shops have been torched. Fatalities distributed across five events to conform to death toll reported across the first three days of fighting, with remaining fatalities split evenly across the fourth and fifth days.
On 11 August 2020, armed pastoralists attacked and wounded three farmers in the Kombo Jali area 8km west of Nertiti (Central Darfur state, coordinates for nearby Asandalou used).

Around 12 August 2020 (as reported), Ethiopian Shifta attacked an unspecified location along the Sudanese-Ethiopian border in El Fashaga locality (Gedaref state), stealing 9,000 sheep, camels and cows, and killing an unspecified number of farmers in the area. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

column16: VOA; Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune; AP; Reuters
column17: On 12 August 2020, clashes between members of the Beni Amir and Nuba continued, with at least 35 killed (one of whom died later of their wounds) and 123 injured (including at least some soldiers) across five days of fighting in Port Sudan, and at least 85 have been arrested. Homes and shops have been torched. Fatalities distributed across five events to conform to death toll reported across the first three days of fighting, with remaining fatalities split evenly across the fourth and fifth days.

column16: Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga; Reuters; VOA; AP
column17: On 13 August 2020, clashes between members of the Beni Amir and Nuba continued, with at least 35 killed (one of whom died later of their wounds) and 123 injured (including at least some soldiers) across five days of fighting in Port Sudan, and at least 85 have been arrested. Homes and shops have been torched. Fatalities distributed across five events to conform to death toll reported across the first three days of fighting, with remaining fatalities split evenly across the fourth and fifth days. Looting has been reported in the aftermath of the clashes.

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 13 August 2020, Resistance Committees from Red Sea state organized a demonstration in Khartoum, to denounce ongoing violence in Port Sudan, and the failure of authorities to restore order. [size=no report]

On 14 August 2020, unspecified security forces (presumed to be police) arrested a large number of activists as well as residents of Port Sudan (Red Sea state), with at least four being tortured during detention.

On 16 August 2020, demonstrators gathered at an unspecified location in Karai locality (Khartoum state), calling for the removal of the locality director and corrupt officials, and improvements in waste management. The demonstrators began a sit-in protest that has lasted at least 5 days. [size=no report]
On 17 August 2020, unspecified security forces (presumed to be police) detained and assaulted health workers at a checkpoint in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). There is no clear motive for the assault.
On 17 August 2020, a father and his son were killed near El Beida/Al Beada in Kalimendo locality (North Darfur state) by an unknown group. There is no further information.

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 17 August 2020, hundreds of demonstrators marched in Wad Medani (El Gazira state) as part of Resistance Committee-organized protests decrying the trajectory of the revolution, alongside a raft of grievances relating to the administration of the state. [size=hundreds]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 17 August 2020, thousands of demonstrators marched in River Nile state (presumed to be at the state capital Ed Damer, since the governor was presented with a memorandum during the demonstration) as part of Resistance Committee-organized protests decrying the trajectory of the revolution, alongside a raft of grievances relating to the administration of the state. [size=thousands]
Around 17 August 2020, residents of Muglad (West Kordofan state) began a sit-in protest in the town, calling for improvements to basic services and infrastructure in the area. [size=no report]

Around 17 August 2020, residents of Buram (South Darfur state) began a sit-in demonstration, protesting against the failure of authorities to tackle corruption and the lingering presence of officials associated with the Bashir regime, and denouncing the increasingly limited services provided in the hospital at Buram. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 17 August 2020, thousands of protesters marched in the Greater Khartoum area (three events recorded in Khartoum, Khartoum North and Omdurman) as part of Resistance Committee-organized protests decrying the trajectory of the revolution, and the failure of the FFC and military wings of the transitional government to fully implement the agreement signed one year ago. The demonstrators also called for a restructuring of the FFC, and for the security forces to relinquish control of businesses. Police and unknown men in civilian attire attacked protesters with batons and tear gas, wounding an unspecified number, and arresting 77. The newly rebranded intelligence forces have denied their agents were the men in civilian attire. [size=thousands]
On 17 August 2020, a female farmer was wounded in an attack by armed pastoralists near El Fasher city (North Darfur state). There is no further information.

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 17 August 2020, thousands of protesters marched in the Greater Khartoum area (three events recorded in Khartoum, Khartoum North and Omdurman) as part of Resistance Committee-organized protests decrying the trajectory of the revolution, and the failure of the FFC and military wings of the transitional government to fully implement the agreement signed one year ago. The demonstrators also called for a restructuring of the FFC, and for the security forces to relinquish control of businesses. Police and unknown men in civilian attire attacked protesters with batons and tear gas, wounding an unspecified number, and arresting 77. The newly rebranded intelligence forces have denied their agents were the men in civilian attire. [size=thousands]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 17 August 2020, thousands of protesters marched in the Greater Khartoum area (three events recorded in Khartoum, Khartoum North and Omdurman) as part of Resistance Committee-organized protests decrying the trajectory of the revolution, and the failure of the FFC and military wings of the transitional government to fully implement the agreement signed one year ago. The demonstrators also called for a restructuring of the FFC, and for the security forces to relinquish control of businesses. Police and unknown men in civilian attire attacked protesters with batons and tear gas, wounding an unspecified number, and arresting 77. The newly rebranded intelligence forces have denied their agents were the men in civilian attire. [size=thousands]

On 18 August 2020, relatives of a father and son who were killed in El Beida the previous day protested against their killing in El Fasher city (North Darfur state), calling for the attackers to face justice. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 18 August 2020, Resistance Committee activists blocked roads in Khartoum with barricades, to denounce the attacks on demonstrators in Khartoum the previous day. [size=no report]

Around 18 August 2020 (as reported), dozens of demonstrators began a sit-in protest in El Fasher (North Darfur state), demanding severance payments that they claim the UN-AU peacekeeping mission owes them. [size=dozens]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 18 August 2020, RSF paramilitaries shot and wounded a commercial driver on the outskirts of Abu Jubaiha (South Kordofan state). There is no clear motive for the attack.

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 18 August 2020, Resistance Committee activists barricaded roads in Burri in east Khartoum, to denounce the attacks on demonstrators in Khartoum the previous day. [size=no report]

On 19 August 2020, hundreds of striking workers demonstrated at the Kenana Sugar Plant in El Jabalian locality (White Nile state), denouncing the refusal of the management of the plant to meet with the union to resolve unequal treatment of workers. [size=hundreds]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 19 August 2020, Resistance Committee activists once again barricaded roads in Khartoum to denounce violence against demonstrators on 17 August, using burning tires to prevent movement of traffic. Police were reported to have detained and tortured a participant in the demonstrations, warning him not to demonstrate in future (coded separately). [size=no report]

On 19 August 2020, four armed pastoralists attempted to rape a female farmer in the Khartoum Jadeed area west of Kebkabiya town (North Darfur state, coordinates for Girgo used at GP2). The woman resisted the sexual assault, and was badly beaten by the attackers.

On 19 August 2020, 20 armed pastoralists attacked Um Gatoi village described as being 30km south-west of Gereida town (South Darfur state, coordinates for Shergeila used at GP2), killing one resident of the village, and looting property.
Around 19 August 2020 (week of), journalists demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for the transitional government to fully adhere to the principles of the revolution. [size=no report]
On 19 August 2020, police were reported to have detained and tortured a participant in the demonstrations in Khartoum earlier the day, warning him not to demonstrate in future.

On 19 August 2020, residents of Tokar locality gathered in Tokar (Red Sea state), calling for the dismissal of the head of the emergency committee due to inaction relating to recent flooding. [size=no report]

On 20 August 2020, demonstrators blocked roads (by unspecified means) in Wad Medani (El Gazira state) in protest at the violent suppression of mass demonstrations by police in Khartoum on 17 August. [size=no report]

On 20 August 2020, demonstrators blocked roads (by unspecified means) in Omdurman as part of continued demonstrations against the violent suppression of protests by police on 17 August. [size=no report]

On 20 August 2020, demonstrators barricaded roads in central Khartoum as part of continued demonstrations against the violent suppression by police on 17 August. Concurrently, demonstrators marched in El Soug El Arabi neighborhood, calling for a correction in the course of the revolution. [size=no report]
Around 22 August 2020, residents of Ghubeish town (West Kordofan state) began a sit-in protest, calling for improved infrastructure and services. [size=no report]

On 23 August 2020, representatives of 18 civil society organizations demonstrated in Khartoum, presenting a memorandum to the Prime Minister and Sovereign Council, calling for the dismantling of the military and paramilitary forces in the country. [size=at least 18]

On 23 August 2020, demonstrators (estimated to be either in the hundreds or in the thousands; lower estimate used) marched in Abu Jubaiha (South Kordofan state), calling for authorities to implement a range of improvements in infrastructure and living conditions that protesters at the sit-in camp have demanded for close to a month. [size=hundreds]

On 24 August 2020, Darfurian pastoralists demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for an end to bloodshed in the region; to improvements for both farmers and pastoralists; and for improved services throughout Darfur. Residents of Buram in South Darfur also demonstrated in solidarity with an ongoing sit-in protest in their home town [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 24 August 2020, residents and Resistance Committee members (FFC) of Kerma (Northern state) began a sit-in protest, calling for improved services and infrastructure, and for the dismissal of the bureaucratic elite and senior health workers from the area. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 24 August 2020, residents and Resistance Committee members (FFC) of Jebel Awlia (Khartoum state) began a sit-in protest, calling for improved services, infrastructure and security, and for the dismissal of the bureaucratic elite from the area. [size=no report]

Around 25 August 2020 (as reported), SAF soldiers were reported to have beaten three farmers when they attempted to farm in lands that had been cleared for dam construction (and subsequently occupied by soldiers), presumed to be in the area south-east of Shuwak (Gedaref state) based on contextual information in the source.

column16: Radio Dabanga; Ayin Network; VOA; UNOCHA
column17: On 25 August 2020, Beni Amir militia attacked members of the Hadendawa clan of the Beja ethnic group who were protesting against the recently appointed governor of Kassala state, causing fighting in Kassala town and resulting in at least one death (local reports suggest fatalities in the region of 15 across 25 and 26 August) and wounding at least 18. Fighting involved bladed weapons and sticks.

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: Around 25 August 2020, demonstrators (including Resistance Committee members, FFC) began a sit-in protest in Omdurman, calling for the removal of the executive director of the locality; for food and water to be supplied; and for improvements for services, particularly for refugees in the area. [size=no report]

On 26 August 2020, women from several civil society organizations demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for an end to harassment and violence against women, following harassment directed at a female singer in the previous week. [size=no report]

On 26 August 2020, retired civil service pensioners protested in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), calling for improvements to their pension payments. The governor has recognized their demands. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 26 August 2020, demonstrators (including Resistance Committee members, FFC) gathered in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state) to denounce the arrest of 7 SPLM-N supporters by Military Intelligence the previous day. [size=no report]

column16: Radio Dabanga; UNOCHA; VOA; Ayin Network
column17: On 26 August 2020, members of the Beni Amir community marched in Kassala (Kassala state) in support of the recently appointed governor, prompting renewed clashes with members of the Hadendawa clan of the Beja ethnic group, resulting in at least one death (local reports suggest fatalities in the region of 15 across 25 and 26 August), in fighting that involved firearms, bladed weapons and sticks. Crops were also torched in areas surrounding the city.
On 27 August 2020, demonstrators marched in Ghubeish town (West Kordofan state), in support for the sit-in protest, and calling for improvements in basic services. [size=no report]

On 27 August 2020, members of the Salvation Initiative (a Gedaref-based activist group) marched in Gedaref (Gedaref state), calling for the military to relinquish control of companies they own; for RSF paramilitaries to vacate El Fil forest; and for Ethiopian forces to leave disputed areas along the border. [size=no report]
On 27 August 2020, residents of El Golid protested in Dongola (Northern state), calling for land taken from them during the Bashir regime to be returned to them. [size=no report]

column16: Ayin Network; UNOCHA; VOA; Radio Dabanga
column17: On 27 August 2020, Beni Amir clashed once again with members of the Hadendawa clan of the Beja ethnic group in Kassala (Kassala state), resulting in at least five deaths (one of whom died the following day of their wounds) and five others wounded, in fighting that involved firearms, bladed weapons and sticks. Shops were looted, and property torched.
On 27 August 2020, hundreds of youth marched in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), denouncing increasing insecurity in the city. [size=hundreds]

column16: Radio Dabanga; UNOCHA; VOA; Ayin Network
column17: On 28 August 2020, Beni Amir clashed once again with members of the Hadendawa clan of the Beja ethnic group in Kassala (Kassala state). Shops were looted, and property torched, though there are currently no reports on casualties or fatalities.

On 30 August 2020, pastoralists demonstrated in El Geneina (West Darfur state), calling for peace, neutral security forces to uphold security, and for displaced persons to be allowed to return to their home areas and be provided with surfaces. [size=no report]

column9: SPLM-N-Agar: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North) (Malik Agar faction); SLM/A-Minnawi: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Minnawi Faction); SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction); JEM: Justice and Equality Movement
column16: Radio Dabanga; Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune
column17: On 31 August 2020, the Sudanese government signed a series of eight distinct agreements (which cumulatively form a comprehensive peace agreement) in Juba, South Sudan. The agreements include a set of changes to administrative structures, and outline military and political power-sharing provisions, with specific economic and security arrangements for certain areas. The agreements were signed by members of the SRF umbrella group (including JEM, SPLM-N Agar faction, and SLM/A-TC) along with SLM/A Minawi rebels. The two major rebel groups - SLM/A al-Nur, and SPLM-N al-Hilu (a.k.a. Nuba Mountains faction) - did not sign the agreement. On 3 September, PM Hamdock signed a separate declaration of principles with Abdelaziz al-Hilu in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, paving the way for future talks.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 1 September 2020, SAF soldiers and RSF paramilitaries clashed with residents of Port Sudan (Red Sea state) during a disarmament campaign in the city, after security forces abused and attempted to detain residents. One member of the Port Sudan militia died, 17 were wounded, and 8 members of the security forces were also wounded.

On 2 September 2020, employees of the Khartoum Water Authority demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for elements of the NCP regime to be removed from their positions in the authority; for the firing of the Director General and other senior officials; and for an end to corruption and casualization of employment. The Director General of the authority ordered regular forces (presumed to be army) to prevent the demonstrators from advancing to the central offices. [size=no report]

On 2 September 2020, former employees of the civil service demonstrated in Khartoum, in protest at their dismissal from their roles at the end of December 2019. The demonstrators called for their reinstatement, and for dues to be paid. [size=no report]
On 2 September 2020, workers from the General Secretariat of the Press and Publications Council demonstrated in Khartoum, demanding their pay from June onwards. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 2 September 2020, demonstrators (including Resistance Committee members) marched in Khartoum in solidarity with the ongoing sit-in demonstration in Ghubeish in West Kordofan. [size=no report]

Around 2 September 2020 (as reported), pastoralists demonstrated in Ed Daein (East Darfur state), calling for peace between pastoralists and farmers, and for pasture and grazing right to be clarified. [size=no report]
On 3 September 2020, demonstrators marched in Nyala (South Darfur state) calling for the military to take power in the country. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 3 September 2020, Resistance Committee members demonstrated in Khartoum, condemning a draconian penalties in the Information and Cybercrime Law, which they say will limit the ability of activists and reporters to highlight corruption and violent abuse by those in positions of authority. [size=no report]
On 4 September 2020, supporters of the outlawed NCP (estimated at between dozens, and fewer than 200) demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for the armed forces to seize power in a coup. [size=dozens]

column7: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction)
column17: On 4 September 2020, dozens of the SPLM-N (Abdelaziz al-Hilu faction, a.k.a. Nuba Mountains Liberation Council faction) demonstrated at Khartoum airport in support of peace talks between PM Hamdock and Abdelaziz al-Hilu. [size=dozens]
Around 4 September 2020 (as reported), rickshaw drivers in Nyala (South Darfur) began a sit-in protest, after a driver was murdered in the city. [size=no report]

On 4 September 2020, members of an unidentified armed group shot 3 civilians who were traveling from Tusi to Toro (South Kordofan), killing 2 and injuring the third. The reason for the attack is unknown.

On 5 September 2020, residents of Duma (South Darfur state) blocked the main road running through the town (through unspecified means) to protest against rising insecurity in the area, following the death of a policeman the previous day. [size=no report]
On 7 September 2020, armed pastoralists killed another pastoralist and took more than 70 livestock in Nertiti (Central Darfur).
Around 10 September 2020 (as reported), armed pastoralists kidnapped 11 civilians from Nertiti (Central Darfur State) in retaliation for a shepherd who was killed earlier in the week.

Around 10 September 2020 (as reported), gunmen believed to belong to a Masalit ethnic militia attacked pastoralists in Damrah near Misterei (West Darfur), leading to the death of a pastoralist and the injury of another.
On 10 September 2020, a displaced civilian was killed by an unidentified armed group east of Nertiti (Central Darfur). Reason for the attack not unknown.

Around 10 September 2020 (as reported), demonstrators gathered outside of the police station in Nertiti (Central Darfur State) to demonstrate against the killings of civilians by armed pastoralists that week (coded separately). The police used tear gas and live bullets to disperse protesters, killing 2 of them. [size=no report]

On 10 September 2020, two civilians walking to the market were killed by armed pastoralists in Nertiti (Central Darfur State) in retaliation for an incident in the week in which a shepherd was killed (coded separately).
On 10 September 2020, members of the North Darfur Artists Initiative demonstrated in El Fasher (North Darfur), calling for a return of activities related to the arts. [size=no report]

On 10 September 2020, hundreds of demonstrators marched through the town of Ghabish (West Kordofan) demanding clean drinking water, electricity, better health services, and new governing officials unaffiliated with the previous government. [size=hundreds]

On 10 September 2020, workers from the Khartoum Water Authority demonstrated in Khartoum (Khartoum), calling on the government to accelerate the formation of the Anticorruption Commission. [size=no report]

On 13 September 2020, dozens of blind civilians and those with other special needs staged a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare in Khartoum (Khartoum), demanding an investigation into the Federation of Handicapped for potential fraud. [size=dozens]
On 14 September 2020, employees of the Sudanese Electricity Distribution Co. demonstrated in Khartoum (Khartoum) against the dismissal of 412 employees. [size=no report]

On 17 September 2020, dozens of demonstrators gathered in Gedaref (Gedaref) to demonstrate against the appointment of two former security officials to office and called for an investigation into their role in the killings of protesters during the revolution. [size=dozens]

On 17 September 2020, members of an unidentified armed group (claimed to be linked to the former regime of Omar el-Bashir according to one source) shot and killed a displaced farmer at Aish Barra west of Murnei (West Darfur state), which prompted the victim's family members to find the shooters and clash with them, leaving a second displaced farmer dead. [size=no report]

On 19 September 2020, residents of Murnei (West Darfur state) protested following the killing of two civilians in the area, delivering a memorandum to the authorities in Kreinik locality. [size=no report]

On 19 September 2020, activists from the Women's Union demonstrated at the Public Prosecutor's office in Khartoum, calling for the release of several activist artists who had been controversially arrested in August. [size=no report]

column7: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
column17: Around 20 September 2020 (as reported), a mass grave was discovered at an unspecified military base in Karari locality (Khartoum state), with the victims reported to be dissidents tortured by the security services under the Bashir regime (perpetrators presumed to be SAF and NISS). The number of bodies in the grave is unclear.

On 20 September 2020, thousands of demonstrators gathered in Murnei (West Darfur state), blocking roads (through unspecified means) and began a sit-in protest, to demonstrate against recent killings in the area. [size=thousands]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: Around 20 September 2020, Resistance Committee members demonstrated at the women's prison in Omdurman, to protest against a controversial arrest and conviction of several activist artists. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 20 September 2020, Resistance Committee members blocked roads (through unspecified means) in Omdurman, calling for local officials associated with the Bashir regime to be removed. [size=no report]

Around 20 September 2020 (as reported), six pastoralists beat villagers Abu Sheikan in Saraf Omra locality (North Darfur state) after their camels caused damage in the village, wounding three of the villagers.
On 20 September 2020, activists demonstrated at the Ministry of Justice in Khartoum, to protest against a controversial arrest and conviction of several activist artists. [size=no report]

column7: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction); SPA: Sudan Professionals Association
column17: On 20 September 2020, thousands of supporters of Abdelaziz al-Hilu's faction of the SPLM-N along with SPA supporters demonstrated in Kadugli (South Kordofan state), calling for a secular state and for a just peace to be achieved. [size=thousands]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 20 September 2020, Resistance Committee members demonstrated in Kerma (Northern state), calling for the removal of corrupt officials in El Borgeig locality. [size=no report]

On 21 September 2020, dozens of demonstrators gathered in Khartoum (Khartoum), calling for SLM/A al Nur rebels to reveal the fate of a man they say was abducted and tortured by the group. The rebel group has denied involvement. [size=dozens]

On 21 September 2020, 10 armed men fired shots in a farming area near Kambo Adam Omar (described as being 21km west of Nertiti, Central Darfur state, with coordinates used for the settlement of Fogadiko used at GP2), causing farmers to flee. The attackers then raped and killed a displaced woman who was unable to escape.

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 23 September 2020, Resistance Committee members demonstrated in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), to denounce soaring prices, poor services and the reduction of flour quotas by authorities. Demonstrators barricaded roads with burning tires. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Military Intelligence Service
column17: On 23 September 2020, residents of Abu Jubaiha (South Kordofan state) demonstrated in support of the recent movement towards an agreement between SPLM-N el-Hilu rebels and civilian politicians. Soldiers (variously described as being SAF and/or SAF Military Intelligence attempted to disperse the protesters, and arrested 31. Military Intelligence officers severely beat a Nuba activist they had arrested, ostensibly for holding an event without their approval. [size=at least 31]
On 23 September 2020, demonstrators gathered in El Goled (Northern state), calling for corrupt officials to be removed. The demonstrators then began a sit-in protest. [size=no report]

On 24 September 2020, students demonstrated against poor economic conditions in Zalingei (Central Darfur state), before being intercepted by police. Differing accounts indicate 27 or 28 students were wounded by police who used live rounds and tear gas against the demonstrators, whilst students may have thrown stones at police, wounding a small number. [size=at least 27]
On 24 September 2020, two farmers were assassinated by two gunmen at a house in El Faid Um-Abdalla close to Rashad town (South Kordofan state). The reason for the killings are unclear.
On 24 September 2020, dozens of activists demonstrated at a courthouse in Khartoum, in protest at a controversial sentencing of five activists on questionable public order grounds. [size=dozens]
On 24 September 2020, a farmer was killed by an unknown group north of Kadugli (South Kordofan state), in an attack which is implied (but not confirmed) to have been carried out by pastoralists.

column7: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction)
column17: Around 24 September 2020, a large group of supporters of the Abdelaziz al-Hilu faction of the SPLM-N demonstrated in Dilling (South Kordofan state), calling for a secular state and just peace to be realized. [size=large]

column7: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction)
column17: Around 24 September 2020, a large group of supporters of the Abdelaziz al-Hilu faction of the SPLM-N demonstrated in Kauda (South Kordofan state), calling for a secular state and just peace to be realized. [size=large]

column7: SPLM-N-NMLC: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North) (Nuba Mountains Liberation Council Faction); SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change; DUP: Democratic Unionist Party; Nuba Ethnic Group (Sudan)
column17: On 24 September 2020, demonstrations took place in Khartoum involving supporters of the Abdelaziz al-Hilu faction of the SPLM-N; the SPA; Resistance Committees; the DUP; and members of the Nuba ethnic group. The protesters were calling for progress with peace talks between the government and SPLM-N as well as SLM/A-al Nur rebels; for the agreements to be negotiated with civilian authorities rather than military forces; and for the root causes of Sudan's civil wars to be tackled. [size=no report]
On 24 September 2020, armed pastoralists attacked farmers at Wadi Kebe (Central Darfur state; approximate coordinates 3km north of Nertiti used), killing 2 and seriously wounding 1.
On 24 September 2020, unknown attackers shot dead a farmer in Saraf Ad Dai north of Kadugli town (South Kordofan state), for unclear reasons. The victim was shot seven times.

On 25 September 2020, residents of Kadugli (South Kordofan state) demonstrated against increasing insecurity directed towards farmers by militias in the area. Residents blocked the main road to Dilling (through unspecified means), stating they will only reopen the road once security has been restored. The protesters reopened the road the following day. [size=no report]
On 26 September 2020, unknown gunmen fired upon civilians travelling to El Fasher near Gallab in Tawila locality (North Darfur state), killing one and wounding two, before robbing the victims.

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 26 September 2020, Resistance Committee members demonstrated in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), denouncing deteriorating security in the city. [size=no report]

On 27 September 2020, gunmen on camels attacked a group of civilians two kilometers east of Tur in Nertiti locality (Central Darfur state), killing one, before gang-raping a 50 year-old lady. The attackers then robbed the remaining victims.

column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column17: On 28 September 2020, SAF and SLM/A-Nur rebels clashed at Baldong/Baldon in southern Nertiti locality (Central Darfur state), with both sides accusing the other of initiating the clash. There are no reports as to the numbers killed or wounded, though SLM/A-Nur rebels claim to have inflicted ""heavy losses"" on SAF soldiers.
On 29 September 2020, demonstrators marched in El Fasher (North Darfur state), calling for an end to soaring prices of essential goods and food. [size=no report]

On 29 September 2020, unknown gunmen shot a farmer who was transporting traders on his tractor at an unspecified location near Abu Jubaiha (South Kordofan state) along the road to Kalogi. The farmer died of his wounds shortly after, and the attackers robbed the remaining victims.

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 29 September 2020, demonstrators (including Resistance Committee members) marched in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), calling for the dismissal of officials linked to the Bashir regime; for intervention in the market to stabilize prices; and for an investigation to begin into the conduct of Gazira state authorities regarding the distribution of basic goods. [size=no report]

On 30 September 2020, around 150 striking gold miners began a sit-in protest at the gates of Hassai gold mine in Haya locality (Red Sea state), calling for an increase in salaries. The managers of the mine claim that the strike is unrelated to pay, and instead is intended to cause disruption as part of demonstrations amongst parts of the Beja ethnic group in Eastern Sudan. [size=about 150]

On 30 September 2020, hundreds of anti-government demonstrations marched in Khartoum, blocking streets with burning tires, and calling for an end to the Hamdock-led government, and for an improvement to economic conditions. Police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse crowds. [size=hundreds]
On 30 September 2020, unknown attackers shot and killed a fisherman near Dito in Gereida locality (South Darfur state). There is no clear motive for the attack.

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 30 September 2020, RSF paramilitaries severely beat a student at a petrol station in Khartoum, after he challenged the soldiers for skipping the que for petrol. The paramilitaries also shaved the head of the victim.
On 30 September 2020, demonstrators from Kutum in North Darfur demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for an end to attacks on farmers by militia forces in the area. [size=no report]

On 30 September 2020, residents of Deim El Musheiha (presumed to be El Gazira state, coordinates for state capital Wad Medani used at GP3) blocked the highway from Wad Medani to Sennar (through unspecified means), to denounce soaring prices of bread. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: Around 1 October 2020, demonstrators (including Resistance Committee members) marched in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) denouncing soaring prices of essential goods and food. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 1 October 2020, demonstrators (including Resistance Committee members) marched again in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), calling for a correction in the course of the uprising, and an end to soaring prices of basic goods. [size=no report]
Around 1 October 2020 (as reported), a hardline Muslim militia attacked followers of a Sufi order at Hilaliya (El Gazira locality) with knives and sticks, wounding four.

On 1 October 2020, striking workers from the Khartoum Water Authority marched in the capital, and attempted to hand a memorandum to the governor of Khartoum detailing a list of demands relating to the regularization of employment and an end to surveillance and corruption in the authority. The governor refused to accept the memorandum. [size=no report]

On 2 October 2020, unknown attackers killed three people at an unspecified location on the road between South Darfur state capital Nyala and El Radoom in the far south-west of the state. There is no further information.

column6: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
column8: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
column17: On 3 October 2020, clashes were reported between a semi-loyal faction of the SLM/A al-Nur rebel group under the command of 'Gaddura', and a dissident faction possibly under the command of Zunoon Abdelshafi, at Doua in East Jebel Marrah locality (South Darfur state). The clashes are linked to disputes over control of a gold mine near Toreea south of Doua. There is no information on casualties or fatalities, and 4,530 people were displaced to surrounding areas.

column7: Halenga Clan Group (Sudan); Beja Ethnic Group (Sudan)
column17: On 3 October 2020, members of the Halenga clan of the Beja ethnic group demonstrated in Kassala (Kassala state) after the Governor dismissed three Halenga directors of local ministries. The governor has refuted claims of ethnic bias, and says the officials were responsible for detonating conditions in the area. [size=no report]
On 3 October 2020, hundreds of IDPs protested against the Juba peace agreement at Al Hujaj refugee camp in El Geneina city (West Darfur state). [size=hundreds]

On 3 October 2020, dozens of demonstrators (implied to be ethnic Beja) demonstrated in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) against the signing of the peace agreement in Juba, amid dissatisfaction among parts of the Beja towards the Eastern Sudan file of the agreement. The main road from Port Sudan was blocked, though through unspecified means. [size=dozens]

column16: Radio Dabanga; Ayin Network; Middle East Eye
column17: On 4 October 2020, Beja demonstrators blocked the highway (through unspecified means) at Haya (Red Sea state), as part of spreading protests against the Juba peace agreement. [size=no report]

column16: Radio Dabanga; Middle East Eye; Ayin Network
column17: Around 4 October 2020, Beja demonstrators blocked the highway (through unspecified means) at Hoshiri (Red Sea state), as part of spreading protests against the Juba peace agreement. [size=no report]

column16: Middle East Eye; Ayin Network; Radio Dabanga; VOA
column17: On 4 October 2020, thousands of Beja demonstrators blocked roads with burning tires in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), as dock workers closed the port in the city, blocking access with shipping containers. The demonstrations are in response to the signing of the Juba peace agreement. [size=thousands]

Around 4 October 2020, Beja demonstrators blocked the road and railway (through unspecified means) at an unspecified El Qaneb in Dordieb locality in Red Sea state, as part of spreading protests against the Juba peace agreement. [size=no report]

column16: Middle East Eye; Ayin Network; Radio Dabanga
column17: Around 4 October 2020, Beja demonstrators blocked the highway (through unspecified means) at Sinkat (Red Sea state), as part of spreading protests against the Juba peace agreement. [size=no report]

column16: Middle East Eye; Radio Dabanga; Ayin Network
column17: On 4 October 2020, thousands of Beja demonstrators blocked the highway (through unspecified means) at Suakin (Red Sea state), as part of spreading protests against the Juba peace agreement. [size=thousands]

Around 4 October 2020, Beja demonstrators blocked the highway (through unspecified means) at an unspecified location in Dordieb locality in Red Sea state, as part of spreading protests against the Juba peace agreement. [size=no report]

On 4 October 2020, pastoralists demonstrated in Zalingei (Central Darfur state), calling for an end to hate speech and violent attacks against pastoralists; better arrangements for access to water and land; and justice for those who were killed at the sit-in camp in Nertiti. [size=no report]
Around 4 October 2020 (as reported), dismissed workers from Sudan Airways demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for their reinstatement. [size=no report]

Around 4 October 2020 (as reported), workers at a private bank branch in El Geneina (West Darfur state) demonstrated, calling for an increase in salaries and for staff to receive promotions. Six of the workers were subsequently dismissed, transferred or suspended. [size=at least 6]
On 4 October 2020, residents of Suakin (Red Sea state) barricaded the Port Sudan-Khartoum highway to denounce water shortages. [size=no report]

column16: Middle East Eye; Ayin Network; Radio Dabanga; VOA
column17: On 5 October 2020, members of the Beja ethnic group (likely of the Hadendawa clan) armed with bladed weapons, spears and sticks attacked police defending an oil facility in Haya town (Red Sea state), as they attempted to storm the facility. One police officer was stabbed and killed, and an unconfirmed number of people were injured. The unrest relates to discontent among parts of the Beja at the recent Juba peace agreement.
On 5 October 2020, demonstrations gathered at El Soug El Arabi and other areas of Khartoum to denounce shortages of bread and fuel amid soaring prices. [size=no report]

On 5 October 2020, demonstrations gathered at several parts of Omdurman (Umm Badda, Khartoum) to denounce shortages of bread and fuel amid soaring prices, burning tires in the street. Police fired a large quantity of tear gas at the demonstrators. [size=no report]
On 5 October 2020, demonstrators gathered at El Obeid (North Kordofan state) to denounce shortages of bread in the city. [size=no report]
On 5 October 2020, a student was assassinated in a suburb of Dilling (South Kordofan state), after being lured out of his parents compound. There is no further information.

Around 6 October 2020 (between 5 October - 8 October), two civilians were killed at an unspecified area in South Darfur state as they rode on donkeys to the state capital Nyala. There is no further information.
On 6 October 2020, unknown attackers shot and wounded 8 pastoralists in the Zurug area near Kornoi in El Sireaf locality (North Darfur state). There is no clear motive for the attack.
Around 6 October 2020 (between 5 October - 8 October), two farmers were killed near Nertiti (Central Darfur state) by an unspecified armed group. There is no further information.

On 7 October 2020, four armed pastoralists on camels attacked Torbu/Turba police station in Alwehda locality (South Darfur state). One pastoralist and one police officer were killed in the exchange of fire, while two police and a civilian were wounded. The reason for the attack is unclear.

Around 7 October 2020 (week of), Ethiopian shifta were reported to have launched ""sporadic attacks"" against farmers at unspecified locations in disputed farmland in El Fashaga locality (Gedaref state), preventing them from gathering their harvest. There is no information on casualties or fatalities.
On 8 October 2020, veterinary workers gathered in Khartoum, to demonstrate in support of striking veterinary workers in South Kordofan state. [size=no report]

Around 8 October 2020 (as reported), residents of Port Sudan (Red Sea state) blocked a road (through unspecified means) to protest electricity cuts in the city, after a Turkish military vessel which supplied power to the city left the port. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 8 October 2020, Resistance Committee members demonstrated at a mosque in the Souq Libya area of Ombada (Khartoum state), denouncing corruption at senior levels of the mosque, and demanding to see evidence of how donations by worshippers had been spent. [size=no report]

Around 8 October 2020, unknown attackers killed a man near Tendelti in El Geneina locality (West Darfur state) along the Sudan-Chad border. It is unclear whether the attackers were based in Sudan or Chad.

On 8 October 2020, hundreds of demonstrators (mainly comprising market vendors) rioted in Nyala (South Darfur state), burning tires in the street; torching the administrative building; and throwing stones at police (who responded by firing tear gas at the demonstrators). The demonstrators are contesting attempts to reorder and regularize the market layout. [size=hundreds]

Around 9 October 2020 (as reported), residents of Tendelti in El Geneina locality (West Darfur state) demonstrated against the recent killing of man in the area, decrying the ease with which armed groups move across the Sudan-Chad border. [size=no report]

On 11 October 2020, civil servants demonstrated in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), calling for promotions, and arguing there has been unequal treatment of employees with regards to job progression. [size=no report]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: Around 11 October 2020, Resistance Committee members demonstrated in Gedaref (Gedaref state) against soaring prices of bread and fuel, and for the state to intervene to control commodity prices, and to remove corrupt officials. [size=no report]

Around 11 October 2020, around 200 teachers demonstrated in Kassala (Kassala state) calling for the state minister of education to be removed for alleged corruption, and for officials who were not involved in the uprising to also be removed. [size=around 200]

column7: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
column17: On 11 October 2020, Resistance Committee members demonstrated in Kadugli (South Kordofan state) against the presence of Bashir-era officials at a workshop on religious tolerance. [size=no report]
On 12 October 2020, oil workers demonstrated at the GNPOC Tower in Khartoum, calling for a proposed merger to be stopped to safeguard labor rights. [size=no report]

On 12 October 2020, members of the El Gezira and El Managil Farmers Alliance demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for the removal of the governor of the El Gazira scheme, and for greater financial support amid increasing diesel prices. [size=no report]
On 13 October 2020, Beni Amir demonstrators blocked roads in Kassala (Kassala state) with burning tires, to denounce the firing of the Governor of the state that same day. [size=no report]

On 13 October 2020, Prime Minister Hamdock fired Saleh Ammar, the Beni Amir Governor of Kassala, amid deteriorating security in East Sudan. The Governor refused to resign, prompting his dismissal. The appointment of the Governor in July exacerbated tensions among the Beni Amir and Beja clans in the East.

On 13 October 2020, Ethiopian shifta abducted six women and one child from farms near El Leya in El Quresha locality (Gedaref state), and have since demanded a ransom for their return. The abductions follow renewed attacks by Ethiopian irregulars the previous week.
Around 13 October 2020 (as reported), two pastoralists were found dead near Bir Saleeba north of El Geneina (West Darfur state). There is no further information.

column16: Ayin Network; Radio Dabanga; AFP; Al Rakoba
column17: On 14 October 2020, Hadendawa clansmen and members of the Beni Amir ethnic group clashed in Suakin (Red Sea state), in clashes sparked by the dismissal of the governor of Kassala state the previous day. 6 were killed and around 20 wounded.

column16: Al Rakoba; Ayin Network; Radio Dabanga; VOA; AFP
column17: On 14 October 2020, supporters of the recently dismissed governor of Kassala state (and presumed to be Beni Amir) clashed with opponents (presumed to be Beja) in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), resulting in 12 injuries. Gunfire was reported, and roads were blocked. Unspecified security forces were reported to have become involved in the clashes. 3 individuals died the following weekend as a result of violence in Port Sudan, which also took place on 16 October. Three fatalities evenly distributed across both events.

On 14 October 2020, demonstrators (presumed to be Beni Amir) blocked the main road (through unspecified means) from Port Sudan to Khartoum and an unspecified location (coordinates for Hoshiri, Red Sea state, used at GP2), in protest at the dismissal of the governor of Kassala state the previous day. [size=no report]

On 14 October 2020, supporters of the recently dismissed governor of Kassala state (and presumed to be Beni Amir) once again demonstrated in Kassala (Kassala state). Police fired tear gas to disperse the protesters. [size=no report]
On 14 October 2020, university teachers demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for their salaries for September to be paid, and for student living allowances to be disbursed. [size=no report]

column9: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces; Military Forces of Sudan (2019-)
column16: Sudan Tribune; Al Rakoba; Radio Dabanga; Sudan News Agency; Ayin Network; AFP
column17: On 15 October 2020, thousands of supporters of the recently dismissed governor of Kassala state (and presumed to be Beni Amir) demonstrated in Kassala (Kassala state), clashing with police, SAF, and RSF as they attempted to storm the administrative HQ of the city. Eight were killed and at least 30 wounded, with two reports saying a member of the police was among the dead. Dozens were arrested. Government forces were also reported to have fired live ammunition in the direction of a hospital. [size=thousands]

On 15 October 2020, supporters of the recently dismissed governor of Kassala state (and presumed to be Beni Amir) blocked the Port Sudan-Khartoum highway (through unspecified means) at Suakin (Red Sea state). [size=no report]

On 15 October 2020, Resistance Committee members began a sit-in protest in Jebelain (White Nile state), calling for the dismissal of Bashir-era officials; for restructuring of local administration; for increased in the quota of subsidized flour; and for issues with water availability in the town to be rectified. [size=no report]

On 16 October 2020, clashes were reported once again in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), amid ethnicised violence between the Beni Amir and Beja groups. 3 individuals died the following weekend as a result of violence in Port Sudan, which also took place on 14 October. Three fatalities evenly distributed across both events.
On 16 October 2020, thousands of Beni Amir mourners demonstrated in Kassala (Kassala state), denouncing the killing of demonstrators the previous day. [size=thousands]

On 17 October 2020, medical students demonstrated in Nyala (South Darfur state), calling for improvements in studying conditions and the removal of the head of the medicine department at the University of Nyala. [size=no report]

On 17 October 2020, clashes were reported once again in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), killing four and wounding five, amid ethnicised violence between the Beni Amir and Beja groups. At least one civilian was among the wounded. A hospital in the city was also attacked by an unspecified group.
Around 17 October 2020 (as reported), protesters gathered in Khartoum to denounce excessive violence used by security forces against demonstrators in Kassala. [size=no report]

On 18 October 2020, dozens of Eastern Sudanese protesters marched in Khartoum, denouncing killings by state forces in Kassala on October 15. The protesters called for security officials linked to the killings to be dismissed, and for the Prime Minister to provide clear reasons for his dismissal of the governor of Kassala state. [size=dozens]

On 18 October 2020, clashes were reported once again in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), amid ethnicised violence between the Beni Amir and Beja groups. An official has said that nobody was killed during the clashes, though the report does not mention whether there were injuries.
On 19 October 2020, Darfurians demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for the extradition of former President Omar el Bashir to the International Criminal Court. [size=no report]

On 20 October 2020, unionists demonstrated in El Fasher (North Darfur state), in opposition to the appointment of doctors to direct nutrition departments in hospitals, and calling for a greater role for unionists. [size=no report]

On 20 October 2020, unionists demonstrated in Gedaref (Gedaref state), in opposition to the appointment of doctors to direct nutrition departments in hospitals, and calling for a greater role for unionists. [size=no report]

On 20 October 2020, unionists demonstrated in Khartoum, in opposition to the appointment of doctors to direct nutrition departments in hospitals, and calling for a greater role for unionists. [size=no report]

Around 20 October 2020, Fellata pastoralists attacked several Masalit settlements and IDP camps in Gereida locality, including Haddad, Ed Dekka, Donkey Abyad, Um Asal and Um Zagrad. At least 13 were killed (some of whom died later of their injuries) in the attacks which took place on 20 and 21 October, and 28 were wounded. Around 4,850 families were displaced in the attacks, and at least 200 dwellings were torched. Two events coded for 20 and 21 October in Haddad and Gereida, with fatalities spread evenly across both.

column8: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 20 October 2020, demonstrators torched the Saraf Omra HQ of the Rapid Support Forces in Saraf Omra locality (North Darfur state), after RSF were involved in a violent incident in the town market earlier that day. One source implies that the demonstrators are from the Rizeigat ethnic group. An unconfirmed report says that the rioters took an RSF soldier hostage. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
column17: On 20 October 2020, RSF paramilitaries conducting security operations in Saraf Omra market (North Darfur state) clashed with what are described as armed civilians, who are implied to belong to the Rizeigat ethnic group, with the RSF killing 1 and wounding 5. The clash is attributed by one source to tensions among Rizeigat clans.

On 20 October 2020, demonstrators blocked the Khartoum-Atbara highway near Shendi (River Nile state) using logs and vehicles, to demonstrate against the provisions of the Juba Peace Agreement covering Northern Sudan, and calling for the dismissal of the governor of River Nile state. [size=no report]

On 20 October 2020, unionists demonstrated in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state), in opposition to the appointment of doctors to direct nutrition departments in hospitals, and calling for a greater role for unionists. [size=no report]

On 20 October 2020, unionists demonstrated in Singa (Sennar state), in opposition to the appointment of doctors to direct nutrition departments in hospitals, and calling for a greater role for unionists. [size=no report]

column7: SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; Resistance Committees (Sudan); Labour Group (Sudan)
column17: On 21 October 2020, thousands of demonstrators marched in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) in SPA and Resistance Committee-organized protests to commemorate the 1964 October Revolution. The demonstrators called for a correction in the course of the uprising, amid increasing dissatisfaction with the progress made towards reforming political institutions and reversing economic decline. The demonstrators also called for an end to violence in the East of Sudan. [size=thousands]

column7: SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; Resistance Committees (Sudan); Labour Group (Sudan)
column17: On 21 October 2020, thousands of demonstrators marched in Wad Medani (El Gazira state) in SPA and Resistance Committee-organized protests to commemorate the 1964 October Revolution. The demonstrators called for a correction in the course of the uprising, amid increasing dissatisfaction with the progress made towards reforming political institutions and reversing economic decline. [size=thousands]

On 21 October 2020, demonstrators (including a prominent member of the outlawed NCP) marched in Nyala (South Darfur state), in a demonstration which appears to be in opposition to the March of the Millions commemorating the October 1964 revolution. Some demonstrators threw stones at police, leading the police to disperse the demonstrators, and make a number of arrests (including of the senior NCP member). [size=no report]

column7: SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; Resistance Committees (Sudan); Labour Group (Sudan)

[size=hundreds]

The demonstrators called for a correction in the course of the uprising, amid increasing dissatisfaction with the progress made towards reforming political institutions and reversing economic decline. [size=hundreds]

column7: SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; Resistance Committees (Sudan); Labour Group (Sudan); Journalists (Sudan)
column17: On 21 October 2020, thousands of demonstrators marched in Khartoum in SPA and Resistance Committee-organized protests to commemorate the 1964 October Revolution. The demonstrators called for a correction in the course of the uprising, amid increasing dissatisfaction with the progress made towards reforming political institutions and reversing economic decline. Police fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrators, whilst a number journalists covering the protests were assaulted by police. [size=thousands]

column7: SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; Resistance Committees (Sudan); Labour Group (Sudan)
column17: On 21 October 2020, thousands of demonstrators marched in Omdurman in SPA and Resistance Committee-organized protests to commemorate the 1964 October Revolution. The demonstrators called for a correction in the course of the uprising, amid increasing dissatisfaction with the progress made towards reforming political institutions and reversing economic decline. [size=thousands]
On 21 October 2020, dozens of supporters of the outlawed NCP demonstrated in Gedaref (Gedaref state), denouncing the Transitional Government of Sudan. [size=dozens]
On 21 October 2020, dozens of supporters of the outlawed NCP demonstrated in Kadugli (South Kordofan state), denouncing the Transitional Government of Sudan. [size=dozens]

Around 21 October 2020, Fellata pastoralists attacked several Masalit settlements and IDP camps in Gereida locality, including Haddad, Ed Dekka, Donkey Abyad, Um Asal and Um Zagrad. At least 13 were killed (some of whom died later of their injuries) in the attacks which took place on 20 and 21 October, and 28 were wounded. Around 4,850 families were displaced in the attacks, and at least 200 dwellings were torched. Two events coded for 20 and 21 October in Haddad and Gereida, with fatalities spread evenly across both.
On 21 October 2020, three men in military uniforms (and coded as SAF, pending further information) abducted a farmer near Disa in Kutum locality (North Darfur state).

column7: SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; Resistance Committees (Sudan); Labour Group (Sudan)

[size=thousands]

The demonstrators called for a correction in the course of the uprising, amid increasing dissatisfaction with the progress made towards reforming political institutions and reversing economic decline. [size=thousands]

column7: SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; Resistance Committees (Sudan); Labour Group (Sudan)
column17: On 21 October 2020, thousands of demonstrators marched in Khartoum North in SPA and Resistance Committee-organized protests to commemorate the 1964 October Revolution. The demonstrators called for a correction in the course of the uprising, amid increasing dissatisfaction with the progress made towards reforming political institutions and reversing economic decline. Police fired large amounts of tear gas and used live rounds against the demonstrators, killing 1 and wounding 14 (4 of whom had been shot). [size=thousands]

column7: SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; Resistance Committees (Sudan); Labour Group (Sudan)
column17: On 21 October 2020, thousands of demonstrators marched in Atbara (River Nile state) in SPA and Resistance Committee-organized protests to commemorate the 1964 October Revolution. The demonstrators called for a correction in the course of the uprising, amid increasing dissatisfaction with the progress made towards reforming political institutions and reversing economic decline. [size=thousands]

On 22 October 2020, 50 gunmen on camel and horseback attacked the village of Sabrelwagiha (described as being 30km south of Gereida; coordinates for Haddad used at GP2), killing 2. There has been intense violence involving attacks by Fellata pastoralists against Masalit civilians in the area this past week, and this event is presumed to involve the same actors.

column7: SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; Resistance Committees (Sudan); Labour Group (Sudan)
column17: On 22 October 2020, demonstrators (backed by the SPA and Resistance Committees) blocked a bridge connecting Khartoum with Khartoum North with barricades, and began a sit-in demonstration. The demonstrators are calling for justice following police attacks on demonstrators on 21 October. [size=no report]

On 23 October 2020, demonstrators gathered in several areas of Khartoum to denounce efforts by the executive to normalize relations with Israel. Some demonstrators burned Israeli flags. [size=no report]

column17: Police block group of women demonstrators
