After protests, during the night police entered dorm rooms, arrested students, and used tear gas on one person.
Student rioters and police clashed after police raided the campus in previous days.
A sports journalist was attacked by sports fans.
Police broke up a rally in commemoration of Mandela. From report: ""police used force to lock the mourners inside after the mourners asked the police to show documentation of such an order.""
2,000 people held a protest to ""demonstrate against tyranny"" and in honor of ""late pro-democracy political activist Bongani Dlamini .""

column16: Swaziland Media Commentary; Media Institute of Southern Africa
column17: Police reportedly beat & detained ~100 students at Mbabane Central High School who were protesting against the school's decision to suspend sporting activities.

Security Measures: In order to thwart a potential protest, police set up barricades around Manzini and abducted prodemocracy leaders. Police then drove the abductees 30 kilometers away and left them on the road.

Swaziland Youth Congress held a protest outside the court and blocked police vehicles peacefully. Police intervened, arresting the youth leader, activists, and several other political party members. Protests were held over the arrest of two journalists in March.
Police intervened on a May Day rally organised by PUDEMO and SWAYOCO. Police arrested PUDEMO leader Mario Masuku.

column7: SAPWU: Swaziland Agricultural Plantations Workers' Union
column17: Over 2 000 workers at Ubombo Sugar strike demanding salary increments. On the third day many of the strikers were armed and riot police were called.

column7: SAPWU: Swaziland Agricultural Plantations Workers' Union
column17: Over 2 000 workers at Ubombo Sugar strike demanding salary increments. On the third day many of the strikers were armed and riot police were called.

column7: SAPWU: Swaziland Agricultural Plantations Workers' Union
column17: Over 2 000 workers at Ubombo Sugar strike demanding salary increments. On the third day many of the strikers were armed and riot police were called.

column7: SAPAWU: Swaziland Agricultural Plantations and Allied Workers Union
column17: Police fired teargas and water at demonstrating workers at Ubombo Sugar plant, led by SAPAWU, who were calling pay increases. A newspaper owned by the king blamed the workers for the violence, but a workers' leader said peaceful negotiations were taking place when the police attacked.
A police officer attacked by soldiers along the main street in Pigg's Peak. The incident happened on Saturday before 10pm near KFC in full view of the public.
Security Measures: Police have banned marches by trade unionists against the governments banning of unions.

column9: TUCOSWA: Trade Union Congress of Swaziland; SNAT: Swaziland National Association of Teachers
column17: Police broke up a meeting of the Trade Union Congress of Swaziland held at the Swaziland National Association of Teachers (SNAT) Center in Manzini, and assaulted SNAT secretary general Muzi Mhlang.
Soldiers beat women at an informal crossing point between Swaziland and South Africa.
Student rioters attack journalists with fists and stones and vandalise the journalists equipment and vehicles.
University students protest increased book fees.
Soldiers shoot and kill a suspected smuggler who refused to stop at a road check in Mshololo near Nhlangano.
Soldiers shoot and kill a man who refused to stop at a road check in Gege.
Soldiers ambush a truck and killed one civilian in Dwalile area of Mankayane.
Public sector workers protest, demanding the release of the salary review report.

column7: SNAT: Swaziland National Association of Teachers
column16: Swaziland Media Commentary; Times of Swaziland
column17: 300 members of teachers association rioted and blocked roads with stones and clashed with police to demand the release of the government salary review report. 2 were arrested the following day at their homes.
Supporters of Communist Party of Swaziland riot and set fire to buildings in Siphofeni in protest against feudal rule by King Mswati III. Police arrest 4 at the scene.
Albinos protested for more protection from people hunting them to use their body parts for witchcraft.

column7: MWUS: Media Workers Union of Swaziland; Journalists (eSwatini)
column17: Members of the Media Workers Union of Swaziland have been gathered at the offices of the Swazi Observer to protest low wages, intimidation, and poor working conditions. The High Court has banned an official protest.
Striking plantation workers in Swaziland (around Piggss Peak) were reportedly violently assaulted by police.

Police fired gunshots at protesting students at the university in Swaziland in Mbabane that is set to house King Mswati IIIs proposed SADC University of Transformation. At least four students had serious injuries

column7: SNAT: Swaziland National Association of Teachers
column17: A Swaziland policeman broke his baton as he attempted to prevent schoolteachers from passing through during a peaceful protest march. No reported injury.

Thousands of people marched through the streets of Mbabane on 8 September 2017 to deliver a petition which calls for democracy and socioeconomic justice to the country's Cabinet. The Swaziland United Democratic Front organised the march.
Students at the Swaziland College of Technology (SCOT) vandalised property in protest.
Swazi students marched in protest and at least 11 were arrested for damaging property and causing a disturbance. Police allegedy fired at the students

Armed police in Swaziland fired rubber bullets and arrested eight students when they put a rubbish skip in the middle of a road during a protest. It happened at Limkokwing University, Mbabane. Students were protesting about poor wi-fi internet connections. It was part of a continuing protest against poor teaching and facilities.

column7: TUCOSWA: Trade Union Congress of Swaziland
column17: On 29 June, protesters took to the streets in Mbabane with assistance from Trade Union Congress of Swaziland (TUCOSWA) against government policies and corruption. Police responded with violence leaving 2 people injured.
On 22 August, in Mbabane nurses were tasered when they were protesting. They were protesting at the Swazi government's decision to offer a zero increase in their salary cost of living adjustment.

On 24 August, police shot and wounded a schoolteacher during a march in Manzini, Swaziland. They were protesting at the Swazi government's decision to offer a zero increase in their salary cost of living adjustment.

On 30 August, more than 200 paramilitary police and correctional facility warders with riot shields, helmets and batons guarded the entrance to Juris, one of the major factories, where workers protested. Swaziland police fired several gunshot blasts while textile workers, mostly women, protested about poor pay and dispersed them with batons.
On 28 September, a Swaziland journalist was assaulted by marchers as he took photographs at a teachers' protest in Mbabane. He sustained injuries on the face and body.

18 February. Rioting pupil from Nkiliji High School forced teachers to lock themselves in their storerooms. The pupil also threw stones at some of the teachers and damaged property. The police intervened to calm the situation. The riot came after the principal announced that all sporting activities will be banned. [size=no report]
03 May. Thousands of residents from Manzini demonstrated, demanding political reform in eSwatini. Political parties have been banned since 1973. [size=3000].

15 May (on or around). Demonstration action have been reported at the Mhubhe High School, Ngulwini. The students accused teachers of sexual assault. Police used rubber bullets and teargas to disperse the students. Six students have been arrested for theft and property destruction. [size=no report].
18 May. Hundreds of demonstrators marched in Malkerns in response to forced evictions planned by King Mswati III. [size=100].

24 May. Students from the Mhubhe High School, Ngulwini, demonstrated at the school, demanding that two of their suspended teachers to be reinstated. The teachers were suspended from absenteeism. One of the teachers were the president of the Swaziland National Association of Teachers (SNAT) and the other a union activist. The SNAT have accused the Ministry of Education for attacking the union. [size=no report].
On 22 June 2019, around 200 people marched in Mbabane (Mbabane East, Hhohho) for LGBTQ equality and acceptance. [size=around 200]

08 July. A young woman has been shot with a stray bullet at Mavuso Trade Centre, Manzini during a concert where attendees started throwing bottles on the stage and vandalized property after the lights went off during the concert. Police were called to the scene and used rubber bullets and teargas canisters to disperse the crowds. The young woman was taken to hospital. [size=no report].

15 July. Students from Dvokolwako High School demonstrated at the school. The demonstrators accused one of the teachers of using witchcraft. The demonstrators blocked the road near the school with a burning car, pelted police vehicles with stones and broke furniture at the school. Police fired a water cannon, stun grenades, and rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. [size=no report].

column7: Labour Group (eSwatini); COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; TUCOSWA: Trade Union Congress of Swaziland; PUDEMO: Peoples United Democratic Movement; SSN: Swaziland Solidarity Network
column17: 26 July. Members from various organizations demonstrated at Golela / Lavumisa at the Swaziland and South Africa border, demanding the isolation of King Mswati III and for a democratic election process. The demonstration was led by the Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU), the Trade Union Congress of Swaziland (TUCOSWA), the People's United Democratic Movement (TUCOSWA) and the Swaziland Solidarity Network (SSN). [size=no report].

column7: WLSA: Women and Law in Southern Africa; CSC: Council of Swaziland Churches; SWAGAA: Swaziland Action Group Against Abuse; World Vision; SNAT: Swaziland National Association of Teachers; TUCOSWA: Trade Union Congress of Swaziland; SNUS: Swaziland National Union of Students; SRWA: Swaziland Rural Womens Association; CIEAS: SOS Childrens Village and Coalition of Informal Economy Associations of Swaziland (CIEAS); Labour Group (eSwatini); Students (eSwatini); Aid Workers (eSwatini); Christian Group (eSwatini)
column17: 10 August (on or around). Women and Law in Southern Africa (WLSA), Council of Swaziland Churches (CSC), Swaziland Action Group Against Abuse (SWAGAA), World Vision, Kwakha Indvodza (KI), Swaziland National Association of Teachers (SNAT), Trade Union Congress of Swaziland (TUCOSWA), Swaziland Union of Students (SNUS), Swaziland Rural Women's Assembly (SRWA), SOS Children's Village and Coalition of Informal Economy Associations of Swaziland (CIEAS) marched through Manzini, to raise awareness on the killings of women and children in eSwatini. [size=no report].

15 August. Students marched to the Ministry of Labour and Social Security, Mbabane, to deliver a petition, demanding the payment of allowances and scholarships. Students and police clashed, police have reported to hit students with batons. Seven students have been detained. Three have been injured. [size=no report].
27 August. Ongoing student demonstrations across three campuses at the University of eSwatini have been reported. The students are demanding scholarships. [size=no report].
23 September. 3500 Demonstrators marched in Mbabane against the misuse of public funds by King Mswati III. [size=3500].
23 September. Demonstrators marched in Manzini against the misuse of public funds by King Mswati III. [size=3500].

25 September. Violent clashes between the police and demonstrators have been reported in Mbabane. Teachers from across Eswatini demonstrated in the capital, accusing King Mswati III of misusing public finds. Police fired teargas, stun grenades and water canons to disperse the crowds. Demonstrators have reportedly pelted rocks at the police. [size=3000].

27 September. Police fired teargas into a classroom to disperse demonstrating taxi workers in Malkerns who hid from the police. The demonstrators were carrying stones and bottles. The demonstration was in response to the continued arrest of taxi drivers for traffic offences. [size=no report].

column7: Teachers (eSwatini); SNAT: Swaziland National Association of Teachers; Labour Group (eSwatini); NAPSAWU: National Association of Public Service and Allied Workers Union; SNAGAP: Swaziland National Government Accounting Personnel
column17: 02 October. Teachers and government workers, led by the Swaziland National Association of Teachers (SNAT), National Association of Public Service and Allied Workers Union (NAPSAW) and Swaziland National Government Accounting Personnel (SNAGAP), demonstrated in Manzini, demanding better salaries and lower living costs. The demonstrators pelted stones at police. Police used water cannons, tear gas and rubber bullets at the crowd. Ten demonstrators and three police officers have been injured. Two demonstrators have been arrested for public violence. [size=no report].

01 November 2019. Students demonstrated at the Southern African Nazarene University (SANU), Manzini, protested their allowances not being paid since August. School property has been damaged and forced non-demonstrating students out of classes. One demonstrator has been injured by a non-demonstrating student. [size=no report].
04 November 2019. Students from the University of eSswatini, at the Kwaluseni campus, demonstrated at the university on the 4th and 5th, demanding the payment of their allowances. [size=no report].
04 November 2019. Students from the University of Eswatini, at the Luyengo campus, demonstrated at the university, demanding the payment of their allowances. [size=no report].
04 November 2019. Students demonstrated at the Southern Africa Nazarene University (SANU) in Manzini over delayed allowance payments. [size=no report].
05 November 2019. Students from the University of Eswatini, at the Kwaluseni campus, demonstrated at the university on the 4th and 5th, demanding the payment of their allowances. [size=no report].

05 November 2019. Students demonstrated at the Southern Africa Nazarene University (SANU) in Manzini over delayed book, practical and monthly allowances payments. Students barricaded roads with logs and concrete blocks and threw stones at police. Police fired rubber bullets, injuring one student. [size=no report].
06 November 2019 (on or around). In two separate incidents, two women were beaten and assaulted by members of the defence force at the Nsubane army camp (nearest location found, Siteki).
06 November 2019 (on or around). In two separate incidents, two women were beaten and assaulted by members of the defence force at the Nsubane army camp (nearest location found, Siteki).

column7: TUCOSWA: Trade Union Congress of Swaziland; Labour Group (eSwatini)
column17: 07 November 2019. Public service workers, led by TUCOSWA, demonstrated in Mbabane, demanding higher salaries after the King ordered luxury vehicles. The workers are accusing the king of draining public funds. [size=700].

column7: SWADEPA: Swazi Democratic Party; NNLC: Ngwane National Liberatory Congress; PUDEMO: Peoples United Democratic Movement
column17: On 12 December 2019, three members of SWADEPA, NNLC, and PUDEMO were arrested during a march in Matsapha. The march was ruled by the court as being illegal. [size=no report].

On 24 December 2019, a mob stabbed and stoned two brothers after one of the brothers assaulted and later threatened a man of the community in Letindze, KaNkonjwa (location not found, Lubombo chosen as a location). [size=20].

As reported on 09 February 2020, a man accused police of torture after he was arrested and taken to Siteki police station in Siteki (Lugongolweni, Lubombo). The victim said that police placed a plastic bag over his head and hit him followed by taking him to a nearby forest and threw him into a fire. The man managed to crawl out of the fire.
On or around 5 March 2020, demonstrators, mostly women, gathered at the Manzini court (Manzini North, Manzini), against the bail hearing of a man accused of murdering a businessman. [size=no report]
On 11 March 2020, students demonstrated at the KaMkhweli High School in Siphofaneni (Siphofaneni, Lubombo), demanding more teachers. [size=no report]
On 12 March 2020, a journalist accused police of arresting and torturing him in Manzini (Manzini North, Manzini) after he published an article criticising the king.
Around 15 March 2020 (month of), a journalist was arrested and tortured by Swazi police for an alleged act of sedition in Mbabane (Mbabane East, Hhohho). He later fled to South Africa.

column7: SWADNU: Swaziland Democratic Nurses Union; Health Workers (eSwatini)
column16: Swaziland Media Commentary; Times of Swaziland
column17: On 17 March 2020, nurses, led by the SWADNU marched to the Swazi Ministry of Health in Mbabane (Mbabane East, Hhohho) to hand over a petition, demanding protective clothes and equipment to treat patients with coronavirus. [size=no report]

On 20 March 2020, nurses demonstrated in Manzini (Manzini North, Manzini), demanding management of the facility to involve them in the planning process for taking care of coronavirus patients. [size=no report]
On 10 April 2020, police officers took a wife of an eSwatini journalist, who fled the country to South Africa, and tortured her in Mbabane (Mbababe East, Hhohho).
On 10 April 2020, 2 women were assaulted by eSwatini police officers in Mhlatane (Mankayane, Manzini) for not staying at home during the partial Coronavirus lockdown.

On 12 April 2020, a lawyer was run over by his own car while allegedly being assaulted by armed members of the eSwatini military in Mbabane (Mbababe East, Hhihho). The reason for the attack was that the soldiers were enforcing Coronavirus regulations.

On 23 April 2020, a journalist sustained head injuries after he was assaulted by eSwatini police officers, who came to his home and detained him in Nhlangano (Maseyisinj, Shiselweni). His arrest is allegedly related to critical articles he published about King Mswati.
Around 11 May 2020, several people have been assaulted by police officers for allegedly not respecting the Coronavirus lockdown in Mbabane (Mbababe East, Hhohho). No fatalities reported.

Around 2 June 2020 (as reported), a police officer allegedly fired his weapon upon spectators, who were watching young boys that were playing football during the Coronavirus lockdown, near Gege (Shiselweni). The 15 year old boy was injured while others trampled on each other.
On 3 June 2020, nurses burned tyres at the entrance of the hospital in Sithobela Health Center (Lubombo) demanding the removal of the hospital administrator. [size=no report]

On 18 June 2020, nurses staged a demonstration in the Siteki Public Health Unit in Siteki (Lubombo). Police were called to intervene. The demonstration was prompted by the return of a senior staff member, whom they no longer want as their supervisor, after she recovered from coronavirus. [size=no report]

On 16 July 2020, a government assistant accountant was tortured and injured by police officers in Nhlangano (Shiselweni) during a fraud investigation. The victim was beaten and had a plastic bag put over his head inside the police station.

Around 29 July 2020 (as reported), a man was beaten with sticks and injured by a mob in Ludlawini near Ndzingeni (Piggs Peak, Hhohho) after he threatened to rape a girl. He was arrested. Police intervened and took the man to the police station. [size=no report]

On 1 August 2020, a woman was stripped half-naked and insulted by a police officer in Murray Camp, outside the city of Manzini (Manzini North, Manzini) during an attack by police officers against a group of people for not obeying coronavirus-related rules. The group were beaten and detained, and one officer tried to shoot the woman.

Around 4 August 2020 (as reported), a man was shot and killed by police near the Sidwashini neighborhood, Mbabane (Mbabane East, Hhohho) after the man tried to prevent the officers from chasing a suspect accused of rape.

On 8 August 2020, congregants from various churches were beaten by 10 police officers, who also used tear gas in Siteki (Lugongolweni, Lubombo) for allegedly disobeying coronavirus related rules. According to the pastor organizing the event, the prayer would happen in an open area, with less than 100 people, as required. No reports on injuries.

On 15 August 2020, unidentified individuals opened fire against the house of the KoNtshingila Iduva in the Shiselweni Region. No one was injured. The attempt was allegedly motivated by the ongoing chieftaincy dispute at KoNtshingila; the Iduva was arrested on the following days, suspect in a homicide attempt against 3 people on the same day.

On 25 August 2020, bus operators halted activities and barricaded a bus rank in Manzini (Manzini North, Manzini). The action came amid confusion over how buses would operate as coronavirus measures started to be eased; some want the return of operations as before, while others support restrictions. [size=no report]

On 7 September 2020, 2 men ( a former police officer and a community police member) were shot and killed, and another was shot and injured during a clash with a former Cabinet Minister and Public Works and Transport Minister in the Mhlabubovu's Traffic Circle, that leads to Mankayane (Ngwempisi, Manzini). The event was motivated by a longstanding boundary dispute between LaMgabhi and Luyengweni chiefdoms. Both of the men who were shot dead by the former minister, are reportedly from Luyengweni and were part of a group that was travelling with the chiefdom's inner council (bandlancane), allocating land at Mhlabubovu to certain individuals

On 24 September 2020, a group set tires on fire in Eteni (Manzini North, Manzini) on the Manzini-Mbabane Highway. The police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the group, who were demonstrating against being forced to pay fines for jaywalking while a broken pedestrian bridge was left unrepaired in the area. [size=no report]
Opposition march broken up by police, many injuries reported
Ongoing student riots over conditions at University
Ongoing student riots over conditions at University
Police block student protesters

column7: MEET: Movement for the Advancement of Togolese Students
column17: Student rioters clash with police
Rioters clash with police following peaceful protest march

column7: ANC: National Alliance for Change Political Party
column17: Protest against proposed amendment to constitution
Togolese journalists take to streets to protest threats against colleagues
Fighting between two clans of the Baasare tribe

column7: ANC: National Alliance for Change Political Party
column17: Opposition supporters rally over ANC parliamentarians who had been ejected from legislature

column7: ANC: National Alliance for Change Political Party
column17: Opposition supporters rally over ANC parliamentarians who had been ejected from legislature
Students gather to protest financial aid policy; property destroyed during protest
Students gather to protest financial aid policy
Groups form to launch an anti-government protest on the occasion of Togos 52nd Independence Day.
Togolese police attacked and confiscated the equipment of two journalists filming an anti-government march in the capital, Lome. The police were later disciplined.

column7: UFC: Union of Forces for Change
column17: A major opposition political party protests upcoming elections, threatens boycott if demands of fixing irregularities are not met.
Togolese opposition parties gather in protest of a new passes by parliament, believing it favors the majority political party.

Togolese security forces shot canisters of tear gas in an attempt to disperse thousands of angry opposition supporters and anti-government protesters who demonstrated Tuesday in this capital city against a new electoral law. The clash lasted three hours many of the protesters threw stones at police. Many street battles were reported throughout the city.

Violent clashes between security forces and protesters erupted Wednesday in the Togolese capital for the second day, Lome as the police attempted to disperse a demonstration staged by activists of the organization known as Let's Save Togo. The opposition claimed there were 119 protesters injured, though the government disputes this.
Police and opposition parties clash for the third day in Loma. Over the past days 22 security officials reported injuries, 17 demonstrators.
Arrests: Authorities in Togo have detained three protest leaders and 53 others over demonstrations in recent days that were dispersed with tear gas.

Arrests: Togolese authorities on Tuesday detained former prime minister and opposition figure Agbeyome Kodjo in the wake of protests last week, a coalition of opposition parties and civil society groups said. The two men were not held in custody for an extended time. LST vows further protests.

Several thousand gather, mostly of LST, before an upcoming poll. The group was demonstrating their inability to demonstrate in a certain area of the city, which is reserved to commercial activity. Police forces broke up the protest by firing tear gas at the group.

Police clash with LST protesters for a second day. LST descend in to riot, throw rocks at police, burn tires in retaliation. Police eventually disperse the group with tear gas. More than 100 people were wounded and 125 others arrested during the demonstrations.
Thousands of opposition supporters marched through Lome on Saturday but faced no resistance from security services, after two days of rallies earlier this week when protesters and officers clashed.

Togolese security forces fired tear gas to disperse the latest in a string of protests demanding electoral reforms ahead of parliamentary polls expected in October. Many of the protesters retaliate in protest.

column6: RPT: Rally of the Togolese People
column17: A violent mob, carrying sticks and machetes, intimidates an opposition group from protesting in the capital. It is reported the police looked on but did nothing to stop the group. Injuries reported. It is probable the mob were either members of, or hired by the ruling party, Rally of the Togolese People (RPT).

column7: LST: Lets Save Togo Coalition; Women (Togo)
column17: The women's wing of the Lets Save Togo group gathered in the capital to demand ""sweeping political reform."" Broadly, the groups wants President Faure Gnassingbe to resign. The group, numbering in the thousands, wore red to demonstrate an unarticulated political statement.

Protesters of the Lets Save Togo group begin a three day protest, calling on President Faure Gnassingbe to resign. Faure Gnassingbe was appointed by the military after his fathers death, and has since won two elections, though LST disputed the validity of these elections.
Day two of the LST protest.
Day three of the LST protests.
Violence inflicted by security forces upon a journalist while covering a protest march organized by two opposition groups, the ""Collectif Sauvons le Togo"" and ""Mouvement Arc-en ciel""

An unauthorized protest by the Collectif Sauvons le Togo (CST) turned into a riot as police attempted to disperse the crowd and a crossfire of projectiles from rioters and tear gas from police officers occurred. The protest was organized as a three-day sit-in advocating electoral reform. Around 23 people, including 3 journalists, were injured and 18 were arrested.
A fire in the market of Kara occurred. The government declared the fire a criminal act, and investigations are underway to search for the arsonist.
Protests by Collectif Sauvons le Togo (CST) continued, demonstrating for electoral and constitutional reform.
Protests by Collectif Sauvons le Togo (CST) continued. The protests were part of a three-day activist event called ""les derniers tours de Jericho.""
A fire occurred in Adawlato, the largest market of Lome. Authorities declared the fire a criminal act, potentially targeting the President, who was due to appear at the market.

Arrests: Togolese authorities on Wednesday detained opposition leader and former President of the National Assembly Agbeyome Kodjo for questioning over two major fires at markets that the government has named criminal acts. Fires caused significant damage but no injury in two markets. A former Prime Minister of Togo and three other members of the opposition (CST) were also taken in for questioning (they were later arrested, along with 12 others).

Protests took place to demonstrate against arrests of opposition party leaders suspected of involvement in recent market fires. A women's collective (Collectif des femmes pour une conscience civique) also demonstrated for the government to provide compensation for damages from the fire.
Police dispersed a protest.
Refugees protest and prevent arrival of Ivorian ambassador
Tensions in the Avepozo camp of Ivorian refugees, about twenty kilometers from Lome. More security forces were sent on Wednesday, April 3rd, and one person was arrested for disturbing public order

Thousands of opposition supporters took the streets of Togos capital to celebrate the first anniversary of the Collective ""Save the Togo"" (CST) that consists of seven organizations defending human rights, three civil society organizations civil and five political parties.
More than 20,000 children from primary, secondary and college protested in the streets of Lome, in support of their teachers strike asking for better working conditions.
More than 20,000 children from primary, secondary and college protested in the streets of Lome, in support of their teachers strike asking for better working conditions
Several thousand students protestedThursday and Friday in the streets of Lome to request the resumption of classes and urge the government to meet the demands of teachers

The protest of civil servants took a tragic turn, Monday, April 15, with the death of a 12 year old student shot and killed during a demonstration in the north of the country while a member of the security forces was wounded. Another student died from his injuries.
Peaceful protest of civil servants of the prison administration about their working conditions.
Peaceful protest for May 1st
Tensions in the Avepozo camp of Ivorian refugees, about twenty kilometers from Lome.
Violent intervention of the police forces shooting grenades beating refugees up, and setting fire to some tents.
Violent riot by the population after a philosophy teacher got arrested by the police forces the day before. The police station has been destroyed
Students from the Lome University protested against the delay in the grants allocation. They blocked a few streets before the police intervention with tear gas. The campus has been closed for 3days
Peacefull protest against the death of a political opponent to the regime, in jail.
Peacefull protest of women from the opposition party, against the death of a political opponent to the regime, in jail.
Clashes between police forces and rioters after the opposition protest has been suspended by the government
The police forces stopped the protest before the protesters could gather in the main street
Victims of the fire at the Adawlato market, Lome, staged a sit-in to demand relocation to a more secure location and compensation.

Authorities in Togo have shut down a radio station that aired reports of fraud as the country held a parliamentary election Thursday, the opposition said, sparking a protest by several hundred youths. There were no incidents of violence.
Clashes took place between two rival Muslim groups in Ketao on August 9th resulting in 13 injuries, destruction of 20 houses, shops, cars, etc. The security forces intervened to restore calm.

column7: USET: Trade Union of Teachers of Togo
column17: The Trade Union of Teachers of Togo (USET) has implemented its threat to strike on Thursday and Friday in Lome, Atakpame, Vogan, Tabligbo and Aneho over issues of pay.

column7: USET: Trade Union of Teachers of Togo
column17: The Trade Union of Teachers of Togo (USET) has implemented its threat to strike on Thursday and Friday in Lome, Atakpame, Vogan, Tabligbo and Aneho over issues of pay.

column17: The Trade Union of Teachers of Togo (USET) has implemented its threat to strike on Thursday and Friday in Lome, Atakpame, Vogan, Tabligbo and Aneho over issues of pay.

column7: ANC: National Alliance for Change Political Party; Women (Togo)
column17: Thousands of women of the National Alliance for Change (ANC) marched in the streets of Lome demanding the release of those still detained regarding the case of the market fires of Kara and Lome. Jean-Pierre Fabre (ANC), Aime Gogue (ADDI: Alliance of Democrats for Integral Development) and Claude Ameganvi (Workers Party) took part in the march alongside the women.

column7: USET: Trade Union of Teachers of Togo
column17: The Trade Union of Teachers of Togo (USET) has implemented its threat to strike on Thursday and Friday in Lome, Atakpame, Vogan, Tabligbo and Aneho over issues of pay.

column7: USET: Trade Union of Teachers of Togo
column17: The Trade Union of Teachers of Togo (USET) has implemented its threat to strike on Thursday and Friday in Lome, Atakpame, Vogan, Tabligbo and Aneho over issues of pay.

School students affected by the teachers strike of the previous week rallied students from unaffected schools and they protested against the disruption in education. Reports of violent demonstrations.

Villagers of Borgou discovered the body of a farmer in a field, killed by pastoralists. This sparked clashes between the villagers and pastoralists on the 22nd and 23rd December, resulting in six deaths.

Villagers of Borgou discovered the body of a farmer in a field, killed by pastoralists. This sparked clashes between the villagers and pastoralists on the 22nd and 23rd December, resulting in six deaths.
Strike:Employees of SNPT at Dagbati and Kpogame strike against poor living conditions, working conditions, and payment of below minimum wage.
Strike:Employees of SNPT at Dagbati and Kpogame strike against poor living conditions, working conditions, and payment of below minimum wage.
Strike:Employees of SNPT at Dagbati and Kpogame strike against poor living conditions, working conditions, and payment of below minimum wage.

column7: ANC: National Alliance for Change Political Party
column17: Supporters and sympathizers of the National Alliance for Change (ANC) of the Agoe area held a march on 4th January 2014 in the neighbourhood to raise awareness and demand rule of law for all.
A trainee journalist at Focus Info suffered attacks by several policemen and gendarmerie who did not want him to take pictures and interview people. The policemen have since been arrested.

column7: APDHDS: Association for the Protection of Human Rights and Social Development
column17: The village leaders of Avevoin, Loome and Yometchin were beaten over a land dispute involving the Chief of Staff of the Togolese Armed Forces (FAT)

column16: Telegramme228; Media Foundation for West Africa
column17: A student protest on the Lome university campus was dispersed after clashes with police through the use of tear gas; 12 students were arrested and 19 students injured, along with some security personnel
Students demonstrated for the release of colleagues arrested at protests the previous day; four more demonstrators were arrested
Thousands of Togolese workers took part in a ""peaceful protest march"" to express their frustration at the latest failure of the government and central union to come to an agreement
Human rights activists across West Africa held protests on the 20th anniversary of President Yahya Jammehs seizure of power in Gambia to raise awareness of Gambias human rights situation.

column7: LST: Lets Save Togo Coalition; Coalition Arc-en-ciel
column17: Waves of protests in Lome (specific dates unavailable) in lead up to 2015 presidential elections. Reports of police spraying tear gas to disperse crowds. Protests connected with opposition groups Lets Save Togo Coalition and Coalition Arc-en-ciel, which continue to push for a constitutional amendment imposing a two-term limit (to prevent President Gnassingbe from running again).

column7: ANC: National Alliance for Change Political Party; UPR: Union for the Republic
column17: Opposition parties riot to demand presentiational term limits and two-round voting leading up to 2015 elections. Government supporters were also present. When protesters deviated from planned route towards the sea, thousands were stopped by the Gendarmerie and prevented from reaching Parliament. Rioters threw stones, barricaded streets and burned tires. Gendarmie used tear gas. Two injuries reported.

Several thousand protest in Lome to demand presidential term limits to prevent President Gnassingbe from running for a third term in 2015. Protesters gathered at the Dove of Peace and marched to Hanoukope district.
Thousands protest to demand constitutional reforms, presidential term limits, and presidential vote in two rounds.
Thousands protest to demand constitutional reforms, presidential term limits, and presidential vote in two rounds.
Thousands protest to demand constitutional reforms, presidential term limits, and presidential vote in two rounds.
Thousands protest to demand constitutional reforms, presidential term limits, and presidential vote in two rounds.
Dozens of reporters gathered at the French Embassy in Lome to protest against militant attacks that took place at Charlie Hebdo magazine in Paris.
Students protested in Lome after repeated strikes by teachers, demanding the resumption of classes and urging authorities to meet the demands of educators.

Protests outside the Independent National Election Commission aimed at disrupting the presidential electoral process scheduled to take place April 15, 2015. Police dispersed the crowd using water cannons.

A militia armed with machetes and clubs attacked teachers and health workers at a meeting of the Synergy Workers of Togo/Coalition of Togolese Workers in Dapaong, 600km north of Lome. Several injuries reported.
Protests in Vogan in support of teachers.
Rioters (many students) ransacked the prefecture in Dapaong to protest against the militia violence against teachers and health workers that occurred on Mar. 15.
Protests in Badou support of teachers.
Protests in Bassar in support of teachers.
Protests in Kpalime in support of teachers.

Hundreds of people - many students - gathered in Glei, 200km from Lome, in support of the teachers strike. Rioters erected barricades along the highway and threw rocks at police. Police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd and fired warning shots. 43 people injured, including 20 members of security. 19 arrested. Soldiers later arrived on scene.
Thousands in Lome protested the April 25 election results that saw President Gnassingbe win a third term. Opposition leader Jean-Pierre Fabre declared fraud and stated that he won the elections.
50 journalists staged a sit-in near police headquarters in Lome demanding the release of a colleague held on suspicion of defaming the security minister.

Rioters in Mango protest a project for the protection of wildlife because they want the land to be used for agriculture. Rioters lit tyres, threw stones at police and stole weapons. 5 killed, 13 injured, 50 arrested.
Protests in Lome against a wildlife project in Mango.
Protests against a wildlife project in Mango, as protesters refused to remove bodies of rioters killed the previous day.
Women protest in the streets of Mango, demanding the return of children arrested in previous riots. Police fire tear gas.
Rioters threw rocks at police in protest of being relocated from a nature reserve. Police fired tear gas. One police commissioner lynched by rioters.
After a police officer was lynched by rioters on Nov 26, police and an elite army unit fired on and beat civilians in their homes, killing 2 and injuring 87. 60 arrested.
Students protest against lack of electricity on campus.

On second day of strike for better working conditions at University of Lome, students gathered to protest on campus. Police fired tear gas and clashed with students, leaving five students and three members of the security forces injured. 9 arrested.
On February 15, suspected Fulani gunmen killed a woman of the Tem community in the village of Tchalo.

On February 16, residents in Tchalo from the Tem community barricaded roads and burned tires in reaction to the killing of a woman by suspected Fulani gunmen, the demonstrators attempted to take to the bush in order to retaliate against the Fulani community, although security forces intervened to protect the Fulani and prevent further escalation. [size=no report]

On February 24, four people were killed and livestock butchered amidst intercommunal violence between Fulani pastoralists and agriculturalists near the villages of Ayakope and Doglobo (coded as Amakpave at geoprecision 2).
Clashes between rioters and police in Mango, linked to preparation of indpendence day celebrations. 3 wounded.

column7: ANC: National Alliance for Change Political Party
column17: The Togolese opposition staged a peaceful demonstration in the capital, Lome, on 21 May to call for constitutional reform and the organization of local elections.

Police in June arrested and beat a man in detention in Guerin Kouka over alleged theft. He was released without charge after three days and filed a complaint with the tribunal of Guerin Kouka. No investigation was known to have been initiated at the end of the year.
Security forces used tear gas, batons and live ammunition to disperse a protest against lack of compensation over land evictions in Abobo near Lome in August, leaving at least ten protesters injured.

Student rioters threw rocks at fellow students attending their classes in a private school. The student rioters were reacting to a strike action led by their teachers who has led to the disruption of classes in the public sector.
Unknown gunmen shot and killed 11 Ghanaians returning home from Nigeria along the border with Benin over unclear reasons.

On February 12, seventeen people were killed amidst intercommunal violence between Burkinabe Fulani pastoralists and indigenous Togolese in northern Togo (coded as Dapaong at geoprecision 3), the clashes erupted in reaction to the killing of three people during an armed robbery where the perpetrators were suspected of being Fulani.

Hundreds of protesters including journalists and civil society and political representatives staged peaceful marches over three days in Lome again the recent suspension of two major radio stations by authorities. The march was interrupted by police officers before reaching the audio-visual and communication authority. The protesters threatened of bigger mobilisations the following week should the stations not be reopened.

Hundreds of protesters including journalists and civil society and political representatives staged peaceful marches over three days in Lome again the recent suspension of two major radio stations by authorities. The march was interrupted by police officers before reaching the audio-visual and communication authority. The protesters threatened of bigger mobilisations the following week should the stations not be reopened.

Hundreds of protesters including journalists and civil society and political representatives staged peaceful marches over three days in Lome again the recent suspension of two major radio stations by authorities. The march was interrupted by police officers before reaching the audio-visual and communication authority. The protesters threatened of bigger mobilisations the following week should the stations not be reopened.
Military police officers beat and handcuffed a journalist while reporting on a land dispute in Lome.

Hundreds of people led by 12 civil society organisations marched in Lome to protest the suspension of two private radio stations. Police intervened firing tear gas to disperse the protesters as they were trying to access a part of the city without authorization.

Togolese taxi and boda boda drivers set up barricades and burnt down a bus during a strike in several parts of the capital over fuel price hikes. Police intervened to disperse them, leaving one killed and several injured, including among police forces.
Thousands of supporters of the Combat for Political Change (CAP2015) coalition (which gathers four opposition parties) staged a peaceful march in Lome to protest fuel price increases.

column7: CSET: Coordination of Education Trade Unions of Togo; Students (Togo)
column17: Teachers' syndicates launched a three-day strike in the capital. Students took the streets to call for the return of the teachers in classes.
Student riots in Yembour mid-March cause materiail damage. Police arrested and detained three students during a week after the protests.
Students marching towards the Government building were stopped by police forces.
Police forces violently dispersed peaceful student protests in Lome over 14-16 June resulting in several injuries and arrests.
Police forces violently dispersed peaceful student protests in Lome over 14-16 June resulting in several injuries and arrests.
Police forces violently dispersed peaceful student protests in Lome over 14-16 June resulting in several injuries and arrests.

University students in Togo vowed to continue their protests for better teaching conditions, after three days of demonstrations and clashes with police that saw eight arrested. Seven of the students who were detained after campus protests at the University of Lome turned violent last week were released from custody on Monday evening.
Opposition leaders and their supporters marched in Lome to call for democratic reforms.

PNP opposition supporters protested in 5 towns of Togo to claim political reforms in the country: Lome, Sokode, Kara, Anie and Bafilo. Clashes between the protesters and police reportedly occurred in all towns except Bafilo. Security source says 2 police posts were burnt down, 2 killed, and 40 injured including many among police. In Sokode, protesters burnt down a police station and clashed with gendarmed, resulting in the two fatalities and 12 injured.

PNP opposition supporters protested in 5 towns of Togo to claim political reforms in the country: Lome, Sokode, Kara, Anie and Bafilo. Clashes between the protesters and police reportedly occurred in all towns except Bafilo. Security source says 2 police posts were burnt down, 2 killed, and 40 injured including many among police. In Sokode, protesters burnt down a police station and clashed with gendarmed, resulting in the two fatalities and 12 injured.

PNP opposition supporters protested in 5 towns of Togo to claim political reforms in the country: Lome, Sokode, Kara, Anie and Bafilo. Clashes between the protesters and police reportedly occurred in all towns except Bafilo. Security source says 2 police posts were burnt down, 2 killed, and 40 injured including many among police. In Sokode, protesters burnt down a police station and clashed with gendarmed, resulting in the two fatalities and 12 injured.

PNP opposition supporters protested in 5 towns of Togo to claim political reforms in the country: Lome, Sokode, Kara, Anie and Bafilo. Clashes between the protesters and police reportedly occurred in all towns except Bafilo. Security source says 2 police posts were burnt down, 2 killed, and 40 injured including many among police. In Sokode, protesters burnt down a police station and clashed with gendarmed, resulting in the two fatalities and 12 injured.

PNP opposition supporters protested in 5 towns of Togo to claim political reforms in the country: Lome, Sokode, Kara, Anie and Bafilo. Clashes between the protesters and police reportedly occurred in all towns except Bafilo. Security source says 2 police posts were burnt down, 2 killed, and 40 injured including many among police. In Sokode, protesters burnt down a police station and clashed with gendarmed, resulting in the two fatalities and 12 injured.

PNP opposition supporters protested in 5 towns of Togo to claim political reforms in the country: Lome, Sokode, Kara, Anie and Bafilo. Clashes between the protesters and police reportedly occurred in all towns except Bafilo. Security source says 2 police posts were burnt down, 2 killed, and 40 injured including many among police. In Sokode, protesters burnt down a police station and clashed with gendarmed, resulting in the two fatalities and 12 injured.
Presidential supporters went to the street to show their support to President Gnassingbe.

Protesters took to the streets in huge numbers on Wednesday and Thursday calling for political reform, in the biggest protest against President Faure Gnassingbe in years. The opposition wants to limit a president to a maximum of two, five-year terms and the introduction of two-round voting.

Riot police fired tear gas at massive crowds gathered in Togo's capital late Thursday, breaking up the huge opposition protests against President Faure Gnassingbe's regime. In the Be area, where there were clashes with police throughout the night, barricades of rocks and burning tyres were visible. Demonstrators, blowing whistles and waving Togo's green, yellow and red flag, had said they were determined to stay in the streets ""all night"" but were finally made to disperse by security forces.
Opposition went to the street to protest against the government refusal to include into the parliamentary debate the consitutional reform.

Opposition parties in Togo kept on demonstrating over the rule of President Faure Gnassingbe, the scion of Africa's oldest political dynasty, amid accusations of harsh repression by the security forces. At least 77 people were injured in the town of Bafilo when security forces fired rubber bullets at the crowd on Wednesday, according to the opposition. Four people who were critically wounded were sent for treatment in Sokode, the country's second biggest city, about 50 kilometres (31 miles) to the south, it said. In statement, the opposition added that soldiers and militiamen in civilian dress ""infiltrated demonstrations"" in the northern cities of Bafilo, Kara, Mango, Sokode and Dapaong.""In Dapaong, soldiers staged punitive operations all night,"" the coalition said. In Mango, the source said, a nine-year-old child was killed and 25 people were injured, including 10 by gunshot. The injuries were caused by hunting rifles and other guns -- types of weapons that the security forces did not use, the source said.

Opposition parties in Togo kept on demonstrating over the rule of President Faure Gnassingbe, the scion of Africa's oldest political dynasty, amid accusations of harsh repression by the security forces. At least 77 people were injured in the town of Bafilo when security forces fired rubber bullets at the crowd on Wednesday, according to the opposition. Four people who were critically wounded were sent for treatment in Sokode, the country's second biggest city, about 50 kilometres (31 miles) to the south, it said. In statement, the opposition added that soldiers and militiamen in civilian dress ""infiltrated demonstrations"" in the northern cities of Bafilo, Kara, Mango, Sokode and Dapaong.""In Dapaong, soldiers staged punitive operations all night,"" the coalition said. In Mango, the source said, a nine-year-old child was killed and 25 people were injured, including 10 by gunshot. The injuries were caused by hunting rifles and other guns -- types of weapons that the security forces did not use, the source said.

Thousands of protesters in Togo Thursday joined demonstrations around the country for a second day against the rule of President Faure Gnassingbe, the scion of Africa's oldest political dynasty. The atmosphere was tense amid accusations of harsh repression by security forces on Wednesday, when at least 77 people were injured by rubber bullets in the far north of the country, according to the opposition.
Opposition supporters went to the streets in Lome and in several city across the nation to ask for the return to 1992 constitution.

Clashes were reported between opposants and police during the second day of demonstrations in Togo. In Sokode, the country's second biggest city, six people were wounded as security forces tried to break up a protest.""The police intervened by launching tear gas to free the blocked national road 1,"" Amnesty International's director for Togo, Aime Adi, told AFP. Five civilians were wounded in small calibre weapon fire and one soldier was seriously injured after mishandling a tear gas grenade. Several other rallies in the country's north -- a region previously seen as reliably pro-government -- also drew thousands of people in the cities of Bafilo and Dapaong, local residents told AFP.The atmosphere was more tense than during the previous day's demonstrations, which occurred without incident. Barricades have been erected in Lome, blocking traffic in several districts. ""Demonstrators have used rocks to block the road from Gakpoto to St. Joseph's school, and others are preventing cars from going through,"" Adi said.

Violence broke out also in Lome, after the arrest in Sokode of an imam close to the country's main opposition. One dead.

Violence broke out in Togo's second city, Sokode, after the arrest of an imam close to the country's main opposition. Security forces and youths clashed in several parts of the city, with teargas and stone-throwing. Two policemen and a civilian died in the clashes, 20 people were wounded.

There has been another deadly crackdown on opposition demonstrations in Togo, with official sources reporting four deaths. According to the MFWA correspondent in Togo, an 11 year-old boy, Zomake Jojo, was killed by bullet fired by security forces in Lome on October 18, 2017. Three more people were also killed in Sokode, some 300 km north of Lome.

Deadly crackdown on opposition demonstrations in Togo, with official sources reporting four deaths. According to the MFWA correspondent in Togo, an 11 year-old boy, Zomake Jojo, was killed by bullet fired by security forces in Lome on October 18, 2017. Three more people were also killed in Sokode, some 300 km north of Lome.

Five people were shot and injured on Thursday as gangs of youths and the security forces clashed sporadically in Togo's capital Lome, ahead of a planned opposition protest that the government has ruled illegal. The streets were largely deserted ahead of the rally, which the opposition coalition has refused to cancel despite a government ban on weekday marches on security grounds. Opposition spoke about 3 dead and 44 wounded.
A man was killed during an anti-opposition police operation in Sokode.

Thousands of people took to the streets in Sokode on Tuesday in the latest protest calling for the long-standing President Faure Gnassingbe to step down. Gatherings were dispersed in the late morning by law enforcement, despite the recent lifting of the government's ban on demonstrations on weekdays

Thousands of people took to the streets in Togo's capital on Tuesday in the latest protest calling for the long-standing President Faure Gnassingbe to step down. ""The army has been in the area since last night (Monday) and has been chasing young activists to their homes,"" said Ouro Akpo Tchagnaou, from Fabre's National Alliance for Change (ANC). ""They are breaking up any gathering on the streets and are using sticks and chains to beat people.""

Thousands of protesters descended Thursday in the streets of Lome and other cities for the second consecutive day against Togolese President Faure Gnassingbe. Sokode and Bafilo were unable to demonstrate during these three days, these two cities were besieged by soldiers deployed in large numbers and who prevent any gathering.

Thousands of protesters descended Thursday in the streets of Lome and other cities for the third consecutive day against Togolese President Faure Gnassingbe. Sokode and Bafilo were unable to demonstrate during these three days, these two cities were besieged by soldiers deployed in large numbers and who prevent any gathering.
Thousands of opponents of Faure Gnassingbe's regime demonstrated once again that popular mobilization does not falter after three months of political crisis, said an AFP correspondent.

Thousands of opponents of Faure Gnassingbe's regime demonstrated in Togo for the second consecutive day Friday, demonstrating once again that popular mobilization does not falter after three months of political crisis, said an AFP correspondent.
Togo's opposition parties pledged on Wednesday to maintain the momentum of anti-government protests, as thousands took to the streets once more ahead of promised talks with the president.
Protesters in Togo took to the streets for a second day in their bid to oust President Faure Gnassingbe on Thursday, as the opposition outlined conditions for talks with the government.

Thousands of protesters once again took to the streets of the Togolese capital to demand the departure of President Faure Gnassingbe, who promised to engage in a dialogue soon with the opposition. Opposition denouced police repression.

Thousands of people again marched in the streets of Lome at the call of the opposition, which boycotts the consultations proposed by the government to get out of the political crisis that Togo has been going through for three months.
In Togo, the opposition has mobilized again, in Lome

Togolese again descended the streets of Lome on Saturday to protest against the regime of President Faure Gnassingbe, who chaired the same day the summit of heads of state of the Economic Community of West Africa (ECOWAS) to Abuja, Nigeria.
Tens of thousands of people again took to the streets of Lome to protest against the regime of President Faure Gnassingbe

The demonstrations that took place Thursday in the streets of Lome, to protest against the regime of Faure Gnassingbe, have injured 12, including five seriously. ""Fifteen were arrested"", on the sidelines of the marches that were dispersed by police using teargas.
Tens of thousands of people again took to the streets of Lome to protest against the regime of President Faure Gnassingbe
Thousands of women took to the streets of Togo's capital Lome on Saturday to protest against the power of President Faure Gnassingbe.
Government coalition supporters took the street.

Thousands of protesters took to the streets in Togo's capital Lome, against President Faure Gnassingbe and his government. The protest came the day after mediators from Ghana and Guinea said that Togo will enter talks on controversial constitutional reform February 15, in a move aimed at ending a crippling political stalemate.
Students blocked National Road N1 against teachers' strikes.
On 12 and 13 March students across Togo took the streets and disturbed the regular teaching to protest the arrest of a German teacher in Kara on the 12th.

On 12 and 13 March students across Togo took the streets and disturbed the regular teaching to protest the arrest of a German teacher in Kara on the 12th. In Kara on 13 March, students were dispersed with teargas.

On 12 and 13 March students across Togo took the streets and disturbed the regular teaching to protest the arrest of a German teacher in Kara on the 12th. In Kara on 13 March, students were dispersed with teargas.
On 26 March, pregnant women went to the streets in Lome to protest the misfunctioning of hospitals.
On 5 April, a teachers' strike ongoing for 3 days triggered students' violence, as public school students interrupted private students' classes.

On 25 April, police prevented opposition supporters to gather, as the main assembly points in Lome were closed at daybreak by security forces. Nevertheless, teargas were thrown to protesters as demonstrators erected some barricades.
On 26 April, police and opposition supporters clashed in Lome. Protesters erected some barricades and burned some tyres.
Around 1 June, a land conflict opposed the villages of Nadouni, Dankpen in Togo, and Nambire, Saboba in Ghana. 1824 people were displaced and 10 people were wounded.
On 6 June, opposition parties demonstrated in Lome against the government: police dissuasion thwarted the demonstration.
On October 5, several thousands of people marched in Lome to demand the release of those arrested during major opposition protests in Togo for a year.

column9: ANC: National Alliance for Change Political Party
column17: In the night between Oct 15 and 16 the president of the ANC federal office was attacked at his house by 8 unknown men in Kara. He was severely injured and hospitalized.
On Nov 3, the FCTD marched in Lome to demand the release of some prisoners and the end of the electoral process, in view of the legislative elections, scheduled for December 20.
On Nov 17, the Coalition of 14 opposition parties organized a large protest march in Lome to call for electoral and other political reforms.
Opposition supporters staged a demonstration on 29 Nov 2018 in Lome, denouncing irregularities in the electoral process in Togo and calling on President Faure Gnassingbe to leave.
Opposition supporters staged a demonstration on 29 Nov 2018 in Kpalime, denouncing irregularities in the electoral process in Togo and calling on President Faure Gnassingbe to leave.
Opposition supporters staged a demonstration on 29 Nov 2018 in Atakpame, denouncing irregularities in the electoral process in Togo and calling on President Faure Gnassingbe to leave.
Opposition supporters staged a demonstration on 29 Nov 2018 in Sokode, denouncing irregularities in the electoral process in Togo and calling on President Faure Gnassingbe to leave.
Several thousand opposition supporters staged a demonstration on 1 Dec 2018 in Lome in anticipation of 20 Dec polls, denouncing irregularities in the electoral process in Togo.
On 2 Dec 2018, opposition supporters took to the streets in Lome.

On 6 Dec 2018, government security forces (assumed police) prevented a demonstration in Lome organised by a coalition of opposition parties, intended as a protest against upcoming legislative elections on 20 Dec.
On 8 Dec 2018, demonstrators clashed with security forces in Anie during protests against the upcoming legislative election. 17 people were wounded, including eight of them seriously.

On 8 Dec 2018, unknown gunmen in a 4x4 vehicle fired shots at protesters during a clash between opposition supporters and security forces in Lome due to upcoming disputed elections. Two people were killed including a child. Reports of a third person being killed were unconfirmed.
On 8 Dec 2018, opposition supporters assembled to protest in Bafilo against the upcoming legislative election. The protesters were dispersed by security forces who used teargas.

On 8 Dec 2018, opposition supporters clashed with security forces (assumed police) in Lome due to upcoming disputed elections. Youth set up barricades in various part of the city, particularly Agoe, to which security forces responded with tear gas. Four security members as well as several demonstrators were wounded and 28 demonstrators were detained.

On 8 Dec 2018, opposition supporters assembled to protest in Sokode against the upcoming legislative election. The protesters were dispersed by security forces who used teargas. Meanwhile, the demonstrators caused material damage.

On 10 Dec 2018, two people were killed in Sokode during clashes between opposition supporters and security forces ahead of the upcoming elections. One of the victims was shot dead and the other beaten to death. During the day, youth set up barricades to prevent government forces from entering streets.

On April 6, in Lome, a group of Martin Luther King Movement activists, organized a sit-in in front of the Municipal Stadium to demand the resignation of football coach Claude Leroy. Police used tear gas to disperse them. [size=no report]

On April 12 (or before, date unclear), Police Forces arrested 20 suspected Burkina Islamists and deported them to Burkina Faso. Weapons were also seized. (location unknown, coded as Lome geoprecision 3)

On April 13, PNP activists marched to demand reforms and the release of political prisoners despite a ban in Bafilo and other towns. Police intervened to disperse protesters. One protester died - the circumstances of his death remain unclear. PNP leaders claim that he was beaten to death by policemen. [size=no report]

On April 13 in Agoe, Agoe Demakpoe roundabout, PNP activists attempted to demonstrate against the government several times and blocked the road, using wheels and tree trunks but were dispersed by police forces. Several of them were arrested. Police Forces reportedly assaulted Agoe inhabitants (unclear), and rioters reacted by beating two police officers, including a woman. Police Forces used tear gas against rioters. [size=no report]
On April 13, PNP activists protested to demand reforms and the release of political prisoners in Afagnan. [size=no report]

On April 13, in the evening, unknown men in pickup trucks damaged the front gate of the PNP leader's house in Kegue neighbourhood, Agoe. They beat people at the property and according to the PNP took three security guards.
On April 13, PNP activists marched in Sokode to protest against the government, demanding new reforms and the release of political detainees. [size=no report]

On April 14, 2 PNP leaders, Gueffe Nouridine and Kezire, were arrested by Police in Lome, accused of not following security guidelines regarding PNP's protests the day before which led to one killed, several injured and many arrested (protests coded in separate event).

On April 28, unidentified men damaged director of newspaper ""Flambeau des democrates"" Loic Lawson's car during the night in Lome, in the newspapers' parking. The journalist had received threats following an article accusing a Minister of financial corruption. [size=no report]
On May 9, Togo's deputies voted a law allowing current President Faure Gnassingbe to stay in power potentially until 2030.

On June 17, in Hedzranawoe neighborhood, Lome, a mob attacked and beat 5 Nigerian men in their house, destroying goods, following rumors regarding the murder of a murder by a Nigerian. Police later intervened to disperse the attackers. [size=no report]
On June 23, in Lome, in Avepozo neighborhood, a young man accused of robbery was beaten by a mob and then burned alive. His body was found on June 24.

On June 30 (or before, unclear), in Gando, following a land dispute, Gangan inhabitants clashed with Tchokossi inhabitants. 4 people were killed, 20 injured, and 50 houses burned. Around 2,000 people reportedly fled the village.
On July 21, in Lome, Hedzranawoe neighbourhood, soldiers detained and tortured a man.

On July 21, in Danyagan, Akebou Prefecture, Ogou, a man was arrested by three soldiers, detained in a military camp and tortured during several hours. (coordinates not found, coded as Atakpame geoprecision 3)

column16: Togo Top News; Togoweb; aLome; Ici Lome
column17: On August 20, residents in Gbama Kope demonstrated against the decision to evict the village amid a land dispute, villagers threw rocks and policemen responded by firing tear gas and carrying out arrests.[size=no report]

On September 19, 2019, Rioters blocked access to many areas of Cinkasse and ransacked the customs offices, as they demonstrated against the decision to seize motorcycles without license plates. [size=no report]

On October 10, 2019, Military Forces attacked a Forest Guards' post in Davie in repraisal after Forest Guards attempted to arrest a military truck loaded with prohibited forest products. Many Forest Guards were reportedly injured.

On November 18, 2019, suspected members of the security forces [coded: Police Forces of Togo] beat two leaders of a students' Union in Kara (Kozah, Kara) were they planned a meeting with the local section of their Union. The two students were injured.

On November 23, 2019, a group of unidentified armed men attacked a Gendarmerie patrol in the area of Agoe (Golfe, Maritime), injuring three gendarmes. This attack comes amidst another attack against gendarmeries in the same area on the same day.

On November 23, 2019, a group of unidentified armed men attacked two gendarmes guarding a Bank office in the area of Agoe (Golfe, Maritime). They took away two guns. This attack comes amidst another attack against gendarmeries in the same area on the same day.
On November 23, 2019, a group of unidentified armed men attacked two gendarmes in the town of Sokode (Tchaoudjo, Centrale), taking away one gun.
On November 23, 2019, a group of unidentified armed men damaged several vehicules, setting fire to some of them in the city of Lome (Golfe, Maritime).

column16: A Free Press; Xinhua; Koaci News
column17: On 27 November 2019, supporters of the FCTD staged a protest in Lome (Golfe, Maritime) to demand the suspension of the ongoing electoral process in the context of the 2020 presidential election. [size=1000]
On 13 December 2019, a group of women marched in Bassar town (Bassar, Kara) to call for the preservation of peace, after the attacks of 23 November 2019. [size=thousands]

On an unspecified date in December 2019, [coded: 15 December 2019], an unidentified communal militia attacked members of the Adja ethnicity in Bandjeli town (Bassar, Kara). The attacks started after a voodoo oracle reportedly accused Adja people of abducting a baby. [size=no report]
On 23 December 2019, the police forces arrested 337 people during a securing operation in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime). No fatality and/or casualty reported.
On 23 December 2019, the police forces arrested 60 people during a securing operation in Kpalime town (Kloto, Plateaux). No fatality and/or casualty reported.

On 26 December 2019, the military forces clashed with the populations of Aloum and Ahodo villages, near Kara (Kozah, Kara) [coded: Kara] as their were resisting a motorbike registration control operation. 3 villagers were reportedly killed and around 10 injured (fatality split with 2 for Ahodo and 1 for Aloum). [size=no report]

On 6 Jan. 2020, the population of Kadambara village, near Sokode (Tchaoudjo, Centrale) protested against the announced candidacy of the President Faure Gnassingbe to the presidential elections. The security forces [coded: Police Forces] intervened to disperse them. [size=hundreds]

On 9 Jan. 2020, the military forces reportedly beat and injured many people including children in Bafilo town (Assoli, Kara). The victims are accused of supporting protests in the region. A least 3 people were also arrested.

column16: A Free Press; Togo Actualite; Togo Top News
column17: On 13 Jan. 2020, the population of Tchakpalakope village, in Anie subdivision (Ogou, Plateaux) [coded: Anie] clashed with a group of gendarmes who were sent to resolve a dispute between them and a Fulani herder after his cattle allegedly destroyed their crops. One villager was killed, and 5 gendarmes injured. [size=no report]
On 16 Jan. 2020, the population of Barkoissi town (Oti, Savanes) staged a protest to call for the paving of the Kara-Dapaong road. [size=no report]
On 22 Jan. 2020, the population of Amou Oblo locality (Amou, Plateaux) staged a protest to demand the reopening of drinking water points closed by the local authorities. [size=no report]

column16: Togo Actualite; Togo Online; A Free Press; Togoweb; Togo Top News; Republique Togolaise
column17: On 25 Jan. 2020, the police forces arrested 31 suspected members of Tigre revolution militia in Davie and Lome city (Golfe, Maritime). They were reportedly plotting to disrupt the next February presidential election. Two leaders of the PNP party were among the arrested.

On 25 January 2020, military forces attacked the home of the Secretary general of PNP party (opposition) in Kpalime town (Kloto, Plateaux). They damaged parts of the building and broke doors and windows.

column9: ANC: National Alliance for Change Political Party
column17: On 10 Feb. 2020, suspected supporters of the ruling UNIR party armed with sticks and machetes prevented the ANC party (opposition) to campaign in Bassar town (Kara). [size=no report]

column17: On 11 Feb. 2020, suspected supporters of the UNIR ruling party reportedly threw stones to disrupt a meeting of an MPDD opposition candidate in Afagnan-Bletta town (Lacs, Maritime), in the context of electoral campaign. [size=no report]

column17: On 11 Feb. 2020, suspected supporters of the ruling UNIR party blocked the road leading to Sotouboua town (Sotouboua, Centrale) to prevent a convoy of the ANC party (opposition) to reach the town for electoral campaign. They also 'occupied' the place where an ANC meeting was planned. [size=no report]

column9: ANC: National Alliance for Change Political Party
column17: On 19 Feb. 2020, suspected supporters of the ruling UNIR party attacked supporters of the ANC party (opposition) who were taking part the electoral campaign in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime). One person was injured. [size=no report]

On 24 Feb. 2020, in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime), the CENI elections body announced the victory of incumbent president Faure Gnassingbe in the presidential elections, with 72,36% of the votes according to preliminary results.
