column17: On 28 Feb. 2020, the security forces (assumed Police Forces) reportedly 'arrested' a Catholic bishop and supporter of the MPDD opposition party in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime), as he was leaving the US Embassy after a meeting. He was taken to his home that was reportedly surrounded by the security forces.

column7: MPDD: Patriotic Movement for Democracy and Development
column16: A Free Press; Togo Actualite; aLome; Togoweb; Togo Top News; Togonews; Koaci News
column17: On 28 Feb. 2020, supporters of the MPDD opposition party demonstrated in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime) against the results of the presidential election, claiming that the party's candidate won it. Security forces (assumed Police Forces) intervened and fired tear gas at the demonstrators to disperse them. Several people were reportedly injured, and several others arrested. The house of the MPDD candidate was surrounded by the security forces. [size=at least several]

column16: Togoweb; aLome; Togo Actualite; Republique Togolaise
column17: On 22 March 2020, unidentified individuals engaged in fire fight with Gendarmerie forces who were intervening after a failed road attack near Mango town (Oti, Savanes). One gendarme was killed and another injured.

column16: Republique Togolaise; Togoweb; A Free Press; Togo Actualite; Koaci News
column17: On 23 March 2020, the gendarmerie forces shot and killed one Beninese national in Agwegan border village (Lacs, Maritime), as he was trying to transport 11 people into Togo despite the border closure due to the coronavirus.

column16: Togoweb; Togo Top News; Togo Online
column17: On 2 April 2020, a group of prisoners demonstrated in the prison of Lome city (Golfe, Maritime) against the decision of the government to free 1048 prisoners in the context of the fight against the coronavirus. They denounced the number of freed prisoners as too low, and complained about their detention conditions. They attacked and damaged the building of the prison and blocked the main entrance. [size=no report]

column16: A Free Press; aLome; Xinhua; Republique Togolaise; Togo Online; Togoweb; Togo Actualite; Koaci News
column17: On 2 April 2020, the government of Togo declared the state of health emergency for 3 months, to combat the coronavirus. A curfew was also decided from 8 p.m to 5 a.m. A 5000-men strong special force was also created to combat the epidemic.

column16: Togoweb; Togo Actualite; A Free Press
column17: On 3 April 2020, two groups of youths armed with machetes clashed in Be town (Golfe, Maritime). The fight started after a dispute between townsmen of the Be Hedze and Akodessewa neighbourhoods, before escalating in a general clash between the two neighbourhoods. Several people were reportedly severely injured.

column16: Togo Actualite; Togoweb; Togo Top News
column17: On 4 April 2020, about 100 taxi bike riders demonstrated in Kara town (Kozah, Kara) against the decision of the government to ban their activity in the context of measures against the coronavirus. [size=about 100]
On 4 April 2020 (or around), the security forces (assumed police forces) beat up several violators of the coronavirus related curfew in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime).

On 6 April 2020, soldiers in charge of enforcing coronavirus curfew measures reportedly arrested and tortured 7 people in Baguida village (Golfe, Maritime). The event reportedly happened between 12 p.m to 4 p.m while the curfew was not yet in force.

column7: MPDD: Patriotic Movement for Democracy and Development
column16: Togoweb; Togo Top News; Togo Actualite; Togo Online
column17: On 9 April 2020, youth supporters of the MPDD (opposition) party demonstrated in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime), burning tires on the road and erecting barricades. This happened after military and police forces surrounded the house of a leader of the party who self-declared his victory in last Feb. 2020 presidential election. The police and military forces fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrators. [size=no report]
As reported on 15 April 2020, military forces beat a young man to death in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime), for violating the counter coronavirus curfew.
On 15 April 2020, the soldiers of the special anti-coronavirus forces beat up and injured a journalist and a woman accused of violating the curfew in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime).
On 15 April 2020, the military forces beat and injured an old woman in Devikinme village, near Aneho town (Lacs, Maritime), for violating the counter coronavirus curfew.

On 16 April 2020, the soldiers from the special anti-coronavirus forces beat up and injured several residents, including an off-duty police officer, in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime). They were accused of violating the coronavirus curfew.

column7: MPDD: Patriotic Movement for Democracy and Development
column16: Togoweb; Togo Actualite; A Free Press; Togo Top News; RFI; Togo Online; aLome; Republique Togolaise
column17: On 21 April 2020, supporters of the MPDD (opposition) party demonstrated in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime) in an attempt to prevent gendarmerie forces from arresting their leader. The gendarmes fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrator and arrested the leader. Several people were beaten up and injured during the arrest. [size=no report]

column16: Togo Online; aLome; A Free Press; Togoweb; Togo Actualite
column17: On 22 April 2020, special anti coronavirus military forces reportedly killed one violator of the curfew in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime).

column16: Togoweb; Togo Online; Togo Actualite; A Free Press
column17: On 23 April 2020, residents demonstrated in Adakpame neighbourhood of Lome city (Golfe, Maritime) against the reported killing of a young man by the anti coronavirus special force the previous day. They erected barricades and burnt tires on the road. The security forces (assumed Police Forces) intervened and fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrators. [size=no report]
On 3 May 2020, prisoners demonstrated in a prison in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime), after the death of one of a fellow prisoner from the coronavirus. [size=no report]

column16: Koaci News; Togo Actualite; Togo Online; A Free Press; Togo Top News; RFI; aLome; Togoweb
column17: On 4 May 2020, unidentified individuals shot and killed an army officer, commander of the rapid intervention battalion, in his office in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime). An investigation is underway, with 4 army officers arrested so far.

column16: Koaci News; Togoweb; Togo Actualite; Togo Online; A Free Press; Togo Top News
column17: On 7 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Doufelgou prefecture, beginning in Siou (Doufelgou, Kara) to call for justice after the assassination of an army officer who originated from the region. [size=no report]

column16: Togoweb; Togo Top News; aLome; Togo Actualite
column17: On 11 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Niamtougou town (Doufelgou, Kara) to demand justice after the assassination of an army officer who originated from the region. The demonstrators clashed with security forces (assumed Police Forces) who tried to disperse them, resulting in one person killed and several injured. [size=at least several]

column16: Togo Online; aLome; RFI; Togoweb; Togo Actualite; Togo Top News
column17: On 11 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Siou town (Doufelgou, Kara) to demand justice after the assassination of an army officer who originated from the region. They also demanded the remains of the deceased for traditional rituals. The demonstrators clashed with military forces, resulting in several injured. Some source say one of the demonstrators injured later died of his wounds. [size=at least several]

column16: A Free Press; Togo Actualite; Koaci News; aLome; Togo Online; Togo Top News; Republique Togolaise; Togoweb
column17: On 12 May 2020, prisoners demonstrated in Lome prison (Golfe, Maritime) to demand to be freed for fear of coronavirus contamination. The gendarmerie fired tear gas to disperse them. [size=no report]
Around 12 May 2020, the military forces captured one person who evaded from a coronavirus quarantine facility in Kegue neighbourhood of Lome city (Golfe, Maritime), beating and severely injured him.

On 15 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Siou town (Doufelgou, Kara) to demand justice after the assassination of an army officer who originated from the region. They also demand the remains of the deceased for traditional rituals. [size=no report]

On 15 May 2020, Komkomba people from Tatchiboure village attacked a group of Lamba with firearms in Kinasiou village (Kozah, Kara) over a land dispute. Both groups engaged in gunfire with several people injured.

On 18 May 2020, Komkomba people engaged in a firefight with the Lamba in Dankpen sub prefecture (Kozah, Kara) over a land dispute. One person was shot and killed, and 12 others injured. Several houses were also burnt.

On 18 May 2020, residents clashed with police forces in Gamasoe village (Moyen-Mono, Plateaux), as they opposed the arrest of a group of youths accused of killing cattle days before. The police forces used tear gas to disperse the rioters injuring several of them. [size=at least several]

On 19 May 2020, Komkomba people engaged in a firefight with the Lamba, for the second day in a row, in Dankpen sub prefecture (Kozah, Kara) over a land dispute. The Mayor of Dankpen was briefly kidnapped and tortured.

column16: Togoweb; Togo Online; Togo Actualite; aLome; A Free Press; Koaci News
column17: On 21 May 2020, a gendarme shot and killed one person in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime) after he apparently resisted a police control.

column16: A Free Press; Togo Actualite; Togoweb; Togo Online; Koaci News
column17: On 21 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime) after a police officer killed one person who apparently resisted a control. The police forces fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrators. [size=no report]

On 30 May 2020, armed bandits opened fire on the gendarmerie forces who were trying to arrest them in Cinkasse town (Kpendjal, Savanes). One bandit was killed, and a civilians was injured by a stray bullet.
On 14 June 2020, the gendarmerie forces reportedly tortured one person to death in Kara town (Kozah, Kara), after he was arrested for an unpaid debt.
On 15 June 2020, transporters erected barricades on several roads as they demonstrated in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime) against new transport fees imposed by the authorities. [size=no report]

column16: A Free Press; Togo Actualite; Togoweb
column17: On 16 July 2020, police forces arrested and reportedly tortured about 40 young students in Lome town (Golfe, Maritime). They were accused of recording a pornographic video and sharing it on social media.

column17: On 27 July 2020, residents demonstrated in Tsevie town (Golfe, Maritime) after the police shot and injured a bystander during a security operation. The demonstrators erected barricades, burnt tires in the road, and clashed with the police forces. [size=no report]

column16: Togoweb; Togo Online; Togo Actualite; Le Temps (Togo); Togo Top News
column17: On 27 July 2020, police forces reportedly fired tear gas and shot at bystanders during security operation in Tsevie town (Golfe, Maritime). One person was injured.

column16: A Free Press; Togoweb; Togo Actualite
column17: On 28 July 2020, members of the Pagnes Noirs voodoo sect demonstrated in Agbodrafo village (Golfe, Maritime) against a plan by the authorities to build a city hall in what they say is their sacred forest. [size=no report]

column16: Togo Actualite; Togo Top News; A Free Press; Togo Online
column17: On 10 August 2020, hundreds of residents demonstrated in Kpome town (Zio, Maritime) after the death a government officer who originated from the town. One villager was killed, and 13 injured, and 4 gendarmes were also injured. The villagers also destroyed 2 intervention cars. [size=at least 14]

Workers and youths in the Tunisian city of Sfax gathered in front of the local office of the Tunisian General Labour Union in solidarity with the population of Sidi Bouzid Province which was the site of two-week long social protests. The union members called for the freedom to demonstrate and freedom of expression and denounced the way security forces dealt with protestors in many Tunisian cities.

In Redayf in the southern mining region, a group of people, who were detained in connection with the 2008 social protests in the region and have been recently released, began an open sit-in. They were protesting for the release of people who were detained during the mining region unrest and the Sidi Bouzid protests.

Scores of students clashed with security forces in the Tunisian town of Tala and threw a burnt tire at a police centre while lawyers announced they will go on strike in protest over what they call police ""abuses"" against their colleagues.

Five protesters suffered gunshot wounds in the southern economic centre of Sfax, union activists said, after riot police moved in to disperse thousands who had taken to the streets for a general strike in the industrial city 300 kilometres southeast of Tunis. A 19-year-old man died after being shot by police.
Police opened fire on a demonstration in the central town of Douz, killing two.

In the El Aouina district, near the Carthage international airport, a branch of a supermarket chain owned by a businessman close to the administration was burnt. Eight were killed in clashes around Tunis overnight as angry youths had burned cars and attacked state offices in defiance of a curfew.
Shops and banks in Douar Hicher were attacked and vandalised by rioters on 12 January.
A receptionist from a local hotel in Hammamet was shot dead on 12 January when police fired on demonstrators. Another demonstrator was also reportedly shot dead.

Many journalists and staff of regional newspapers of the Sfax governorate demonstrated on 20 January against the situation of the regional press and barriers to the exercise of their profession.

Workers in Tunisia on 20 January prised the name of the ousted presidents party off the RCD headquarters amid fresh protests against the inclusion of its former members in a new cabinet. Soldiers fired shots in the air to keep the crowd away and to keep the protest peaceful. Protested chanted for Prime Minister Ghannouchi to resign.

A peaceful demonstration was staged on 20 January in front of Tunis Law Courts in Bab Bnet by a large number of judges and lawyers chanting slogans against the RCD and calling for the independence of judges, the freeing of all political prisoners and keeping corrupted judges in the background.
Dozens of people at the airport protested against Ghannouchis return.

In Sousse, the fourth demonstration and protest day was marked by the participation of the police forces joining the marchers, in uniform and plain dress, who walked the streets of the city expressing solidarity with the citizens and pride at the Tunisian peoples Revolution which brought down the Ben Ali regime.

In Gabes, police joined protesters and headed towards the regional seat of UGTT, waving the national banner, singing the national anthem and loudly voicing support to the Tunisian people and its Revolution.

About 100 Tunisians demonstrated in front of the Libyan embassy in the capital Tunis, chanting slogans against veteran ruler Moamer Kadhafi and backing demands for him to quit.

At the same time, protesters, mostly students, gather outside the Libyan embassy in Tunis for the second consecutive day, to show their support for the uprising in Libya against Moamer Kadhafis regime.

Dozens of Tunisians demonstrated on the capitals Habib Bourguiba Avenue to support Libyans calls for Kadhafi to go, describing him as an ""executioner"" and chanting ""Tunisians and Libyans, same people, same future"".

Journalists at Tunisias state television began a sit-in protest against their managers saying they want a new editorial policy reflecting the ongoing democratic changes that resulted from the uprising against the deposed President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali.

Violent clashes erupted between some demonstrators and security forces in La Kasbah, killing three people. The Interior Ministry blamed the acts of violence against the police to ""a group of agitators infiltrated the ranks of peaceful demonstrators.""

Five people were killed in clashes on 26 February between demonstrators and security forces in Tunisias capital. Security forces had fired warning shots and tear gas at the youths armed with knives and stones who wanted to force the headquarters of the Interior Ministry. Soldiers arrived at the scene to back up police.
Clashes with police were reported on Avenue Bourguiba in Tunis on 26 February.
Police fired tear gas and warning shots in the centre of Tunis, where anti-government protesters were gathered for a third day. The crowds threw stones and mounted barricades.
Over two thousand demonstrators gathered in front of the home of Mr. Mohamed Ghannouchi in Tunis after the announcement, on Sunday, of his resignation from the interim government.

Non-violent activity: Tunisias Prime Minister Mohammed Ghannouchi resigned on 27 February. Tunisias interim president Foued Mebazaa announced the appointment of Beji Caid Essebsi, a former minister, as the new premier to succeed Mohamed Ghannouchi who resigned.
Several thousand demonstrators flocked to the Dome El Menzah: they camped in the square rejecting the political vacuum, violence , insecurity and ""chaos that threatens the country.""

Young people from different parts of the country and representing all social groups gathered at the Place de la Kasbah chanting slogans against the Constitutional Democratic Rally (RCD) and calling to dissolve the government.

In the town of El Guettar, traffic at the road to Gabes was suspended by protesters. The protesters believe they have been excluded from recruitment program developed by the GIC in response to protests that erupted in the mining area. They demand to strengthen this program by new job opportunities.

In the town of Gafsa, youth groups gathered outside the headquarters of the CPG to demand jobs. They cut the road with burning tires and containers, before attempting to force the offices of the company. The army intervened to stop the acts of violence and evacuate personnel.

column17: Members of the Tunisian Union of Industry, Trade and Handicrafts (Utica) organized a rally on 2 March to call the country to return to work and rescue the country from imminent economic crisis.

In the town of Zannouch (Essened) rail transport in the direction of Gabes and Sfax was paralyzed by protesters. The protesters believe they have been excluded from recruitment program developed by the GIC in response to protests that erupted in the mining area. They demand to strengthen this program by new job opportunities.
Units of the National Security arrested in Jendouba, 29 persons involved in acts of looting, violence, consumption of drugs and use of knives.

Vandalism and violence occurred in Metlaoui, outside the headquarters of the Gafsa Phosphate Company, following an exchange of stone throwing between groups among the locals. The police and the National Guard fired shots in the air to disperse the groups and ease the tension.
The staff of the Ministry of Industry and Technology observed a sit-in against the Executive Director of the Chemistry Technology Centre.

The police and National Guard officers, in collaboration with the National Army, dispersed the perpetrators of these acts of violence by using tear gas.

column17: Troops clash with protesters in unrest on 12 March. The protests began amid rumors that the regional phosphate mining company was secretly recruiting in a specific tribal area instead of opening its jobs to the entire local population. The clashes left two dead the previous day.

Many university graduates in Mareth, continued their sit-in outside the headquarters of the delegation to demand a job that guarantees them a decent life.

column17: Peaceful demonstration outside the Swiss embassy in Tunis, organised by the Tunisian Association for Financial Transparency (ATTF) in association with other NGOs, claimed retrieval of all funds placed illegally by the former president and his clan in public and private Swiss banks.

Strike:Magistrates in courts against Tunisia held a strike to protest against the insecurity and acts of violence and aggression perpetrated against them in recent days. The Tunisian Judges Assocation was not involved.

Police fired tear gas on stone-throwing youths in Tunisias capital after a demonstration by hundreds of Islamists protesting the countries secular laws. Groups of youth marched near the Casbah and clashed with police, who responded with volleys of tear gas.
Protesters held two demonstrations in Tunis, one by a group demanding more economic freedoms and another by young Islamists shouting ""God is great"" and other religious slogans.

Clashes and acts of violence were reported in the night of the 3 April to 4 April in Gafsa, leaving several injured, mostly minor.
Staff at the radio channel Kalima staged a protest against being driven from their premises and being banned from airing communication.
On April 5, a band of ""religious extremists"" seized a mosque in Djerba and sakced the remains. Salafists are suspected to be involved but not confirmed.
Nearly 2,000 residents protested against the former mayor of Tabarka, , Dr Jilani Dabboussi, over comments he made about the regional development of the city.

On April 18, in Tunis, an unknown assailant struck film director Nouri Bouzid on the head with a metal bar. Bouzid was attacked shortly after he gave an interview on a Tunisian radio station in which he called for a secular constitution for Tunisia and explained that his forthcoming film defended civil liberties and criticized religious fundamentalism.

Hundreds of school students fought with sticks and knives in a tribal-rooted clash that left two dead and 43 wounded. Classrooms and a vehicle were torched during the brawl at a school in the town of Sened, with the two sides attacking each other with sticks, knives and stones. This clash was triggered following a dispute between two students that Sened and Alim has expanded today to include a large number of high school students and residents of the region.
Tunisian football referees went on strike. The referees who gathered at the headquarters of the Tunisian football federation took the decision in protest against the latest violence in stadiums.

Refugees blocked the main cross-border highway at the Chouca refugee camp prompting more fighting between refugees and local residents. Tunisian troops moved in and fired tear gas and warning shots to restore order. A total of 10 people died in the week of unrest (4 fatalities recorded for 24 May)
Tunisian police and locals clash with African refugees

Hundreds of African refugees, mostly Somalis and Eritreans, protested against the living conditions in the Choucha camp and the slowness of the evacuation process, asking the UN to hasten their evacuation from the camp.
People in Reguab in Sidi Bouzid to begin demonstration as mistrust of government deepens.
A local market was burnt and a number of shops looted as violent clashes broke out between local residents in Matlaoui.

Ongoing clashes between rival groups. The violence followed simmering tensions in the region after rumors related to the recruitment policies of the Gafsa Phosphates company favouring a local tribe. A total of 11 people were reported killed from Saturday-Sunday. Unidentified military and security forces reported that members of Ben Alis now-disbanded RCD party were among 105 people arrested over the violence. This statement has not been verified.

Brief clashes took place on 6 June in Metlaoui, between groups of citizens at the city ""El Mahatta. Security and the national armed forces intervened in time to stop the clashes.
Several residents of el-Djerid region on 8 June in Tunis held a peaceful protest to denounce the tribal clashes have occurred recently in the delegation of Metlaoui Gafsa, killing several victims.

Protest to demand release of police employee after he criticised interior ministry officials over corruption and links to former regime. About 100 to 150 people in central Tunis demanded that current interim Interior Minister Habib Essid, who worked under ousted president Zine El Abidine Ben Ali, step down.

A group of people protested Saturday outside the headquarters of the Delegation of La Marsa to demand an end to violations of the forest of Gammarth, including illegal appropriation, uncontrolled construction and logging.

Protesters in Matlaoui, organised by the Tunisian League for Tolerance (LTT) shouted slogans to initiate a process of reconciliation between the actors of the last tribal clashes: ""The people want national unity"", ""Loyalty to the blood of the martyrs"", ""Freedom and unity for Metlaoui.""
Salafist Muslims attack movie-goers at secular film
Salafist Muslims smash glass at cinema to protest secular film
Salafist Muslims protest to demand release of fellow members. Police arrested about 30 people.
Salafist demonstrators attacked three lawyers outside the main courthouse in Tunis who had to be taken to hospital.
Inmates riot in jailbreak attempt

Troops were deployed outside the Kasserine prison as relatives of inmates were protesting for the release of the prisoners. The protesters stoned troops when they stopped them from storming the prison.
Demonstrators torch police station after deaths of inmates during jailbreak
Protests against Islamic extremism
Several political parties and representatives of civil society observed a sit-in outside the headquarters of the governorate of Sidi Bouzid to protest violence that might derail the revolution.
Riots between neighborhood residents in the Sidi Bouzid region resulted in the destruction of public and private property including commercial premises and cars and attacking housing arrangements.

Large groups of young men, armed with sticks and bladed weapons, engaged in fierce clashes, with some attacking private and public properties on 13 July in Gafsa. High military and security presence, as well as the use of tear gas.

Twenty people some of whom were wearing balaclavas smashed the windows of the exterior facade of the Gafsa radio headquarters and caused panic among journalists and staff operating there.

In front of the governorate of Sfax a number of demonstrators who participated in the recent sit-in Place des Martyrs in Sfax, protested for the release of 6 young sit-inners imprisoned, believing that they are victims of repressive policing against freedoms. The demonstrators chanted slogans calling for the independence of the judiciary, freedom of expression and opinion, as well as a political statement and the fight against administrative corruption.

Acts of violence and riots reported in Jendouba on 5 August. La Presse reported that group belonging to the Salafist movement attacked restaurants and cafes, arguing that these stalls were serving non-fasting in the month of Ramadan.
Syrians and Tunisians protest Syrian regime outside of Syrian embassy in Tunisia
Jebeniana witnessed a wave of peaceful protest led by some residents and representatives of political tendencies in the region.

Dozens of people protested outside the Syrian embassy in Tunisia to demand an end to the ""carnage"" in Syria and the departure of President Bashar al-Assad.

The locality of sakiet ezzit in Sfax experienced acts of violence and clashes between police and young protesters who stormed the police office, burned documents and assaulted the police chief.
A band of 300 people interrupted railway traffic in Sidi Ismail (Beja) after they did not receive their salaries while working in construction sites.
A band of 300 people, including workers of logging sites engaged in acts of violence, attacking the HQ of the governorate and buildings, forcing shops and public facilities to close.

A clash at a wedding party between the tribes of Ouled Ben Nouma and El Dziria took place in Sbeitla (center-east). The clashes degenerated into a fire of tires and rubbish bins. The police station was also attacked. The security forces and the army intervened to pin down the aggressors (about a thousand), who were riposted by throwing stones and molotov cocktails, seriously wounding a soldier.
After news that a girl was killed by security forces, Sbeitla residents set fire to a police post, three buses and a railroad station, and ransacked the local hospitals emergency room.

column7: Military Forces of Tunisia (2011-2014) National Guard

about thirty people were injured in clashes that occurred Thursday evening between young people of El Kalaa and Abedla in the delegation of Douz-Nord. Fires were fired in three houses and two gas kiosks located at the northern entrance of the town of Douz.
Acts of violence were reported in the coastal southern city of Metouia near Gabes, after mobs decided to cut off a main road.
The main road connecting Douz to the city of Kebili was cut, preventing citizens from joining their workplaces.

Fighting between rival clans in the southwestern Tunisian mining town of Metlaoui. Local sources identified the two clans as the Ouled bond and Jridia families. Most of the fighting took place at the level of cities, ""Kaina"" and ""Makroun"". Security forces dispersed the crowds.
A group of Salafists attacked a car and fought a man who was throwing empty beer bottles by throwing back stones and other objects in Hergla.
A bus driver was assaulted by a policeman near the Olympic Stadium in Rades.

Fighting between rival clans in the southwestern Tunisian mining town of Metlaoui. Local sources identified the two clans as the Ouled bond and Jridia families. Most of the fighting took place at the level of cities, ""Kaina"" and ""Makroun"". The internal security forces dispersed the crowd using tear gas.

Fighting between rival clans in the southwestern Tunisian mining town of Metlaoui killed a young man. Local sources identified the two clans as the Ouled bond and Jridia families. Most of the fighting took place at the level of cities, ""Kaina"" and ""Makroun"". The internal security forces dispersed the crowd using tear gas.
In revenge for being shot at, a Salafist group attacked homes and set fire to apartments.
Two young boys were shot on their Vespa in Hergla after a man intended to shoot a group of Salafists.

column7: UNSFST: National Union of Tunisian Security Forces
column17: Police demonstrate to call for resignation of interim prime minister and for a fair trial for 23 officers who have been detained on charges of killing protesters.
Police demonstrate to call for resignation of interim prime minister

Acts of violence in Ettadhamen and Mnihla (Ariana governorate) by groups of young people and individuals who were armed with knives and sticks.

Five unemployed men tried to hang themselves in a suicide protest in Kasserine after waiting in vain for years for a government job. TAP says the five university graduates aged 34 to 43, were protesting the results of a recruitment exam with the Education Ministry.

Group of Salafist Muslims took over a Christian basilica in the Tunisian town of Kef with the aim of turning it into a mosque. Police dispersed about 20 people from the Roman site, who argued that it was a place of Muslim worship before it reverted to a basilica in 1966.

Several people attacked the local hospital in Jebeniana, destroyed its equipment and terrorised the medical and semi-medical framework in it using knives and clubs.
Violence recorded in Jebiniana on October 2nd. ""A group of young people tried to attack the regional hospital and were blocked by the forces of an army unit.
Some taxi drivers gathered, Monday 3 October, in front of the Sfax governorate to protest against their professional conditions.
Police use teargas to deter protesters in Tunis
protesters demonstrate outside local television headquarters

Four Islamist activists (reported as Salafists) carrying knives and swords attacked the Faculty of Letters and Human Sciences of Sousse after the administration refused to enroll a female student wearing a niqab. No one was hurt and the attackers were eventually forced out of the campus.

column16: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
column17: On October 8, at the School of Arts and Humanities of Sousse, a crowd confronted the secretary-general of the faculty after the administration prevented a female student wearing a niqab from registering for courses. Demonstrators pounding his car and started kicking and hitting him and tearing his clothes.

A group of Salafist protesters armed with sticks and knives tried to storm the offices of private Tunisian TV station ""Nessma TV"" in Tunis after it broadcast a French-Iranian animated film depicting Allah, entitled ""Persepolis"", followed by a debate. Security forces dispersed them and managed to drive them off.
Two individuals entered the TV stations offices on 11 October and threatened to kill employees, while two cars parked outside the head of Nessma TVs home was torched.

Tunisian police used tear gas to disperse protestors who were angry at a TV station that showed a French-Iranian animation feature, which they deemed to be blasphemous. The protests were also about the ""denunciation of indifference"" shown mainly by the visual media to the issue of identity that extends to Tunisians religious beliefs and their value system.

Protesters damaged flimmaker Nabil Karouis home with Molotov cocktails after Karoui chose to broadcast the film ""Persepolis"" on Nessma television station October 9. ""Persepolis"" is controversial for depicting an image of God.

column16: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
column17: At the Higher Institute of Theology of Tunis, one day in mid-October, students gathered in the courtyard. They were shouting that they did not want a secular professor teaching them Islamic Beliefs (Akida).
More than 2,000 Tunisians marched in favor of a secular state that allows press freedom and other rights. The demonstration is a response to protests and violence by Islamist extremists.
Nearly 100 protestors gathered outside the Congress Palace in Tunis to protest alleged ""irregularities"" by Ennahda.
Around 400 protesters gathered in Tunis to demonstrate against voter fraud
Police use teargas against protesters in Sidi Bouzid. A group of 2,000 young people broke doors and windows of the Ennahda building and set alight tyres on the towns main road.
Protest in the town of Regueb, some 50 kilometers (30 miles) from Sidi Bouzid where a gunshot was fired at the local offices Ennahda.
Protests spread to nearby Menzel Bouzaiene where more than 1,000 people demonstrated
In Meknassy, 50km from Sidi Bouzid, demonstrators set fire to Ennahdhas party office.

Several citizens of Zarzis held Friday afternoon, a peaceful demonstration in downtown to express their discontent for the lack of resources at the regional hospital of Zarzis and claim improvements and the human and material support in favor of this hospital.

Troops fired into the air in Sidi Bouzid on Friday morning to disperse a crowd trying to attack the offices of the regional government. Supporters of the Petition for Justice and Development Party, popular in Sidi Bouzid, were angered that it had been eliminated from the ballot over allegations of campaign finance violations.
Taxi drivers invaded the city police station, blocking traffic, to protest against the laxity of the law enforcement officers and the lack of security.

column16: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information

Women rally to protest role of Islamists
Hundreds of students protested at has Tunis college to defend ""academic and individual freedoms.""

A group of teachers and students of the Faculty of law and political science and the Faculty of Economic Sciences and management of Tunis under the Tunis El Manar University, held a protest movement within the University grounds to claim respect for individual freedoms including the freedom of dress and the acceptance of the other.
Some 150 family members of the young Tunisian prisoners reported missing in Iraq staged a sit-in in front of the Foreign Ministry in Tunis, to demand their repatriation to Tunisia.

column7: UJCT: Union of Communist Youth of Tunisia
column17: Hundreds of protesters occupied the Place of human rights in downtown Tunis under the banner of Occupy Wall Street. Protesters held banners with slogans like ""No. More Capitalism"" and ""Artistic Revolution against Capitalism"", blood freedom songs, and played music with homemade instruments.
The police union of Gafsa gathered in front of police headquarters in protest of low night shift wages and financial corruption within the police administration.
Tens of tunisians gathered outside the Arab League headquarters to protest

column7: The Association of Parents of Tunisian Prisoners in Iraq
column17: The Association of Parents of Tunisian Prisoners in Iraq staged a demonstration at El-Kasbah Square in Tunis. The protesters claimed the release of the Tunisian nationals still detained in the Iraqi prisons and repatriation of the bodies of those who died.

On Saturday, November 19th, a ceremony organized by the Independent High Authority for Elections (ISIE) to commemorate the martyrs of Tunisias Revolution turned into a protest in Tunis. In a separate demonstration, protesters denounced the Arab League and rejected intervention in Syria.

column7: UJCT: Union of Communist Youth of Tunisia
column17: Nearly 2,000 Tunisians from various civil society organizations from across the political spectrum demonstrated in front of the Tunisian Parliament building during the opening session of the Constituent Assembly on November 22nd. One of the largest groups who showed up at the demonstration were the various Tunisian Communist Party.
Demonstrators cut off the main road and burned out in the streets. The military dispersed the crowd with tear gas and shots fired in the air.

Angry villagers of Mdilla attacked the local offices of the Gafsa Phosphate Company after the announcement of results for a new hiring competition. 76 people were injured by tear gas in the two towns.

Riots in Thala and Feriana.

column16: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information

The offices of the Gafsa Phosphate Company (GIC), in the districts of Mdhilla and Om Larayes, in Gafsa, were burnt down and the companies warehouses looted, following the announcement of its staffing competition results, deemed unfair by local applicants. 76 people were injured by tear gas in the two towns.

A smaller peaceful demonstration was held in Kasserine, gathering around 200 people as a result of the Constituent Assemblys failure to include the names of Kasserines dead in a list of martyrs of the Tunisian Revolution.

Violence resumed in the cities of Om Larayes and Mdhilla. The head of the company of phosphates of Gafsa (CPG) has been largely burned and its warehouses have been looted. Scuffles between security forces and protestors broke out.

Violence resumed in the cities of Om Larayes and Mdhilla. The head of the company of phosphates of Gafsa (CPG) has been largely burned and its warehouses have been looted. Scuffles between security forces and protestors broke out.

The transport of phosphate from the factories of the Gafsa Phosphate Company (GIC) to the factories of GCT in Mdhila, Gabes and Skhira was paralyzed by sit-ins organized. The transfer of production from Gafsa to the commercial port of Sfax was also interrupted due to the sit-ins held by many unemployed people in the train station of El Ksar. Similarly, freight and passengers transport by train in the governorate of Gafsa was interrupted following a protest by young unemployed people, particularly in El Ksar and Metlaoui.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The Salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

Security forces began dispersing protests in the Gafsa region of central Tunisia. Protesters had been staging sit-ins in front of the offices of the governorate of Gafsa and elsewhere in the region since one week ago, demanding job opportunities and improvement of their living conditions.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

Clashes and acts of violence continued between the young people of Remada and Dhehiba, especially at the locality of ""Ouni"", located between the two cities and which was the scene of exchange of shots.

In Sfax, a sit-in was held by Club Sportif Sfaxien fans against the use of teargas against fans leaving a stadium in Sousse.

On December 26th some Tunisians protested in front of the Tunisian Ministry of Foreign Affairs after the announcement of the appointment of Rafik Abdessalem as Minister of Foreign Affairs.

Dozens of ISIE employees who formally worked for the Tunisian institute that administered the October 23rd Constituent Assembly elections staged a protest in front of the Constituent Assembly when they found themselves laid off from work.

According to a local eyewitness, more than 200 persons peacefully demonstrated in downtown Thala, governorate of Kasserine. Protestors are denouncing the military courts decision to free Colonel Moncef Ladjimi. Ladjimi is accused of being behind the killing that occurred in Kasserine and Thala during last winters uprisings.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

A number of Tunisian human rights groups held a rally to demand that the Constituent Assembly issue a law to criminalise all forms of normalisation of ties between Tunisia and Israel on 30 December.
Environmental groups protested at the Qatari Embassy, urging the new government to curb hunting of endangered species by wealthy citizens of the Arab Gulf. Motivations apolitical.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

A dozen armed Libyans kidnapped four Tunisian gendarmes at the border. Three of the paramilitary police managed to escape, leaving behind one policeman as well as their patrol car and their weapons. The detained policeman sustained bullet wounds on the hands and was released the following day.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

A patrol of Tunisian gendarmes exchanged fire with a Libyan armed group that tried to penetrate Tunisian territory. The assailants were forced to pull back. The event corresponded with the date of President Moncef Marzoukis first diplomatic visit to Libya.

column16: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
column17: Two journalists covering a protest at the Ministry of Higher Education were assaulted by plainclothes police officers. protesters were teachers from Manouba University in Tunis demanding the resumption of classes, which have been stopped all month due to protests against a law preventing women from attending school wearing the niqab.

Hundreds of teachers and students from the Manouba University in Tunis demonstrated for the resumption of classes at the Ministry of Higher Education. Classes have been stalled due to protests asserting women's right to wear the niqab to class; counter-protesters demand government intervention in the Salafist sit-ins.

200 young people staged a sit-in and began throwing stones at security forces in front of the Governate Headquarters to demand jobs as three ministers from Tunisias social affairs, industry and employment ministries visited Gafsa to discuss unemployment. Police responded with tear gas. The riot, which spread to police outposts throughout the city, was sparked by the self-immolation of a 42-year-old unemployed father at the demonstration, who set himself on fire after being refused audience with the ministers . He was airlifted via military helicopter to the Trauma and Burn Center of Ben Arous and succumbed to his wounds January 9.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students ended or changed the location of a weeks-long sit-in that they had staged to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The sit-in at the Deans office lasted from November 28 to January 5 before moving locations in Manouba.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.
A group of bearded men protested in front of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, calling upon the government to push for the release of more than 100 Tunisian prisoners detained in Iraq since 2003.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

column16: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
column17: Journalists were attacked in Tunis, according to the National Syndicate of Tunisian Journalists, who criticized the attacks.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

More than 300 journalists and civil society members demonstrated yesterday outside the government headquarters in the Tunis Casbah to condemn police violence and oppose the recent appointment of new bosses of state media outlets.

Mohamed Taieb Youssefi was named president and chief executive of the state news agency TAP. The agencies journalists organized a sit-in yesterday in front of its offices in protest against his appointment.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

Acvitists from Tunisias internal security forces organized a sit-in to call for the dismisal of the head of internal security, who is associated with the former regime. Protesters affiliated with the majority-party Ennahda assembled in counter-protest.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

One journalist for private broadcaster Nessma TV was assaulted while covering a protest. The attackers were protesters affiliated with the majority-party Al-Nahda, who were assembled in counter-protest against acvitists from Tunisias internal security forces. The assault was perhaps motivated by the journalists past criticism of Al-Nahda.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.
Local protesters put up barricades in the streets of Makthar, a plateau town suffering from unemployment, no running water or gas, and limited infrastructural investment.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

Local protesters maintained barricades put in place on January 13 in the streets of Makthar, a plateau town suffering from unemployment, no running water or gas, and limited infrastructural investment.

Commemorating the anniversary of Tunisias 2011 revolution and outster of former-President Ben Ali, thousands of Tunisians, many of them wearing the red and white of the national flag, turned out in central Tunis calling for jobs and reform. A cluster of protesters wore the black flag of Salafist Islamists.

Agreement: Amnesty or conditional release was granted to 9,000 detainees, including Tunisian and foreign prisoners, in commemoration of the anniversary of Tunisias 2011 revolution. Death sentences against another 122 detainees were commuted to life imprisonment

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer. protesters changed locations of their sit-in today to the universities administrative offices. The sit-in campsite had been previosly held at the Deans office starting November 28 (Radio Mosaique FM).
Riots over poor living conditions and employment took place in the border town of Ghardimaou. 17 rioters were arrested for vandalism and looting.

Local protesters maintained barricades put in place on January 13 in the streets of Makthar, a plateau town suffering from unemployment, no running water or gas, and limited infrastructural investment.

column7: UGET: General Union of Tunisian Students
column9: UGTE: General Tunisian Union of Students
column17: Clashes between members of the General Union of Tunisian Students (UGET) and the Tunisian General Union of Students (UGTE) took place on Monday at the Faculty of Arts and Humanities of Sousse. Several students sustained injuries and have been hospitalized.

A group of more than 50 Salafists occupied the University of Sousse as exams were taking place, triggering clashes between them and other students. Scuffles broke out and stones were hurled, which disrupted exams. Three students were injured and were taken to the nearby hospital.
Tunisians staged protests in a number of cities to bring attention to their ""marginalization and unemployment"" and solving their ""poor social conditions.""

Groups of strikers over poor living conditions and employment blocked access to small communes using tyres and barricades as they demonstrated for jobs, housing and regional development. Schools and several roads were closed.

A prominent journalist for Nessma TV was attacked by a group of 50-60 Salafists protesters who had assembled to voice opposition to Nessma TV executive Nabil Karoui. Karoui stands on trial for airing the controversial film ""Persepolis"" on Nessma TV in October. Karoui faces charges of ""libeling a religion"" and ""distributing or displaying information that can harm public order or good morals.""

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.
protesters blocked roads between El Kef and Jendouba to demosntrate for greater social aid, as well as jobs for unemployed young people in the region. Shops and businesses closed.

Local protesters maintained barricades put in place on January 13 in the streets of Makthar, a plateau town suffering from unemployment, no running water or gas, and limited infrastructural investment.

Groups of strikers over poor living conditions and employment blocked access to small communes using tyres and barricades as they demonstrated for jobs, housing and regional development. Schools and several roads were closed.

A general strike staged by unemployed protesters blocked access to the Bizerte-Nefza, Tabarka-Nefza, and Beja-Nefza access roads, the only thoroughfares through the town. protesters began by demonstrating against marginalization and poverty, but also chanted anti-US and anti-Qatar slogans, which led to clashes with nearby pro-Ennadha civilians. Troops were deployed to prevent looting and violence but no violence was reported.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

Local protesters maintained barricades put in place on January 13 in the streets of Makthar, a plateau town suffering from unemployment, no running water or gas, and limited infrastructural investment.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

Three men affiliated with the Young Democratic Progressive movement were kidnapped and robbed by a group of thirty armed men before escaping. The attackers have not been detained but several were identified as prisoners recently granted general amnesty by Tunisian President Moncef Marzouki.

A group of salafists protested against the ban of niqab (full-face veil) in France. They gathered at the French Embassy in Tunis to defend Hind Ahmas, a Moroccan-French national who was arrested for sporting the full-face veil in public in Meaux (east of Paris) and refusing to remove it.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

column7: Association of the Syrian Diaspora in Tunisia
column17: A group of supporters for the Syrian revolt against Bashar Al-Assad held a demonstration to spread awareness and urge the government to recognize the Syrian National Committee. The supporters were allied with the Association of the Syrian Diaspora in Tunisia and the Tunisian Association for Defending the Syrian Revolution.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

Three journalists (one also a professor of Political Sciences) were kicked and beaten by a group of Salafist demonstrators assembled to protest against a Tunisian television station airing the film ""Persepolis."" Protesters had gathered in front of a courthouse where the flims broadcaster, TV executive Nabil Karoui, stood on trial.

Salafist-inspired protesters comprised mostly of unenrolled students staged a sit-in to demonstrate against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University--a secular, public school--wearing the niqab. The salafist protesters also demanded a place for prayer.

A group of Salafists protested against Nessma TV executive Nabil Karoui on the date of his January 23 trial for ""libeling a religion"" and ""distributing or displaying information that can harm public order or good morals."" They assembled outside the courthouse where Karoui was being tried chanting anti-Secularist slogans. Another group of pro-Nessma demonstrators assembled in counter-protest. The trial was subsequently delayed to April 19.

Police disrupted a sit-in by Salafist-inspired protesters who had been demonstrating since November 28 against a law preventing women from attending Manouba University wearing the niqab. The police deployment followed rioting by some of the demonstrators, who broke down the door of the Arabic department and insulted professors.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2011-2014) National Guard
column17: Gunfire was exchanged between members of the security forces and three armed ""bearded"" gunmen bearing Kalashnikovs. Two of the gunmen died while one escaped, and four men from the Tunisian National Guard and Army were wounded in the skirmish. The incident began when police discovered the armed men in a car in the Talab area. The officers pursued the vehicle and confiscated a cache of weapons and ammunition from the car.

6,000 demonstrators gathered to condemn violent attacks - whether verbal or physical - on citizens, including national figures, politicians, activists, and media figures. The demonstration responded to recent surges in assaults on civilians such as journalists and public figures, which have been sometimes associated with Salafist groups. Many political parties took place in the march, including the PDP, Afek Tounes, and the Republican Party as well as the activist group Citizens Front for Democracy.

A mass of 1,000 people gathered in al-Kasbah square calling for an end to the open strike of the National Union for Security Forces. Protesters claimed that the Unions claims are not legitimate, that the Union does not represent all members of the Police Force, and that police officers endanger citizens by refusing to work. More than 200 supporters of the National Union for Security Forces assembled in counter-protest but ended yesterdays strike.
Sporadic gunfire exchanges erupted between the Tunisian and Libyan border guards at the main border crossing of Ras El Jedir.

150 Militia (Hizb ut-Tahrir) activists - adherents to a strict, conservative interpretation of the Quran, and advocates for the establishment of an Islamic Caliphate - protested against the official visit of the Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) Christine Lagarde. Protesters urged the state to reject all cooperation with European and North American economic partners, advocating an ""Islamic economy.""

Approximately 200 Islamist demonstrators gathered in front of the American Embassy today, to denounce U.S. foreign policy as it pertains to the Muslim world. The demonstrators condemned recent incidents involving the burning of Qurans by NATO forces in Afghanistan and the continued detention of prisoners at the Guantanamo Bay facility.

A large mob of unemployed youth ransacked the district of Gafsa governmental headquarters, pelting the building with stones before destroying its interior offices and burning some of its archives. The demonstrators accused the government of dragging its feet in its response to employment demands and complained against the lead district official. Since January 2012, the government has allocated 350,000 million Tunisian Dinars toward development of the region and alleviating unemployment.

Supporters of workers of the Tunisian Workers Union (UTT) at the Leoni wiring plant in Mateur clashed with police over the arrest of Mohamed Monaem Darragi, Secretary-General of the UTT. The arrest followed tense negotiations between the Leoni company and UTT. Protesters blocked the cities main road and looted a number of supermarkets. Local police intervened, using tear gas to disperse the crowd. Six policemen had been injured by projectiles.

Supporters of workers of the Tunisian Workers Union (UTT) at the Leoni wiring plant in Mateur clashed with police over the arrest of Mohamed Monaem Darragi, Secretary-General of the UTT. Protesters also blocked the road of Bizerte and Menzel Bourguiba as a sign of solidarity with Darragi.

Islamist mosque-goers began rioting near Tunis Place de La Republique after Friday prayer. Rioters were outraged by President Moncef Marzoukis recent comment that supporters of Egyptian cleric Wajdi Ghoneim are ""bacteria"" (Ghoneim apologized for the comment). Police resorted used tear gas bombs to scatter the agitated crowd.

Nearly 700 people gathered in front of Bardo Palace, the seat of Tunisias National Constituent Assembly (NCA), to call for more lenient legislation on marijuana (""zatla"") use; denounce the arrest of Attounissia newsmen on February 15th; and call for job creation. The protest targetted the NCA, Tunisias legislative body in charge of drafting the countries new constitution.
Female employees of the French telecom company Orange were assaulted at a store opening by Salafist religious extremists, who were offended by the women's apparel. Police made several arrests.

A skirmish between a group of Salafists and the Tunisian police erupted after Salafists asked female workers at an Orange telecommunications store to cover their hair with headscarves. The local police had to intervene, leading to clashes in which a police car was damaged. According to the online paper Businessnews, the salafists pulled knives on the police, wounding two officers (unconfirmed). The event follows assaults on female Orange workers for wearing skirts on February 20.

A Salafist mob set fire to the local police station and the branch office of the Congress for the Republic (CPR) political party. Rioters then threw stones at firefighters trying to douse the flames, and police responded with tear gas. An associated group attacked a second police station armed with knives, stones, sticks and Molotov cocktails. Salafists occupied a number of the cities mosques and broadcasted messages calling for an Islamic holy war .The town has lately seen an increase in Salafist rioting and organized attack.

200 or so men occupyied a mosque in downtown Jendouba, using the mosque as a base from which they launched pro-Islamist riots downtown. Bouts of confrontation between rioters and police took place, with police firing teargas canisters and protesters taking refuge intermittently in the mosque.

Police used batons to repel around 300 Protesters as they attempted to storm the venue of the inaugural summit of the ""Friends of Syria,"" an international meeting of 67 countries convened in Tunis to promote humanitarian relief in Syria and support opposition to Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. Protesters opposed Western intervention in Syria and Tunisias complicity in the conference.

Seven attacks on journalists by policeman occurred during a February 25 protest-turned-riot by members of the UGTT, who had assembled at the Ministry of the Interior to demonstrate against recent ransacking of UGTT offices. Police used tear gas to disperse the gathering and assaulted journalists covering the event.

More than 3,000 demonstrators marched toward the Interior Ministry headquarters to express outrage against recent, coordinated acts of vandalism on UGTT offices. The protests condemned Ennadha, the Islamist majority coalition party, for organizing the attacks in order to silence governmental opposition. Security forces attempted to usher the protesters away from the Ministry. After several isolated clashes occurred between police officers and the crowd, the police used to tear gas to disperse the gathering. The Tunisian Communist Workers Party (POCT ) and centre-left ""Ettajid"" party were also present.

Angry crowds burned a police station in the district of Bousalem during the nighttime. The rioters allegedly condemned government inaction in assisting Bousalem residents after severe floods in the district in recent weeks, claiming they were isolated from assistance by road closures. Interior Minister Ali Laarayedh and Prime Minister Hamadi Jebali visited the region.

column7: Association of Martyrs of the Revolution
column17: A group of men and women wounded during the 2010-2011 Tunisian Revolution and their relatives assembled outside the Ministry of Defence to protest against missing compensation. The government earmarked wo rounds of compensation for wounded Revolution veterans, but the second round (declared in January) has yet to be delivered in full, and trials on perpetrators of civilian killing during the reovlution are still underway without verdict.

column7: SNJT: National Union of Tunisian Journalists
column17: The SNJT: National Union of Tunisian Journalists (SNJT) organized a protest against a recent spate of police violence against journalists. The latest incidents occurred on February 25, when police committed at least seven attacks on journalists covering a UGTT protest. The Ministry of the Interior issued an apology, stating that it would launch investigations into the violence.

Demonstrators who claim no political affiliation staged a prolonged sit-in in front of the national public news agency Al Wataniya. Protesters accuse journalists affiliated with the network of having a left-wing bias and underreporting positive government activity. They advocated for clearing up the media sector, which, according to them, is still plagued by remnants of the corruption of the former regime.

A demonstration was held in opposition to Prime Minister Hamadi Jebalis recent controversial remarks about the General Union of Tunisian Workers (UGTT). Jebali called the UGTT a band of""Ben Ali militias"" intent on disrupting governmental stability after they assembled to protest against Ennadha vandalism of UGTT offices.

Hundreds of trade unionists, representatives of several political parties and civil society organisations and citizens took part in a popular rally and peaceful march near the regional section of the Tunisian General Labour Union (UGTT) in Sousse. The crowd protested against ""attacks"" against the UGTT in recent weeks, including comments from Interim Prime Minister Hamadi Jebali implying that the UGTT was supported by regional militias.

Demonstrators who claim no political affiliation staged a prolonged sit-in in front of the national public news agency Al Wataniya. Protesters accuse journalists affiliated with the network of having a left-wing bias and underreporting positive government activity. They advocated for clearing up the media sector, which, according to them, is still plagued by remnants of the corruption of the former regime.

Demonstrators who claim no political affiliation staged a prolonged sit-in in front of the national public news agency Al Wataniya. Protesters accuse journalists affiliated with the network of having a left-wing bias and underreporting positive government activity. They advocated for clearing up the media sector, which, according to them, is still plagued by remnants of the corruption of the former regime.

Protesters accuse journalists affiliated with the network of having a left-wing bias and underreporting positive government activity. They advocated for clearing up the media sector, which, according to them, is still plagued by remnants of the corruption of the former regime.

Protesters accuse journalists affiliated with the network of having a left-wing bias and underreporting positive government activity. They advocated for clearing up the media sector, which, according to them, is still plagued by remnants of the corruption of the former regime.
Two men attacked an officer in Ghardimaou.

column9: UGET: General Union of Tunisian Students
column17: Clashes between Salafist demonstrators and the student union erupted at the University of Manouba when Salafist students began protesting against a violent incident the previous day. In the incident, two niqab-wearing female students, who had been suspended for six months for participating in earlier riots, broke into the deans office and damaged files as well as windows. The students claim they were kicked and beaten by the dean. The dean denies these accusations, and the case is under investigation. Five were injured and three were hospitalized in the resulting student clashes until police arrived to restore calm.

Demonstrators who claim no political affiliation staged a prolonged sit-in in front of the national public news agency Al Wataniya. Protesters accuse journalists affiliated with the network of having a left-wing bias and underreporting positive government activity. They advocated for clearing up the media sector, which, according to them, is still plagued by remnants of the corruption of the former regime.

Two bearded men suspected of being Salafists violently attacked an officer at the police security station in Ghardimaou using sticks and paralysing gas. The event follows another attack on an officer in the same area the previous day. The officer was hospitalized.

Demonstrators who claim no political affiliation staged a prolonged sit-in in front of the national public news agency Al Wataniya. Protesters accuse journalists affiliated with the network of having a left-wing bias and underreporting positive government activity. They advocated for clearing up the media sector of corruption.

Demonstrators who claim no political affiliation staged a prolonged sit-in in front of the national public news agency Al Wataniya. Protesters accuse journalists affiliated with the network of having a left-wing bias and underreporting positive government activity. They advocated for clearing up the media sector of corruption.

Demonstrators who claim no political affiliation staged a prolonged sit-in in front of the national public news agency Al Wataniya. Protesters accuse journalists affiliated with the network of having a left-wing bias and underreporting positive government activity. They advocated for clearing up the media sector of corruption.

Demonstrators who claim no political affiliation staged a prolonged sit-in in front of the national public news agency Al Wataniya. Protesters accuse journalists affiliated with the network of having a left-wing bias and underreporting positive government activity. They advocated for clearing up the media sector of corruption.

Demonstrators who claim no political affiliation staged a prolonged sit-in in front of the national public news agency Al Wataniya. Protesters accuse journalists affiliated with the network of having a left-wing bias and underreporting positive government activity. They advocated for clearing up the media sector of corruption.

column7: FNAI: Tunisian Front of Islamic Associations
column17: Around 4,000 people gathered in front of the National Constituent Assembly, calling for the implementation of Shariaa law in the new constitution. Tunisia completed a provisional constitution in December is and currently drafting a new constitution, to be completed around the middle of next year.
Thousands staged a demonstration today in Habib Bourguiba Street in order to protest against Islamicism in government and express their commitment to a secular state.
Residents of Sidi Bou Zid protested against water shortages. The local water company did not pay its electrical bill and therefore ceased sending water to the cities residents.
Residents of Sidi Bou Zid protested against water shortages. The local water company did not pay its electrical bill and therefore ceased sending water to the cities residents.

Residents of Sidi Bou Zid protested against water shortages. The local water company did not pay its electrical bill and therefore ceased sending water to the cities residents. Additionally, protests were inspired by allegedly derogatory comments made by the Minister of Higher Education regarding Sidi Bou Zid request to build a college in the town.

Educated unemployed youth organized by the Union for Unemployed Graduates (UDC) demonstrated across the country in front of the regional bureaus and head offices for employment. They demanded the government annul the Amal subvention, which allocates 200 dinars per month to unemployed graduates, and channel its funds instead towards job creation, the creation of a National Fund for Unemployment, and investment in the private sector.

An Al-Jazeera reporter was kicked in the knees and abused at a multi-party political conference while covering the event. The National Association of Bourguibist Thoughts organized the gathering to call for unity in Tunisias opposition political parties, many of which were present. The journalist received an official invitation to the event but was evicted from the rally shortly after being attacked.
Salafists organized at the Clock Tower in central Tunis to protest against threats to the Koran they perceived from secular elements of Tunisian society.

Salafist demonstrators attacked a crowd assembled at the Municipal Theatre to celebrate the World Day of Theatre. The Salafists first organized a protest to oppose threats to the Koran from secular elements of Tunisian society. A group diverged and attacked the theatre celebration, damaging equipment, disrupting outdoor performances, and throwing eggs, empty bottles and sharp objects at those celebrating theater.
At least 8,000 Islamists staged a mass demonstration in central Tunis to demand the adoption of Islamic (sharia) law by the Tunisian government.

column7: Association of Martyrs of the Revolution
column17: The wounded of the Tunisian Revolution staged a sit-in at Tunisias transitional justice ministry inside the gates of the Ministry of Human Rights and Transitional Justice. They demanded greater attention to injuries and medical care from the government, as well as speedier resolution of trials of those involved in killings during the revolution.
The wounded of the Tunisian Revolution staged a sit-in at Tunisias transitional justice ministry inside the gates of the Ministry of Human Rights and Transitional Justice.

Eight unidentified men wearing green uniforms of the Tunisian National Guard pushed and verbally assaulted a group of the wounded of the Tunisian Revolution, who were staging a protest inside the gates of the Ministry of Human Rights and Transitional Justice. The spokesman for the ministry of the interior denied that National Guard agents entered the area, though he could not explain the uniforms.

A land dispute between two clans killed one and injured seven, and subsequently led to the burning of a number of houses and a local police station in the region of El Ksar. Some claim the Tunisian arouchiya (clan system) in Gafsa has been coopted for political purposes in order to distract from unemployment problems in the area.

Security Measures: The Tunisian Ministry of the Interior announced a curfew in the region of El Ksar, in the Governorate of Gafsa, in the wake of deadly violence that killed one, injured seven, and led to the destruction of public offices on March 27.

Over 1,000 people gathered in front of the National Constituent Assembly (NCA) to show their support of the Palestinian cause on ""Land Day"" and to take a stand against the normalization of relations with Israel. March 30, Land Day, is the day the Arab World commemorates the confrontation between Palestinians and Israeli security forces in 1976 that killed six Palestinians.
Security Measures: President of Tunisia (2011-) extends state of emergency until end of April 2012, in place since deposed President Zein El Abdine Ben Ali fled country last year.
Security Measures: Ministry of the Interior issues a ban on demonstrations in Habib Bourguiba Avenue, Tunis.
Police Forces of Tunisia (2011-) clash with 40 Rioters (Tunisia), protesting outside the Ministry of Human Rights. Rioters threw stones, injuring 4 policemen & police used batons.

column9: Students (Tunisia); UGTE: General Tunisian Union of Students

Ali belhouane and Mongi Slim lead a large protest in the afternoon.

Merchants hold rally in Tunis in support of ban of protests on main avenue.

Members of the opposition in the Constituent National Assembly hold a peaceful march in Habib Bourguiba street in the direction of the Interior Ministry, demanding the cancellation of Interior Ministry ban on protests.
12 protesters (Tunisia) gathered at a local Islamist Ennahda party headquarters, climbed the roof but failed to enter the building. Police Forces of Tunisia (2011-) arrested 6.

ransacking of privately-owned TV station El Hiwar Ettounsi in the northwestern Tunis suburb of Manouba on the night of 26 May. Some equipment destroyed and removed, cash left suggests group was trying to stop the activities of the station.

owners of hotels and bars which sell alcoholic beverages took to the streets of Jendouba today to protest against the repeated violence by Salafis

violent clashes broke out between policemen and hundreds of protestors. Rioters attacked the police station and policemen, throwing stones and setting up road-blocks on the Tunis-Beja highway.

A leader of Tunisias centrist, liberal Republican Party, Ahmed Nejib Chebbi, told Al-Jazeera on 13 July a group of Salafi Islamist youths attacked him while he was travelling by car in the northwest and injured the driver.

Police fired warning shots and tear gas Thursday to disperse protesters who attacked provincial government headquarters. Demonstrators also tried to torch the local headquarters of the ruling Islamist party Ennahda, after some of them broke down the door and sacked the offices.

Hundreds of Tunisians protested outside the interim parliament on Tuesday against a bill that would compensate partisans of the ruling Islamist party Ennahda who suffered under the countries former leaders.

Security forces dispersed demonstrators, activists and bloggers using batons excessively to assault the demonstrators. Moreover, the security forces attacked number of journalists verbally

dozens of protesters demanding compensation for their victims of the revolution of 2011 succeeded in entering the courtyard of the governorate (prefecture) shouting slogans against the government.
police dispersed with tear gas demonstrators protesting against the lack of water. 7 people were arrested.

Detonation: A suicide bomber blew himself up in the resort city of Sousse. There were no other casualties or material damage.
A man arrested in Bab Jedid died in custody an hour later. Injuries on body point to abuse.

Military operations continue on Chaambi Sammama mountains and where the ""militants"" have been hiding for over three months. Aerial bombardments also occurred.
