Security forces intervened Sunday morning to lift the sit-in observed since last May 31 by a group of unemployed people at the industrial zone in Gabes, blocking the railway used to carry phosphate from production units of the Tunisian Chemical Group (GCT). The police used tear gas to disperse a group of youth who attempted to attack them by throwing stones. Efforts were made by the local authorities to lift the sit-in through dialogue but some sit-inners were determined to continue their protest.

Tourism sector workers staged a sit-in outside the Tourism regional offices to protest against the illegitimate layoff of 2500 workers after the attack on Marhaba hotel. They demanded protection from the State.
In application of the new anti-terrorism law, police forces shut down an irregular mosque in Mahdia. Police resorted to the use of force to enforce the decision.

Clashes erupted in Hajeb El Ayoun between ""El Anizet"" et ""Ouled Saied"" tribal groups. After a confrontation between children, violence caused damages to some cafes and light injuries to a few young people.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: A security operation confronted a special unit of the National Guard supported by the National Army with an armed group holed up in mount Ourbata in the governorate of Gafsa. Five militants were killed, while four Kalashnikovs, one Steyr, a gun were seized during this operation in addition to some ammunitions, mobile phones, documents and large sums of money. During the operation, military forces killed Mourad Gharsalli, senior leader of Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade.
The army carried out bombardements in Jebel Ouergha area, following the detection of militants.

The Tunisian-Libyan border crossing at Ras Ajdir was again open today [21 July] after being closed yesterday [20 July] on the Libyan side because of protests in the nearby Tunisian town of Ben Guerdane. Demonstrators there had blocked the main road with salt, angry at the Tunisian governments construction of a fence and trench along the border.
A sit-in was staged by the youth of El Faouar outside the offices of an oil company. Protesters demanded the redistribution of oil revenues.
Civil society organisations and members of trade unions in the public health sector staged a sit-in outside the hospital of Tozeur to denounce the poor conditions in the hospital.

During a series of anti-militant raids carried out by Tunisian authorities in the northern province of Bizerte, one militant was killed and sixteen arrested. The first operation began early Thursday in the town of Sejnane. Police surrounded the area, arresting 13 people and killing one man who opened fire on them. Tunisian media identified the man killed as a member of the banned Ansar al-Shariah movement who later pledged allegiance to the Islamic State group.
A police officer was wounded after being shot by unknown young people on a motorbike. The attack on the police patrol took place on Saturday in Zaouiet Sousse.

An investigation was announced on August 10, 2015, into allegations by five recently released detainees of abuse by the counterterrorism police. The men, who were arrested on July 27, filed formal torture complaints upon their release on August 4, only to be re-arrested later that day by the counterterrorism police. The lawyer said that when he saw the detainees for the first time on August 4 in court, five of them bore visible injuries that they said were the result of torture.
A military man was wounded on Thursday in the explosion of a mine in the way of their military vehicle in the closed military zone on Mount Semmama in Sbeitla.
TCitizens of Maztouria organised a sit-in and blocked the road between their town and tataouine to denounce the interruption of water supply in the region.
Movement of forces: Army units have launched a military operation on Mount Ouergha.
The citizens of Salakta organised a protest outside the offices of the local water supply company to denounce the lack of drinkable water in their area.
Some thirty farmers from Kebili protested outside the Ministry of Agriculture against the increase of the salinity rate in the water of a well used for agricultural purposes.
Interruption of water supply fuelled protests in Redeyef, governorate of Gafsa

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column16: AFP; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Jawhara
column17: A suspected Algerian jihadist was shot dead in western Tunisia near the Algerian border. The killing occurred during an ambush staged by police special forces on Sunday night on Mount Sammama in the Kasserine region. Citing security sources, Jawhara FM reports that the militant killed was known as ""Haroun lAlgerien"", a prominent member of AQIM-linked Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade.
Police fired teargas to disperse a sit-in staged by shepherds in Sidi Bouzid. The crowd gathered on Monday to protest against meat imports from abroad.
Fishermen blocked the port of Kerkennah with their boats to claim the right to benefit from state subsidies, even in case of conviction for unauthorised fishing.

Clashes occurred in the town of Menzel Bouzayane, Sidi Bouzid, between police and inhabitants of the village of Itizaz. Police forces used teargas to disperse the protesters, who threw stones on agents. The clashes erupted due to a row between farmers and locals.

Traders in Ben Gardane region rallied on the road that connects Ben Gardane to the border post of Ras Ajdir to protest against the restrictive measures taken by the Libyan government on border crossing.
Police opened fire on a suspected vehicle that refused to stop at a check-in near the closed area of Jebel Semmama. A woman was killed and a man wounded.
A protest movement was organised in Bizerte against alcohol sale in a shopping centre. The sale of alcohol in this shopping centre had been interrupted since the revolution in 2011.
The OCTT reports a case of torture occurred in Gafsa, where a man was reportedly tortured in a police station.
Two soldiers were killed by a landmine in western Tunisia near the Algerian border. The event occurred in Ain Jaffel near the closed military area of Jebel Mghilla on Monday.

column7: SGEB: General Union of Primary Education; Teachers (Tunisia)
column17: Police fired teargas on teachers protesting in Sidi Bouzid

column7: SGEB: General Union of Primary Education; Teachers (Tunisia)
column17: Police fired teargas on teachers protesting in Sfax
A Tunisian official says two men on a moped opened fire with a rifle on three policemen in the resort town Sousse, killing one and wounding the other two

The youth of El Faouar, Kebili region, decide to resume their sit-in outside the offices of the ""Perenco"" gas company. The protesters denounce the failed application of the agreements concluded with local authorities. In particular, the agreements envisaged the creation of an environment agency to create jobs and reduce unemployment in the region.

column7: SGEB: General Union of Primary Education; Teachers (Tunisia)
column17: A group of teachers protested in Beja against the use of violence on their colleague teachers in other Tunisian cities.

column7: SGEB: General Union of Primary Education; Teachers (Tunisia)
column17: Police fired teargas on teachers protesting in Gabes

column7: UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union; SGEB: General Union of Primary Education
column17: A protest march launched by the UGTT to denounce the excessive use of force by the police was staged in Sidi Bouzid.

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) Border Guards
column17: A Tunisian border guard was killed and three others wounded in a shootout with jihadists on the border with Algeria. Al-Qaidah-affiliated Okba Ben Nafaa battalion has claimed responsibility for the attack.

column16: Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Tunisie Numerique
column17: Looting: A group of fifteen militants - presumably hiding in the mountainous area of Jebel Ouergha - raided two private houses in Ouled Slimane, near Sakiet Sidi Youssef.
An imam was killed by suspected Islamist militants in Jebel Semmama.
Protesters have temporarily seized a bus of SNTRI and one of the regional transports company to draw attention of the lack of infrastructure in the region.

Police in the Tunisian capital prevented demonstrators protesting against a controversial economic reconciliation bill from marching. Protestors, who were trying to reach Habib Bourguiba Avenue in the centre of Tunis, gathered near the headquarters of the UGTT, the countries main trade union. The police later dispersed the protest.

column7: UTAP: Tunisian Union of Agriculture and Fishing
column17: Farmers and fishermen staged a sit-in outside the offices of UTAP. Protesters tried to reach the Ministry of Agriculture when they were confronted by soldiers and police.
Students parents and teachers protested against the closing of a primary school in Ouzra.

column16: Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Tunisie Numerique
column17: Looting: A group of militants - presumably hiding in the mountainous area of Jebel Ouergha - looted a house in the locality of Douar Ouled Ayar, near Sakiet Sidi Youssef.
Protesters gathered, Thursday evening, outside the Tunis municipal theatre in Habib Bourguiba avenue to protest against the economic reconciliation bill.
A group of people supporting one of the imams dismissed by the government in Sfax staged a protest and disrupted the worship in the cities Grand Mosque.
Clashes erupted between police and rioters over the opening of an alcohol shop
Police dispersed a demonstration against a proposed reconciliation bill firing teargas and beating people with batons. Several young people were arrested, while others wounded.
An unidentified armed group attacked a grocery in Ain Nemcha, near Jebel Ouergha.
A sit-in organised by UDC was held in Sidi Bouzid to demand social justice, express opposition against the proposed reconciliation bill and denounce governmental repression.
A sit-in against the reconciliation bill was organised in Tozeur.
Tunisian authorities banned a sit-in organised against the proposed reconciliation bill. The police used force after requesting that the demonstrators leave the area. No injuries reported.
A demonstration against the draft reconciliation bill was dispersed in Jendouba by police who did not use force.
A demonstration was staged in Kebili by rural transport drivers, who protested against the aggression perpetrated by police on one of their colleagues.

column7: SGEB: General Union of Primary Education; Teachers (Tunisia)
column17: Teachers organised a strike at the Ministry of Education in Tunis to demand the resolution of the problems in the educational sector.

Arrests: In Beja, Tunisian police forces have arrested one of the leaders of Ansar al Sharia in north-west Tunisia of Ansar al Sharia, who was wanted by police since 2012 and linked with the September 14, 2012 attack on the US embassy in Tunis.
Demonstrations against the national reconciliation bill were held in several Tunisian towns, including Sfax, Gafsa and Tataouine.
Demonstrations against the national reconciliation bill were held in several Tunisian towns, including Sfax, Gafsa and Tataouine.
Hundreds of Tunisians defied a state of emergency protests ban on Saturday to demonstrate against a controversial draft law on amnesty for corruption offences.
Demonstrations against the national reconciliation bill were held in several Tunisian towns, including Tunis, Sfax, Gafsa and Tataouine.
Residents of El Faouar staged a sit-in and threatened to boycott the beginning of the academic year to denounce the degradated situation of the local schools premises.

Residents of Borgine, in Sousse province, blocked two roads that connect Tunis with Sfax disrupting the circulation of vehicles to demand enhanced infrastructure and denounce the lack of development strategies in the region.

column7: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Movement of forces: Military forces, together with the National Guard, conducted combing operations in Jebel Mghilla (Kasserine side, near Ain Zayen in the delegation of Sbiba) and in the mountains of Le Kef. The patrols revealed significant shelters and camps where militants trained and hid their arms and ammunition. Security agents confiscated weapons, that seem to be used by the Tunisian army before, food, and clothing items

column17: A group of teachers members of the General Union of Primary Education staged a sit-in at the Ministry of Education.

column7: UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union; SGEB: General Union of Primary Education; Health Workers (Tunisia)
column17: Second day of protest in Sfax hospital following the appointment of a military man as new director of the structure.

column7: RATTA: Association for the Rescue of Tunisians Arrested Abroad
column17: Members of RATTA marched in protest in Tunis to demand the repatriation of Tunisian citizens arrested in Syria.
Looting: An unidentified armed group composed of 7-10 people stormed three private houses in Gargour. After the raid, the assailants escaped in the mountains.

column7: SGEB: General Union of Primary Education; Teachers (Tunisia)
column17: During the second day of strike, about fifty primary school teachers staged a protest outside the offices of the regional commission for education.
The OCTT reports a second case of torture involving a young man from Mornaguia, who was assaulted by four police officers. He reportedly had his fingers fractured.
Workers of the Monastir International Airport gathered in protest outside the offices of the airports director. They claimed that their salaries were not paid.

column7: SGEB: General Union of Primary Education
column17: A sit-in organised by SGEB is on-going in Jendouba. He demonstration reportedly started on September 18th.
Journalists of Essour staged a protest outside the offices of their newspaper, claiming that their salaries were not paid.

column17: A sit-in organised by SGEB is on-going in Jendouba. He demonstration reportedly started on September 18th.

column7: SGEB: General Union of Primary Education
column17: SGEB promote sit-ins in Tunis Kebili and Jendouba. In Kebili, the demonstration was interrupted on September 23th.
Residents of Kasserine protest over water shortages.

column7: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Looting: A broad combing operation was launched by Tunisias military forces on Mount Ouergha following the explosion of a landmine and the looting of some private houses in the area.
Residents of Oulad M'hamed blocked the route in sign of protest after the killing of a man and his wife in the region.
Protests in the education sector extend to Beja, where a number of teachers staged a sit-in outside the regional offices for education.
Protests continue in the Habib Bourguiba hospital in Sfax while the new director takes office.
A landmine exploded in the area of Forchene, near Mount Ouergha, on the path of a cattle herd without causing victims.
Farmers from Bouhlel, Tozeur et Hamma staged a sit-in outside the governorate of Tozeur to demand investment on farming equipment.

Defusal: Military engineering units defused two car bombs intercepted Wednesday at dawn in the buffer zone of Larzet, Remada. The explosive-laden cars were also carrying weapons and ammunition, including ten Kalashnikov rifles, grenades, ammunition boxes, Libyan telephones cards and documents with Islamic State symbol.
A demonstration was held outside the tribunal of Kasserine to demand the immediate release of a man arrested for having constructed an artisanal missile.

The chief of the Hassi El Ferid district was assaulted by a man and hospitalised in La Marsa. The attacker hit the local administrator on a motorbike, causing several injuries on the hand, the leg and the chest. The reasons of the attack were not clear yet.
Tunisian airforce bombed the mountains of Jebel Ouergha.
Security Measures: The state of emergency imposed in Tunisia after the June attack on foreign tourists in Sousse is lifted on October 2
In Zarzis, rioters violently clashed with police forces following the death of two young men hit by a police vehicle.
Doctors organised a sit-in outside the hospital of Mahdia to protest against recent attacks carried out by a patient.
Workers staged a protest outside UGTT offices in Sfax to demand a pay rise.
A man reportedly died in prison after being tortured by police.
Nesrine Hamdi, a journalist, staged a sit-in outside the offices of El Hiwar Ettounsi to protest against her recent firing.
A demonstration was held in Mahdia as workers of ""mechanism 16"" demanded the regularisation of their contractual situation.
Police fired teargas to disperse a crowd that protested over the death of a man in prison. The protesters shot gunfires and set tyres on fire.
Unidentified gunmen fired multiple shots at Ridha Charfeddine, a Tunisian sports magnate and Nidaa Tounes MP, on Thursday.
A group of teachers marched from Kairouan to Ben Arous to protest against the failed recognition of their degrees. The march started on November 10th and ended five days later.
A group of workers protested outside the offices of the Regional Labour Union to demand the resumption of negotiations among social actors.

A group of traders staged a peaceful sit-in in Ben Gardane blocking the national route leading to Ras Ajdir to protest against the decision by Libyan authorities to limit the circulation across the border.

Two Tunisian soldiers were killed and four wounded in a clash with the Tunisian branch of Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb. During a search operation following the kidnapping of a shepherd, the militants hiding out on Mount Sammama opened fire on the soldiers.
A shepherd was kidnapped and executed on Monday by a group of armed men allegedly belonging to Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade. The militant group accused the shepherd of being a spy.
Unidentified militants tried to rob a house near Mazrek Eshames, Sbeitla province. The group assaulted the owner of the house and cut his sons tongue.
Relatives of Tunisian citizens detained in Sabratha, Libya, protested in front of the police station in the small town of El Ayoun.
Tourist guides protested outside the National Office of Tunisian Tourism (ONTT) for the degradation of their working conditions after the two attacks against foreign nationals in March and June.

Violent clashes were reported in Kairouan, after that a group of young people assaulted the local police office in an attempt to free a friend jailed for drug dealing. The police fired shots in the air to disperse the rioters. 5 youths were arrested.
Property destruction: A young armed Islamist was arrested for having thrown a molotov cocktail into the house of a Civil Protection officer in Bou Omrane. No injuries reported.
Taxi drivers protested outside the Ministry of Transport against penalties inflicted on colleagues who did not shave.
Residents of El Griss, in El Meknassi, closed the doors of the school Ennour to protests against the continuing lack of personnel in the school.

Prayers of Allakhmi mosque in Sfax have prevented the new imam from starting the ceremony. The imam replaced Ridha Jaouadi, dismissed by a decree of the Minister for Religious Affaires. The protesters also waived placards and chanted slogans against the minister and the imam.
Truck drivers and citizens staged a sit-in in Gremda to protest against the bad conditions of the roads in the area.
Primary school teacher staged a sit-in outside the SGEB offices to protest against the unions position in the negotiations with the Ministry.
A march was held in Sfax against the dismissal of several imams. The demonstration was organised by the Tunisian Labour Organisation (OTT) with a large deployment of police forces.

Citizens opposed to the decision of dimissing the imam of Lakhmi mosque in Sfax staged a protest movement outside the offices of the governorate. Members of trade unions and Ennahda also took part in the rally. Police was deployed, but no violence reported.

Protests were reported in Ben Gardane, where demonstrators gathered blocking trucks going to Libya through the border post of Ras Ajdir. Protesters lamented the limitations imposed by Libyan authorities on border crossing.
Tax drivers protested outside the governorate of Tunis against the relocation of a parking area for collective taxis.
A protest was held outside the Tunisian National TV to demand the dismissal of the general director Mustapha Ben Letaief, accused of mismanagement and poor planning.
Protests against the dismissal of imams moved to Tunis. A sit-in was organised outside the Ministry for Religious Affairs.
The families of two journalists kidnapped in Libya started a protest march in El Ksar, near Gafsa. They are directed towards Ras Ajdir, on the Libyan border.
The UDC staged a demonstration in Place de la Kasbah to draw attention on the condition of the unemployed in Tunisia.
Clashes between police and demonstrators in Sfax following an attempt to stop the Friday prayer.
During a sit-in in Kebili, farmers and date producers demand the authorisation for direct sale in the Libyan market.
A sit-in was organised near the oil plant of Sidi El Kilani. Protesters claim their part of the oil revenues. The police intervene and arrest 15 demonstrators.
Several political parties, trade unions and NGOs organised a demonstration in Sfax to show solidarity with the Palestinians.
Date producers blocked access to Kebili to protest against restrictions on export towards Libya.

Self harm and psychological intervention: A Tunisian customs officer has died after setting himself on fire. The 54-year-old died in Monastir. The man had sprayed his uniform with petrol and set himself alight outside a hotel in the touristic area of the eastern coastal city.

column7: UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union; Journalists (Tunisia)
column17: Workers in the National Office for Television Broadcast demonstrated in Tunis to demand the adoption of a law that would regularise their position.
Doctors in Kebili hospital staged a protest for being target of violence.

Al Qaeda-linked Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade claimed in a video released on the internet the execution of another shepherd suspected of being an informant for the police. The episode took place in the heights of Kassar, in Jebel Ouergha.
Residents of Cite Oued Baassatine protested outside the governorate of Beja to demand the completion of a housing project in the area.

A group of citizens of Bir Djemila blocked the circulation on the route connecting Ben Gardane with Ras Ajdir. The sit-in took place during the visit of the governor of Medenine in sign of protest against the imposition of limitations on cross-border petrol trade.
Journalists of Tounesna protested outside their channels offices against the ""illegal"" dismissal of several of their colleagues.

For the third consecutive Friday, hundreds of Muslim militants close to OTT staged a protest outside Sidi Lakhmi mosque in Sfax, to express their opposition to the decision of dismissing the imam Ridha Jaouadi. Jaouadi was released from prison this week.
Hundreds of demonstrators gathered in Tunis to demand an increase in their salaries, while negotiations between UGTT (Tunisias main labour union) and UTICA (an employers organization) continue.
A group of Nidaa Tounes party members armed with sticks - allegedly supporters of Hafedh Caid Essebsi - blocked the entrance of a party conference beating up other people trying to enter.
A group of citizens blocked the entrance of the bus station in Ettadhamen neighbourhood in Tunis to voice their discontent with the service.
On Monday, Mahdia witnessed the protests of a group of employees in the tourism sector, who claimed their salaries.
Technical workers staged a protest against violence in Kasserine. Exact location not known.
Police forces protest nationwide and call the government to accept their requests.
Date producers continue their protest in Kebili against the decrease in the price of dates.
Taxi drivers protst in Djerba against the indefference of local authorities.

Fourth consecutive week of protest in Sfax, where a group of worshippers loyal to imam Ridha Jouadi attempted to disrupt the Fridays prayer. During the contestation, slogans against the new imam and the Ministry of Religious Affairs were chanted.

Hundreds of Tunisians, including political figures, gathered in the capital Saturday for a demonstration called by the Islamist party Ennahda in support of the Palestinian ""uprising"" against Israel. The demonstrators assembled under close police surveillance in the cities main thoroughfare, Bourguiba Avenue, waving Tunisian and Palestinian flags as well as that of the Palestinian Islamist movement Hamas.
Vendors of tobacco staged a protest in Kebili following a recent shortage of cigarettes in the area.

Armed Islamist hiding in the heights of Kasserine intercepted two shepherds on Mount Meghila and cut off the head of one and handed it to the other to return to his family. The shepherds had allegedly came close to the hideouts of the armed group in Jebel Mghila.
High school pupils protested in Lassouda to demand that the local administration puts in place a new bus service after an incident where another young student was seriously injured.
Popular Current party called a demonstration to support the Palestinian people in Tunis.

An armed militant was killed and several others were wounded, three of them seriously, in clashes between national army units and a group of militants on Mount Mghilla in Sidi Bouzid. A soldier was also killed during the clashes.
Some of the participants to the funerals of the young shepherd killed by armed Islamists in Jebel Mghila staged a protest against insecurity and demanded development programs for the region.
According to Mosaique FM, Tunisian aviation bombed Jebel Mghila after having discovered the presence of militants in the area.
A rally took place, on Monday out the municipal theatre in Tunis, to protest against the recent attacks in Tunisia, Lebanon and France.
Residents of Azib region blocked the route connecting Bizerte and Alya to raise attention on the degradating environmental situation in the region.
Petrol smugglers protested after the closure of the border with Libya
Students and teachers went on strike and staged sit-in in Mghilla.
Mechants from Ali Bey protested in Haffouz setting tyres on fire against the seizure of their merchandise.
Looting: A group of armed Islamist hiding in the heights of Mghila raided a private house in Ain Madour. The owner was assaulted but did not report any injury, according to a local source.

column7: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Movement of forces: The army and the national guard conducted searching operations in Jebel Trozza, Kairouan province. Armed militants are reportedly hiding in the region.
Fifteen unemployed graduates started a protest march in Kasserine. The demonstrators aim to reach Tunis.
The daughter of a National Guard officer from Kesra region was assaulted by an alleged Salafist. The young girl was hospitalised.
The UGTT launched a strike in Sfax. The trade union declared that 100% of UGTT employees in the private sector adhered to the protest movement. A march was organized in the city.
Movement of forces: Combing operations took place in Jebel Serj.
Protests were recorded during the Friday prayer in Sfax over the dismissal of the former imam.
Looting: Four armed men pillaged a house in Sbeitla region and stole food and other material. These gunmen are allegedly members of militant organisation hiding in the neighbouring mountainous areas.
A group of residents from Ait Medaouer staged a demonstration to demand more security.

column9: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) Presidential Security Unit
column17: An explosion has torn through a bus full of members of the Tunisian presidential guard in downtown Tunis, killing 12 soldiers and the attacker. The suicide bomber was identified as 27-year-old local street vendor named Houssam ben Hedi ben Miled Abdelli, and known with the militant name of Abou Abdallah al-Tounissi. 20 people were also wounded in the attack, which was later claimed by the IS.

column7: SGEB: General Union of Primary Education; Teachers (Tunisia)
column17: SGEB organised sit-ins nationwide to demand that the governments respects the agreements concerning primary education teachers.
Citizens marched in Sidi Bouzid to express their solidarity with the military officers killed in the Tunis attack on Tuesday.

Arrests: More than one hundred suspected militants were put under house arrest as part of security steps taken since 12 members of the presidential guards were killed in a suicide attack earlier this week. The Interior Ministry, which is in charge of security in Tunisia, said that the 138 included 44 members of the now-outlawed Ansar al-Sharia and two hardline Islamist militants, who have recently returned home from ""hotspots,"" a reference to Syria, Iraq and Libya. The arrests took place in Tunis, Gafsa, Kairouan, Bizerte, Cap Bon, Medenine and Sousse, where a militant cell named al-Furqan (The Criterion) Battalion was dismantled.
Citizens marched in Tozeur to express their solidarity with the military officers killed in the Tunis attack on Tuesday.
Residents of Gafsa protest against the recent attacks in Tunis.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Weapons Seizure: A weapon and ammunition cache was discovered on Monday night in Akouda, Governorate of Sousse. The operation conducted by the National Unit of Research in Terror Crimes under the National Guard in El Aouina, in co-ordination with special units of the National Guard, is part of the ongoing campaign to dismantle militant brigade ""Al Forqan,"" active in the region of Sousse.

Police used teargas to disperse striking workers in Sfax.

Traders set tyres on fire and blocked the route leading to Ras Ajdir to protest against the limitations on circulation across the border.
Protest in Ras Ajdir area and Dehiba the Libyan authorities decision to impose limitations on cross-border passages.

Protest in Ras Ajdir area and Dehiba the Libyan authorities decision to impose limitations on cross-border passages. In Dehiba, protesters marched toward the offices of the local delegation.

Teachers in Montfleury gathered in protest after some of their colleagues were assaulted by pupils.
The road connecting Ben Gardane and Ras Jedir was blocked by cross-border traders on Wednesday afternoon.
Taxi drivers struck and protested in Jendouba against the introduction of a new bus service in town.
Roadblocks were erected on the road connecting Ben Gardane and the border post of Ras Ajdir for five days to obstacle the circulation of Libyan trucks.
A few dozen protesters gathered in front of the governors office calling for ""Work, freedom and national dignity"" on the 5th anniversary of the 2010-2011 uprising.

A group of farmers protested pouring milk outside the governorate of Jendouba; baker also strike
Residents of Tataouine gathered in the towns main square and protested against the deterioration of healthcare structures in the area.

A protest was staged during the visit of Prime Minister Habib Essid in Tozeur.

Residents have erected roadblocks and disrupted the circulation in the delegation of Sidi Bouzid Ouest, near the villages of Aouled Jalel, Bir Bouzid, Zaafria and Barraka, protesting against the high number of road accidents.
A group of unemployed residents gathered in protest outside the governorate of Gabes demanding the recruitment of 170 young people from the region.
An unknown number of workers in the regional delegation of Agriculture staged a sit-in following a disciplinary sanction inflicted on one of their colleagues.

A group of around 40 workers staged a sit-in outside the governorate of Sfax to demand that the activity of the oil company Weatherford resumed after a strike launched by their colleagues who led to the suspension of work.

Demonstrations which began in Kasserine spread to at least 16 of the 24 Tunisian administrative governorates. Protests have turned violent and could compromise the countries stability. Scuffles erupted and tear gas was used in Sidi Bouzid, Medenine, Siliana, Tozeur, Mahdia, Kef, Sousse, Sfax. Yesterday afternoon, tensions were also running high in Kasserine where demonstrations first began last Saturday. A group of people, who were promised a job in the administration of Siliana, protested outside the municipality to denounce delays in the recruitment process.
A group of young unemployed staged a sit-in and threatened to commit suicide in Mezzouna. Members of the local branch of LTDH intervened to stop the demonstrators from committing any such acts.
Teachers protested in Tataouine against the lack of security.
Some groups staged protests outside the Parliament in Tunis. An unemployed man from Jendouba tried to kill himself during the demonstration.

An off-duty police officer was caught in a crossfire on his way back home. AK-47 shots were fired on his car in the region of Ain Nouba, near Jebel Selloum. The officer was slightly injured and quickly hospitalised in Kasserine.
Residents of the village Sidi Mediene marched in protest to demand the reopening of a factory in their area.
The village of Satfoura saw tensions as residents set tyres on fire and blocked the road protesting against the lack of potable water in the area.
The inhabitants of Djerba protested by blocking trash trucks in their town. They lamented environmental degradation in the area.
Residents of Kelaat el-Andalous went on strike and blocked the access to the town to protest against local authorities.
A day of protest was organised in the delegation of Enfidha.
Doctors in Habib Bourguiba hospital in Sfax went on strike and staged a sit-in on Monday.
Leftist parties held sit-ins in Tunis to demand the recruitment of 174 people who benefitted from an amnesty.
A group of unemployed blocked the entrance to a factory in Jebel Jelloud.
Unemployed staged a sit-in in Sakiet Sidi Youssef demanding jobs.
A group of unemployed blocked the National Route 14 to claim jobs.
Tozeur is witnessing continuing mobilisation. On the twentieth day of a sit-in staged outside the offices of governorate, a march was organised by members of civil society and residents.
Tunisian Telecom workers went on a three-day strike and staged a protest in Tunis on Tuesday.

Residents protested for two days in El Amra after a child was killed in a car accident. The first day a general strike was observed in town. The second day protesters set tyres on fire and erected roadblocks.
A march started in Gafsa last week ended in Tunis on Wednesday with a rally in the city centre.
Protesters chanted slogans and demanded that the governor of Gafsa resigns. A few days later, the Prime Minister dismissed the local governor.

column7: UTICA: Tunisian Confederation of Industry, Trade and Handicrafts
column17: Traders and handicraft sellers staged a sit-in and threatened escalation in Houm Souk, Djerba island, if authorities do not fight against illegal trade.

The workers of a factory in Jebel Jelloud staged a protest against other protesters blocking the circulation on the route Z4. A group of unemployed had blocked earlier in the week the entrance to the factory.

The death of a convicted in the prison of Mahdia triggered protests in Jebeniana, where the deceased came from. Family members of the prisoner assaulted the offices of the National Guard and seized a vehicle.
Employees of Tunis Telecom staged a protest in Sfax over mismanagement.
30 unemployed from Kasserine started a sit-in at the Ministry of Employment in Tunis and demand to resume the negotiations with authorities.
Residents staged a sit and obstructed the circulation of vehicles in Mahdia province.
Local residents marched to protest the closing of their delegation as a consequence of a recent administrative reform.
Near Siliana, residents of Ksar Hadid locality erected roadblocks and disrupted the circulation of vehicles to protest against the closing of a primary school.
Clashes erupted between rioters and police, who fired teargas to disperse a group of around 100 stone-throwing young people.
Students protest and strike in Monastir over alleged manipulation of official acts at university.
Teachers staged a sit-in in Redeyef over repeated assaults carried out by pupils and parents.

Unemployed stormed a school and disrupted classes in Foussena. They were initially protesting peacefully outside the local administration, until they decided to enter the school forcing a teacher to quit.
A peaceful march was held near Jedelienne to demand the interruption of drilling operations in the region.
Fishermen protest in Zarzis and blocked access to the port.
Teachers and employees of a primary school in Hammamet protested and went on strike against the repeated assaults on the staff.
Taxi drivers staged a sit-in outside the Ministry of Transport.
Two days of protest were reported in Bizerte where employees in the local hospital staged marches to denounce the degradation of the local police corps.

Hundreds of youths have staged sit-in protests across Tunisia to demand jobs, but the government responded that it is incentivizing the creation of small businesses to address the problem of unemployment. Open sit-in protests are held outside government buildings in most Tunisian provinces. Al-Jazeera highlighted the example of a group of youths from the central Kasserine province who are holding a sit-in outside the Ministry of Labour and Vocational Training in the capital Tunis.
Fishermen continued their movement of protest in Zarzis and blocked traffic in town.
The employees of the airline company Nouvelair organised a sit-in in Djerba airport against the proposed dismissals in the company.
Milk producers staged a sit-in in Tabursuq, spilling milk on the street and demanding a rise in the price of milk.
Two days of protest were reported in Bizerte where employees in the local hospital staged marches to denounce the degradation of the local police corps.
Property destruction: Unknown attackers threw a molotov cocktail on the offices of the TV channel Zitouna TV. Heavy damages but no casualties were reported.
Milk producers from various provinces gathered in protest outside the milk factory of Bou Salem in Jendouba.
A suspected militant was killed on Monday in an exchange of fire with security forces in Mount Mghila

column7: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Movement of forces: The army conducted combing operations in the area of Oued Meliz, Jendouba governorate, after they spotted militants active nearby.
A 65-year-old man was killed during an exchange fire between militants and military forces near Ghardimaou, in western Tunisia.
Teachers staged protests in Hencha after one of their colleagues was assaulted by unknown men in a cafe.
Doctors protested in Haj Ali Soua hospital in Ksar Hellal after a colleague was assaulted by a patient.
Property destruction: Unknown men set on fire the local offices of Ennahda in Zaafrane.
Lawyers staged a protest in the Tribunal of Rist Instance in Kairouan.
Border guard agents and fishermen protested in various areas of Sfax on Thursday.

column7: UNSFST: National Union of Tunisian Security Forces
column17: A large number of security personnel rallied Thursday at El Kasbah Square at the call of the Union of Internal Security Forces, in protest over pay and social conditions.
A group of retired workers who had worked in Libya staged a protest in Kairouan to demand their right to a pension.

column7: UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union; Health Workers (Tunisia)
column17: UGTT-backed health workers protested in Sfax on Friday.
Two groups of youth from El Amra and Msetria clashed in El Amra. The two groups started throwing stones at each other and set cars on fire.
Farmers blocked the route connecting Boussalem and Jendouba, near Bulla Regia, to protest against dropping milk prices.
Unemployed graduates protested in Meknassi on Monday.
Several fishermen staged a protest in the port of Gabes, preventing ships from accessing the port.
Lawyers and magistrates protested in the tribunal of Sidi Bouzid and demanded the recruitment of more judicial personnel.

column7: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Tunisias National Guard and Army units killed four suspected militants in a security operation on Tuesday. There were no security force casualties in the operation in the Ain Jaffel area on the border between the central provinces of Kasserine and Sidi Bouzid.

Tunisian security forces killed five militants near the Libyan border on Wednesday in a gunbattle in which one civilian also died and an army commander was wounded. The militants were killed after being surrounded by troops in a house in El Aouija, 10 kilometres (six miles) outside the town of Ben Guerdane. The civilian was killed by a stray bullet during the gunfight.
Employees in the tourism sector protested in Djerba and staged a march to demand government intervention to help the sector in the region.
A general strike was staged in Sened. Residents marched in protest and demanded jobs and development.
Tension arose in Tozeur when police forces clashed with protesters. Some people were injured and received medical treatment.
Fishermen marched in protest in Sfax to demand improvement in their professional conditions.
Looting: Gunmen attacked houses in the area of Jelma and stole food.
The army fired artillery and bombarded Jebel Mghila after some gunment rob houses near Jelma, in Sidi Bouzid.
Unidentified gunmen attacked a house in Hachana, assaulted and kidnapped a man, before freeing him a few hours later. They also stole food and covers.
A gunmen trying to escape from Ben Guardane was killed on Monday in El Ghariani, on the route between Ben Gardane and Tataouine.

Clashes between Tunisian forces and suspected IS militants left 55 people dead Monday in Ben Gardane. At dawn, gunmen targeted a police station and military facilities in the southern town, in an attempt to establish a ""Daesh emirate"" in Ben Guerdane. Residents told AFP the assailants appeared to be natives of the region. Government said that 36 militants were killed and seven arrested and that 12 security officers and 7 civilians were also killed. The twelve security forces officers killed include a soldier, 10 domestic security officers, one of whom was killed at home. 14 other security officers and three civilians have been injured.

Clashes between Tunisian forces and suspected IS militants left 55 people dead Monday in Ben Gardane. At dawn, gunmen targeted a police station and military facilities in the southern town, in an attempt to establish a ""Daesh emirate"" in Ben Guerdane. Residents told AFP the assailants appeared to be natives of the region. Government said that 36 militants were killed and seven arrested and that 12 security officers and 7 civilians were also killed. The twelve security forces officers killed include a soldier, 10 domestic security officers, one of whom was killed at home. 14 other security officers and three civilians have been injured.

Tunisias army and security forces killed seven militants in an operation near the Libyan border late Tuesday. The gunmen were killed in Benniri area, five km from Ben Guardane. Sporadic gunfire on Tuesday was also heard in the outskirts of Ben Guerdane as Tunisian forces searched for attackers still at large.
In Medenine, students march in solidarity with the armed forces and against the IS militants.
Another march was organised in Jelma to support the armed forces and the citizens of Ben Gardane.
The local branch of URT organised a march to express solidarity with the police forces killed in Ben Gardane.

On Wednesday, two gunmen who raided a construction site looking for food died in a battle with security forces, while two others who attacked a house in search of something to eat escaped. A soldier was also killed in the clashes. Another suspect barricaded inside a house died in a gunbattle in El Amria

On Wednesday, two gunmen who raided a construction site looking for food died in a battle with security forces, while two others who attacked a house in search of something to eat escaped. A soldier was also killed in the clashes. Another suspect barricaded inside a house died in a gunbattle in El Amria

Three militants were killed Thursday in security operations in Tunisias border area of Ben Guerdane. One of the militants was killed in Zokra district after he shot at an army and police patrol. The two others were killed in Hassi al-Nour district, where another man was also detained and four Kalashnikov rifles were seized.

Three militants were killed Thursday in security operations in Tunisias border area of Ben Guerdane. One of the militants was killed in Zokra district after he shot at an army and police patrol. The two others were killed in Hassi al-Nour district, where another man was also detained and four Kalashnikov rifles were seized.
A gunman died of his wounds on Tuesday after having attacked a house in Hnich region last week.
Citizens marched in solidarity with armed forces and against terrorism.
Citizens protested in Ben Gardane at the arrival of Helath Minister Said Aidi. The demonstrators denounced the lack of equipment.
Gunshots were reportedly heard in Ben Gardane between elements of the army and armed militants.

column7: SRES: Regional Union of Secondary Education; Labour Group (Tunisia)
column17: Unions staged a sit-in outside the Education Department in Kairouan.

column7: UTICA: Tunisian Confederation of Industry, Trade and Handicrafts
column17: UTICA organised sit-ins in support of Ben Gardane and the armed forces.

A group of fishermen from the south-eastern Tunisian city of Sfax have threatened to sail with their boats towards the Italian island of Lampedusa to protest against the ministry of agriculture and fisheries in case it does not take their requests into consideration. Similar protests were staged in other ports along the Tunisian coast, including Monastir, Mahdia and Zarzis and Djerba in the south.

A group of fishermen from the south-eastern Tunisian city of Sfax have threatened to sail with their boats towards the Italian island of Lampedusa to protest against the ministry of agriculture and fisheries in case it does not take their requests into consideration. Similar protests were staged in other ports along the Tunisian coast, including Monastir, Mahdia and Zarzis and Djerba in the south.

A group of fishermen from the south-eastern Tunisian city of Sfax have threatened to sail with their boats towards the Italian island of Lampedusa to protest against the ministry of agriculture and fisheries in case it does not take their requests into consideration. Similar protests were staged in other ports along the Tunisian coast, including Monastir, Mahdia and Zarzis and Djerba in the south.

A group of fishermen from the south-eastern Tunisian city of Sfax have threatened to sail with their boats towards the Italian island of Lampedusa to protest against the ministry of agriculture and fisheries in case it does not take their requests into consideration. Similar protests were staged in other ports along the Tunisian coast, including Monastir, Mahdia and Zarzis and Djerba in the south.

A group of fishermen from the south-eastern Tunisian city of Sfax have threatened to sail with their boats towards the Italian island of Lampedusa to protest against the ministry of agriculture and fisheries in case it does not take their requests into consideration. Similar protests were staged in other ports along the Tunisian coast, including Monastir, Mahdia and Zarzis and Djerba in the south.
Strikes: Workers staged a strike in Sfax, Sousse and Bizerte
Residents of Meknassi protested outside their delegation against the allegedly illegal recruitment of 100 miners.
Fishermen shut down the ports of Chebba and Mahdia in protest against authorities.
Fishermen shut down the ports of Chebba and Mahdia in protest against authorities.
A group of people, who called themselves ""Tawk"", protested outside the offices of the regional administration of Gabes and demanded employment.
Protesters started burning tyres in Meknassi after the recruitment of 100 people in the mining sector.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Three militants attacked a border post called ""Laej"" near Sakiet Sidi Youssef and exchanged fire with national guard officers.

New clashes were reported near Ben Gardane, where Tunisian forces killed two militants on Saturday. The intervention was reportedly linked to the attack that took place last week in the border town. Security have been conducting sweeps in the region against IS militants.
The Ministry reported that a soldier was wounded during an exchange of fire Saturday morning between army units and militant group at Jabal Samama

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Four family members attacked a post of the National Guard in Ouled Chamekh in the attempt of freeing their brother. They also tried to set the chief police officer on fire.

A fire exchange is taking place in Ben Guerdane between security and army units and a militant suspected of being linked to the attack in early March. Some police forces and a civilian were reportedly wounded.

Two servicemen were wounded, Sunday at dawn, during a sweeping operation conducted since Saturday in the mountainous region of Jebel Samama. One of the two servicemen was injured at his leg following the explosion of a landmine and the other was shot in his legs.

Two servicemen were wounded, Sunday at dawn, during a sweeping operation conducted since Saturday in the mountainous region of Jebel Samama. One of the two servicemen was injured at his leg following the explosion of a landmine and the other was shot in his legs.
A group of people who were granted amnesty protested outside the Parliament and started a hunger strike demanding to take part in training courses they were promised.

After having encircled his house on Sunday, Tunisias security forces have killed an IS militant in the outskirts of the southern border town of Ben Guerdane. Eleven persons including a civilian and security and army officers were injured during the clashes in Ben Guerdane.

column7: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Several National Guard agents protested in Tataouine demanding their overdue wages.
Farmers and milk producers protested in Gafsa over the decline in the price of milk and demanded support from the government.

Tensions continue in Meknassi where young people burnt tyres and blocked the circulation of vehicles to express their discontent with the allegedly rigged recruitment of 100 people in the phosphate mines.
Border agents protested in Kasserine demanding more security.
Bakers in Regueb went on strike on Tuesday and protested outside the local administration offices on Wednesday.
Residents of Bardo protested outside the Parliament on Saturday against a railway plan in their area.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Defusal: Units of the National Guard seized explosives and explosive belts in El Aouija, around 10 km from Ben Gardane.
Unemployed staged a peaceful march in Meknassi. They have been protesting for months against the lack of jobs in the area.
Primary school teachers protested in El Manara, Gabes Sud, after a a classroom burst into flames. The movement coincided with the visit of the Education Minister in Gabes.

Several people who were granted an amnesty protested in Tunis and demanded the application of a decree on amnesty approved in 2011. A sit-in has been going on for weeks, but on Monday the protesters have escalated their demands and some of the sit-inners sealed their lips.
21 unemployed who are staging a sit-in inside the offices of the governorate in Kasserine went into hunger strike on Tuesday.
A soldier is wounded after being hit by a landmine during a patrol operation on Mount Semmama.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) Border Guards
column17: A border guard was injured late Wednesday in an ambush by more than a dozen militants in the locality of Bouchebka, near Feriana.
Secondary school teachers staged a protest in Ariana against the Ministrys policies.
Health workers protested in Sidi Bouzid.
Public sector workers staged a sit-in inside the offices of the municipality of Sfax.
Residents of La Marsa and civil society members staged a protest movement against corruption and the proliferation of illegal housing in their town.

A sixty-year-old woman was shot down while on her car by presumed Islamist militants in Ain Zayane, delegation of Sbiba, Kasserine province. Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade issued a statement to deny involvement.
A peaceful protest was staged in the hospitl of Kebili, where doctors wore a red bracelet to demand the recruitment of more staff.
Border agents staged a protest in Tozeur against the arrest of a colleague who shot down a smuggler last week.
Residents of El Hammam blocked the road peacefully to protest against lack of potable water in their village.
Three protesters staging a sit-in outside the Ministry of Professional Training and Employment attempted suicide in an escalation of their movement.
Police managed to disperse the sit-in outside the company Petrofac in the island of Kerkennah

A police convoy en route to disperse a sit-in that had been going on for 78 days outside the oil company Petrofac in Kerkennah island clashed with rioters who blocked the road near Mellita. Security forces fired teargas to disperse the protesters, before the group turned violent and started pelting stones and destroying police vehicles. An agent was injured in his face.
Families of Tunisians detained in Iraq staged a protest outside the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and demanded the liberation and repatriation of their relatives.
Magistrates protested outside the tribunal of Gafsa. They voiced their discontent with a proposed bill which would reform the judiciary sector.
The family of one of the officers in after having killed a man during a patrol operation staged a protest outside the governorate of Sidi Bouzid.
Farmers protested and blocked the road between Jendouba and Fernana, near the locality of Oued Ghzala (location coded as Oued ez Zlazel).
Farmers protested in Beja distributing milk outside the offices of the governorate.
Retail sellers protested in Tozeur outside the governorate.
Teachers staged a sit-in in Sousse, to demand the regularisation of their professional condition.

Five protesters staged a sit-in at the train station of Zannouch. The movement was ended after negotiations with the authorities. The reasons of the protest were not clear, nor was the starting date of the movement.
Specialised doctors protested in the regional hospital of Mohamed Sassi in Gabes. They demanded the recruitment of staff.
Protesters blocked the border post of Ras Ajdir to prevent Libyan trucks from enterring Tunisia.

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Tunisian security forces have shot dead a suspected jihadist in the countries northwest in Seddin forest, near Sakiet Sidi Yussef. The ministry said the suspect was killed in an ambush laid for two jihadists riding a motorbike and that the other man was wounded but escaped. A Kalashnikov assault rifle and two bags filled with explosives were seized.
20 young unemployed started a hunger strike inside the local administration offices of Sbeitla.

column7: UGET: General Union of Tunisian Students
column17: Around 60 unemployed supported by the UGET assembled outside government offices in Tunis and tried to enter the buildings. Five police officers were injured by stone throwing, as well as several demonstrators during subsequent clashes with police. Nearly twenty protesters were arrested.
Protesters blocked the port of Kerkennah.
Traders blocked the road between Ras Ajdir and Ben Gardane to prevent Libyan trucks from enterring Tunisian territory. The incident occurred in the locality of Al Jmila.
A group of employees in the phosphate company of Gafsa staged a protest movement outside the companies offices in Redeyef.
Trade unionists staged a protest march in Hydra to express support with a primary school teacher accused of selling milk originally destined to pupils.
A group of unemployed graduates protested outside the governorate offices in Sidi Bouzid.
Milk producers continued their protest and staged a sit-in in Jendouba.
Demonstrators assaulted and wounded three journalists of Nessma TV covering the protests at the Petrofac site in Kerkennah island.
Transport of phosphate was blocked Tuesday in Metlaoui due to a sit-in organised by a group of unemployed.
Street sellers protested after the destruction of their kiosks in Jendouba.
Unemployed graduates protested in Houmet Souk demanding jobs.

column16: Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Mosaique FM
column17: Clashes erupted on Thursday evening in Kerkennah between police and demonstrators as the latter prevented Petrofac trucks coming from the port of Sidi Youssef from entering. Police used tear gas and water jets to disperse protesters who threw stones at law enforcement officers. Two local police posts were also set on fire during the violent skirmishes.
Clashes between police and protesters continued on Friday on the main road of Kerkennah island. Protesters erected roablocks and threw stones at police, who reacted by firing teargas.
Traders and families of Tunisians detained in Libya staged a protest near Zokra, between Ben Gardane and Ras Jedir.
The Union for Unemployed Graduates organised a peaceful march in Sidi Bouzid demanding jobs.
Smugglers staged a protest in Ben Gardane against the ban on imported petrol.
Truck drivers carrying cereals protested at the entrance of the town of Sfax.
A protesting unemployed graduate attempted suicide in Sned ingesting a large quantity of medicines.
Residents of Kef took to the streets to protest against PM Habib Essid who was visiting the town.
Teachers in Mjez el Beb protested the aggression of one of their colleagues.

column7: UDC: Union for Unemployed Graduates; UGET: General Union of Tunisian Students
column17: Clashes between demonstrators belonging to UGET and UDC and police forces erupted in Tunis on Wednesday. Two protesters injured and three arrested.
Fishermen have been protesting in Tabarka demanding improved working conditions. Not clear when the protests started
Factory workers protested in Bizerte.
Protests were reported in Jendouba, where employees in the forest sector staged a march to demand improved job protection.
Families of fishermen arrested in Tabarka protested to demand the liberation of their relatives.
A group of residents from Radhaa blocked a road to protest during the visit of the Agriculture Minister in Mazzouna. They denounced lack of potable water and high husbandry costs.

column7: UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union; Tunisian League for the Defense of Unemployed Graduates; Health Workers (Tunisia)
column17: Two separate sit-ins were held on Monday in Tunis by workers in the health sector and unemployed graduates.
Traders opened a sit-in in Zokra to demand the resume of commercial activity across the Libyan border.
The Popular Front organised a sit-in outside the Ministry of Justice.

column7: URAP: Regional Union of Agriculture and Fisheries
column17: Farmers protested in Kairouan.
Health agents protested outside the hospita against ministerial policies.
Two civilians were shot and injured by ""extremists"" near Jendouba.
Residents of Ain Tourkia protested against water cuts.
The UTT organised a ""day of rage"" marching in central Tunis to demand more pluralism and the inclusion of UTT in union negotiations.

Clashes occurred between communal groups near Souk Lahad. Residents of Zaouiet el Anes and Bechri clashed over different views on land property. National Guard and army intervened to restore the calm.
Employees in the local phosphate company shut down the administrative offices of their company against the reduction of the workforce.
Local administration officers protested in Medenine.
Employees in the environmental company of Gafsa gathered in protest on Wednesday.

column16: African Manager; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: New clashes were reported on Wednesday in Souk Lahad between residents of Zouiat el Anes and Bechri. Gunfire took place during the clashes.
Families of detainees protested outside the tribunal of First Instance in Bizerte.
Three soldiers were injured after hitting a landmine in Jebel Semmama.
184 school directors protested in Le Kef.
A group of workers in a local oil company protested in Tataouine to demand the regularisation of their professional situation.
The Tunisian League for Tolerance staged a protest in central Tunis against the rise of extremism. An opposing faction chanted slogans against the LTT demonstration.
Taxi drivers staged a protest in Gafsa, during which they also threatened to commit suicide.

Tunisian security forces used tear gas on Monday against hundreds of people in the southern town of Ben Guerdane protesting against the closure of the border with Libya. Around 1,000 people rallied outside local government offices and set tyres ablaze in protest against a Libyan decision to close the Ras Jedir border crossing.
Public sector workers staged a protest in Sfax.
Protests continue for a second day in Ben Gardane, where demonstrators blocked the circulation of vehicles and burnt tyres against the closure of the border passage of Ras Ajdir.

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Four policemen were killed when a militant detonated his explosives belt after a firefight erupted in the Tatouine governorate. A national guard unit had carried out the raid acting on information from an ""anti-militant"" operation earlier the same day near Tunis. One armed element was shot dead while the other detonated his explosives belt, killing two officers and two agents of the national guard. The gunmen were allegedly connected with the March attack in Ben Gardane.

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Two armed militants described were killed and 16 others arrested, Wednesday in the delegation of El Mnihla (governorate of Ariana), by National Guard units.

Ben Gardane went on strike on Wednesday in protest at a decision by Libyan authorities late last month to halt cross-border trade on which its economy depends. Shops and offices in the town of 60,000 inhabitants were all closed in response to the one-day strike called by the UGTT main trade union confederation. Despite the oppressive heat, hundreds of protesters gathered in front of the union offices in Ben Guerdane but a planned march failed to take place. Several tyres were earlier set alight on the towns streets but there was no intervention by the large number of police present.

A peaceful march to denounce terrorism set out Thursday from the seat of the governorate of Tataouine. Citizens, civil society activists, representatives of political parties and professional organisations marched towards the National Guard station to reiterate support for the military and police in their war on terror.
The journalists of the Tunisian newspaper Attounissia organised a two-day protest sit-in outside the offices of their company. They protested against the failed respect of their contracts.
Police fired teargas to disperse protesters that blocked the RN16 near Tozeur and burnt tyres. The demonstrators called for the reallocation of farming lands.
The journalists of the Tunisian newspaper Attounissia organised a two-day protest sit-in outside the offices of their company. They protested against the failed respect of their contracts.
A landmine exploded near an army convoy on Jebel Mghila. No casualties were reported.
Demonstrators staged a protest outside the governorate of Sfax over degradation in the hospital Habib Bourguiba.

Tunisias military has killed an extremist described during a security operation. Seifeddine Jameli, known as Abou al-Qaaqaa, belonged to the Tunisian branch of the Islamic State (IS) group, Jund al-Khilafa (the soldiers of the caliphate), and was killed overnight by special forces in the central region of Mount Mghilla
Taxi drivers protested in Sidi Bouzid
Residents and civil society actors protested in El Mansoura beach in the town of Kelibia against the degradation of the coastal area.
The closure of an industrial complex in Zeramedine prompted a general strike in town. The demonstrators also burnt tyres and blocked the circulation of vehicles in the area.
Residents from Dbebcha village protested outside the governorate of Kairouan against cuts in the provision of potable water.
A protest was staged outside the presidential palace in Tunis to denounce the proliferation of illegal commercial activities.
Weapons Seizure: An arsenal containing heavy weaponry was discovered by the army in Ben Gardane. It contained 29 AK-47 rifles, 3 RPGs, 130 magazines and 9520 ammos.
The employees of the Perenco oil company started a protest outside the HQ of the company in the desert of Kebili.
A soldier was injured after a landmine exploded on Mount Semmama.

column7: Journalists (Tunisia); UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union
column17: The journalists of the Tunisian newspaper Attounsia protested outside the HQ of the UGTT in Tunis. In a separate protest at UGTT headquarters, hundreds of people protested in Tunisia against a bill to enforce a compulsory retirement age at 65 as the government announced that pension funds are in deficit.
A group of unemployed graduates from El Ayoun protested in Kasserine seizing the car of the governor after the cancellation of an official visit by the Development minister.
Military bombed Mount Semmama for two days starting on Saturday.
Residents of El Ghdhabna protested and blocked the road connecting Ksour Essef and Chebba to demand the establishment of a new municipality.
Residents of Saidane protested to demand jobs and development in their region.
Mothers of Tunisians dispersed abroad protested outside a theatre in central Tunis to demand information on the fate of their children.
Military bombed Mount Semmama for two days starting on Saturday.
Residents of Tajerouine protested against the introduction of a new municipality.

A landmine blast killed two women and wounded a third on Monday near Mount Sammama. The two were killed while gathering herbs when the home-made device exploded near the base of Mount Sammama in the Kasserine region. Authorities blamed the armed Islamists active in the Kasserine region.
Residents of El Ghdhabna protested and blocked the road connecting Ksour Essef and Chebba to demand the establishment of a new municipality.
A group of residents from Sidi Maamar village protested and occupied the autoroute at the entrance of Hammamet.
Striking teachers protested outside Parliament before sneaking into the Assembly.
Workers from the Tunisian Chemical Group (GCT) struck and marched in protest after the death of a worker in the company.
Railway workers struck and protested at Tunis railway station.

column16: Mosaique FM; Shems FM; Tunisie Numerique
column17: Violence was reported in Douz, after a brawl between young people from Douz and Kalaa. Violence escalated in open battle which prompted the intervention of security forces to restore the order. A young people was killed in the clashes and several police forces were reported injured. A second person died of his injuries a few days later.
Youths from Menzel Bouzaiene staged a sit-in and blocked the circulation of vehicles on the national route n.14.
Court clerks staged a sit-in outside the Parliament.
Education workers staged a protest in Medenine.
A group of armed residents from Douz tried to attack the village of Kalaa but were repelled by police forces. Clashes between the attackers and security agents ensued.
A hundred residents of Zorda burnt tyres and blocked traffic in Zorda, delegation of Mahdia. They were protesting against the failed creation of a municipality for their town.
Violence resumed in Douz where armed men from Douz tried to attack Kalaa. Security forces fired teargas to disperse the combatants.
Sit-in in Zorga, Beja province, to demand the creation of a municipality.
Residents of Dar Bel Ouaer burnt tyres on the national route 2 near Enfidha to protest the failed creation of a municipality.
Renewed clashes were reported in Douz between police and young people.

Five unemployed attempted suicide in Kasserine, escalating a sit-in in the offices of the governorate of Kasserine.
Tax drivers rallied in protest outside the police station of Kebili Nord to demand stronger fight against abusive taxis.

column7: Police Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) Prison Guards

The people of Kalaa gathered in protest outside the governorate of Kebili to demand the end of the cofnrontation against the residents of Douz.
A ""significant"" number of protesters gathered in Kasserine outside the offices of the local water company. Water supplies were repeatedly cut over the past weeks.
The post offices of Tunis were shut down on Thursday as a consequence of a strike in the capital. A demonstration was held outside the Ministry of Economy.
Residents of El Mourouj, in Medenine, protested against the lack of electricity supply. Location coded as Medenine, with GeoPrecision code as 3.
The army bombarded Jebel Selloum on Friday and Saturday. No casualties were reported.
For a second consecutive day residents protested in Kasserine against the interruptions to water supplies in the region.
The army bombarded Jebel Selloum on Friday and Saturday. No casualties were reported.

Residents of Medjez El Beb organised a night march to demand the creation of a new governorate replacing the old delegation.
Some post offices were shut down in Kebili due to protest sit-ins.
Algerian lawyers protested in Tunis demanding the regularisation of their professional position.
Three unions, civil society members and political parties organised a protest march in Tataouine to demand the establishment of a high school.
Defusal: Two bombs were discovered and defused near Bilal Mosque in Jendouba.
Security Measures: Tunisia on Monday extended by a month a state of emergency in place since November following a series of Islamist attacks on civilians and military forces.
Workers of Tunisia Telecom protested in Sidi Bouzid and staged a sit-in.
A man was injured following the explosion of a mine in a house in Ben Gardane. The house was damaged during the March attack carried out by armed men affiliated to the Islamic State in Libya.
Protests in the hospital of Kerkennah against staff shortage.
Fish sellers protested in Sfax and shut down the local fish market of Bab Jebli.
Tribunal agents protested in Kebili
Traders protested in Ben Gardane and blocked the national route 1.
Civil society members protested outside the governorate of Kebili to demand the reintegration of the local delegate for Childhood who was recently dismissed.
Around 400 farmers from Ain Boumarra blocked vehicles on the RN 3 between Sbikha and Kairouan. They were protesting against the ministerial decision to close the Nahbane dam.
Journalists staged a protest against the governor in Sidi Bouzid to denounce discriminatory behaviour.
Parents of pupils protested in Jendouba against exam results.
Tunisian air force bombed Jebel Ouergha on Thursday.
Employees in the Presidency of the Republic gathered in protest outside the Presidential Palace to demand an increase in their salaries.
Students staged a sit-in at the Faculty of Law and Political Sciences in El Manar area of Tunis.
Several traders from Ben Gardane burnt tyres and blocked vehicles in Ben Gardane to protest against the behaviour of Libyan auhorities in the border passage of Ras Jedir.

After the release of employment lists in the mining basin of Gafsa, protests took place across the governorate. In Mdhilla, young people blocked the roads and blocked the circulation of vehicles carrying phosphate and public transport.

After the release of employment lists in the mining basin of Gafsa, protests took place across the governorate. In Metlaoui, demonstrators blocked the railway and prevented trains from reaching the mining basin.

column16: Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Shems FM; Tunisie Numerique
column17: At least one militant was injured during a shootout with security forces in Zarzoura, near Le Kef. The body of a deceased militant was found in the same region a few weeks later. He was presumably killed in the shootout against the military occurred at the beginning of the month.
Five families staged a demonstration in Skhira after the release of employment lists in an anglo-indian company. They claimed that the selection was rigged to grant employment to other applicants.
Parents of pupils protested in Beja after exam results being published.

column8: Police Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) Prison Guards
column17: The National Union of Domestic Security Forces reported that a prison guard was assaulted and injured in Monastir by ""bearded people"", allegedly Islamists.
Resident of Nezla neighbourhood protested against interruption in electricity supply.
A group of candidates who had applied for a job in the mining basin of Miknassi rallied in protest outside the governorate of Sidi Bouzid on the last day of Ramadan.

The access to the industrial zone of Skhira delegation were reopened late on Friday afternoon, after the blockade imposed since Thursday night, by unemployed youth protesting against the recruitment recently announced by the Tunisian-Indian company fertilizer ""Tifert"".
The route connecting El Haouaria to the beach was blocked by a sit-in of ship owners demanding the authorisation for their job.

Residents of Hajeb El Ajoun marched in protest to denounce the deterioration of the health situation and the poor condition of infrastructure across the region. The protest came after car accidents that claimed several victims over the past weeks.
Roadblocks were reported between Ennadhour and El Kantar, as residents of Siseb el Kobra took to the streets to demand the creation of a municipality.
In Balta near Jendouba, residents protested the delays in the reparation of water pipelines.
A strike was launched in the Ministry of Education. Protesters demand the revision of their pension scheme. Outside the Ministry, striking teachers also organised a protest sit-in.
A car accident triggered protests near the village of Saada. Residents blocked traffic on the national route 17 connecting Jendouba and Kef.
Residents of Kesra, in Siliana, blocked the circulation of vehicles between Le Kef and Kairouan to protest the interruption of water supplies.

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard

Communal clashes resumed in Souk Lahad between the Zaouiet El Harth and Om Essomaa clans. Three people were injured in the clashes.
Army units bombed the mountains near Kasserine.
A sit-in the train station of Metlaoui blocked the transport of phosphate to the Gafsa mining basin.
Self harm and psychological intervention: Several unemployed graduates attempted suicide by hanging or self-immolation in Ksar to denounce the stalemate in the negotiations with the authorities.
Civil society organistions marched on Avenue Bourguiba in Tunis to protest the proposed bill on economic reconciliation, which would grant amnesty to some of Ben Alis cronies.
More than 100 factory workers blocked the road connecting Kairouan with Sousse over possibility of being dismissed.
Private drivers gathered in protest outside the offices of UTICA, the association of entrepreneurs, in Tunis.
A group of striking teachers protested outside the Ministry of Education.

Teachers protested outside the Ministry of Education demanding to be recruited.
Bdoura residents blocked the circulation of vehicles to protest the deteriorating conditions of their region.
Unemployed and civil society members continued their protest activity in Sidi Bouzid by shutting down the road linking Sfax and Gafsa and administrative offices in Bouzaiene.

A landmine killed a Tunisian soldier on Friday during a operation to track down militants in the countries mountainous west. The explosion occurred in Jebel Semmama and was claimed by Katiba Okba Ibn Nafaa.
Roadblocks were erected in Bir Ali Ben Khalifa as protesters took to the streets to denounce the lack of equipment in the local hospital.

Hundreds of Tunisian demonstrated Monday in the capital to protest against a bill being discussed in parliament to grant amnesty to people accused of corruption. On Monday, protesters chanted ""No to reconciliation"" and ""The people want the fall of corruption"".
Residents of Fadhelallah protested peacefully demanding the creation of a new municipality.
Police dispersed rioters in Remada, who protested after a petrol smuggler was shot down by border guards in the desert area nearby.
A peaceful protest took place outside the local authority offices in Sidi Bouzid under the initiative of unemployed people.
The death of a pregnant woman in the hospital premises triggered another protest march in Bir Ali Ben Khalifa

Teachers protested in Beja on Wednesday.
Taxi drivers staged a peaceful protest in Monastir.
Repeated cuts to water supplies triggered protests in the region of Mornaguia, in the governorate of Manouba.

Taxi drivers protested in Sidi Bouzid
Hospital doctors in El Omrane staged a sit-in.
Residents marched in Ghannouch to protest against the spread of diseases in the region leading to a serious health crisis.
A landmine exploded and injured a soldier in Jebel Semmama.
New protests erupted in Msaken to demand that the local tyre factory is reopened. The circulation of vehicles in the region was disrupted for at least 24 hours.
A group of residents from Oued Elkhatef near Kelibia demanded the reopening of the local post office.
Driving school owners staged a protest in Beja after the suicide of one of their colleagues in Ben Arous.
